   <h1 id="firstHeading" class="firstHeading" lang="en">Solar eclipse</h1> 
   <div id="bodyContent" class="mw-body-content"> 
    <div id="siteSub" class="noprint">
     From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia
    </div> 
    <div id="contentSub"></div> 
    <div id="jump-to-nav" class="mw-jump">
      Jump to: 
     <a href="#mw-head">navigation</a>, 
     <a href="#p-search">search</a> 
    </div> 
    <div id="mw-content-text" lang="en" dir="ltr" class="mw-content-ltr">
     <div class="mw-parser-output">
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       "Eclipse of the Sun" redirects here. For the film, see 
       <a href="/wiki/Eclipse_of_the_Sun_(film)" title="Eclipse of the Sun (film)">Eclipse of the Sun (film)</a>. For the novel, see 
       <a href="/wiki/Eclipse_of_the_Sun_(novel)" title="Eclipse of the Sun (novel)">Eclipse of the Sun (novel)</a>.
      </div> 
      <table class="infobox" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="width: 320px;"> 
       <tbody>
        <tr> 
         <td><a href="/wiki/File:Solar_eclipse_1999_4_NR.jpg" class="image" title="Total solar eclipse"><img alt="Total solar eclipse" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1c/Solar_eclipse_1999_4_NR.jpg/308px-Solar_eclipse_1999_4_NR.jpg" width="308" height="303" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1c/Solar_eclipse_1999_4_NR.jpg/462px-Solar_eclipse_1999_4_NR.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1c/Solar_eclipse_1999_4_NR.jpg/616px-Solar_eclipse_1999_4_NR.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3543" data-file-height="3489"></a></td> 
        </tr> 
        <tr> 
         <td>A <i>total solar eclipse</i> occurs when the Moon completely covers the Sun's disk, as seen in this <a href="/wiki/Solar_eclipse_of_August_11,_1999" title="Solar eclipse of August 11, 1999">1999 solar eclipse</a>. <a href="/wiki/Solar_prominence" title="Solar prominence">Solar prominences</a> can be seen along the limb (in red) as well as extensive <a href="/wiki/Corona" title="Corona">coronal</a> filaments.</td> 
        </tr> 
        <tr> 
         <td><a href="/wiki/File:Annular_Eclipse._Taken_from_Middlegate,_Nevada_on_May_20,_2012.jpg" class="image" title="Annular solar eclipse"><img alt="Annular solar eclipse" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/37/Annular_Eclipse._Taken_from_Middlegate%2C_Nevada_on_May_20%2C_2012.jpg/154px-Annular_Eclipse._Taken_from_Middlegate%2C_Nevada_on_May_20%2C_2012.jpg" width="154" height="154" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/37/Annular_Eclipse._Taken_from_Middlegate%2C_Nevada_on_May_20%2C_2012.jpg/231px-Annular_Eclipse._Taken_from_Middlegate%2C_Nevada_on_May_20%2C_2012.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/37/Annular_Eclipse._Taken_from_Middlegate%2C_Nevada_on_May_20%2C_2012.jpg/308px-Annular_Eclipse._Taken_from_Middlegate%2C_Nevada_on_May_20%2C_2012.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1801" data-file-height="1801"></a><a href="/wiki/File:Partial_solar_eclipse_Oct_23_2014_Minneapolis_5-36pm_Ruen1.png" class="image" title="Partial solar eclipse"><img alt="Partial solar eclipse" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/09/Partial_solar_eclipse_Oct_23_2014_Minneapolis_5-36pm_Ruen1.png/154px-Partial_solar_eclipse_Oct_23_2014_Minneapolis_5-36pm_Ruen1.png" width="154" height="154" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/09/Partial_solar_eclipse_Oct_23_2014_Minneapolis_5-36pm_Ruen1.png/231px-Partial_solar_eclipse_Oct_23_2014_Minneapolis_5-36pm_Ruen1.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/09/Partial_solar_eclipse_Oct_23_2014_Minneapolis_5-36pm_Ruen1.png/308px-Partial_solar_eclipse_Oct_23_2014_Minneapolis_5-36pm_Ruen1.png 2x" data-file-width="1181" data-file-height="1180"></a></td> 
        </tr> 
        <tr> 
         <td>An <i>annular solar eclipse</i> (left) occurs when the Moon is too far away to completely cover the Sun's disk (<a href="/wiki/Solar_eclipse_of_May_20,_2012" title="Solar eclipse of May 20, 2012">May 20, 2012</a>). During a <i>partial solar eclipse</i> (right), the Moon blocks only part of the Sun's disk (<a href="/wiki/Solar_eclipse_of_October_23,_2014" title="Solar eclipse of October 23, 2014">October 23, 2014</a>).</td> 
        </tr> 
       </tbody>
      </table> 
      <p>A <b>solar eclipse</b> (as seen from the planet <a href="/wiki/Earth" title="Earth">Earth</a>) is a type of <a href="/wiki/Eclipse" title="Eclipse">eclipse</a> that occurs when the <a href="/wiki/Moon" title="Moon">Moon</a> passes between the <a href="/wiki/Sun" title="Sun">Sun</a> and Earth, and when the Moon fully or partially blocks ("<a href="/wiki/Occultation" title="Occultation">occults</a>") the Sun. This can happen only at <a href="/wiki/New_moon" title="New moon">new moon</a> when the Sun and the Moon are in <a href="/wiki/Conjunction_(astronomy_and_astrology)" class="mw-redirect" title="Conjunction (astronomy and astrology)">conjunction</a> as seen from Earth in an alignment referred to as <a href="/wiki/Syzygy_(astronomy)" title="Syzygy (astronomy)">syzygy</a>. In a total <a href="/wiki/Eclipse" title="Eclipse">eclipse</a>, the disk of the Sun is fully obscured by the Moon. In <a href="#Types">partial and annular eclipses</a>, only part of the Sun is obscured.</p> 
      <p>If the Moon were in a perfectly circular orbit, a little closer to the Earth, and in the same <a href="/wiki/Ecliptic" title="Ecliptic">orbital plane</a>, there would be total solar eclipses every new moon. However, since the Moon's orbit is <a href="/wiki/Inclination" class="mw-redirect" title="Inclination">tilted</a> at more than 5 degrees to the Earth's orbit around the Sun, its shadow usually misses Earth. The Moon's orbit must cross Earth's <a href="/wiki/Ecliptic" title="Ecliptic">ecliptic</a> plane in order for an eclipse (both solar as well as <a href="/wiki/Lunar_eclipse" title="Lunar eclipse">lunar</a>) to occur. In addition, the Moon's actual orbit is elliptical, often taking it far enough away from Earth that its <a href="/wiki/Apparent_size" class="mw-redirect" title="Apparent size">apparent size</a> is not large enough to block the Sun entirely. The orbital planes cross each other at a <a href="/wiki/Line_of_nodes" class="mw-redirect" title="Line of nodes">line of nodes</a> resulting in at least two, and up to five, solar eclipses occurring each year; no more than two of which can be total eclipses.<sup id="cite_ref-totality_1-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-totality-1">[1]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2">[2]</a></sup> However, total solar eclipses are rare at any particular location because totality exists only along a narrow path on the Earth's surface traced by the Moon's shadow or <a href="/wiki/Umbra" class="mw-redirect" title="Umbra">umbra</a>.</p> 
      <p>An eclipse is a <a href="/wiki/Natural_phenomenon" class="mw-redirect" title="Natural phenomenon">natural phenomenon</a>. However, in some ancient and modern cultures, solar eclipses were attributed to <a href="/wiki/Supernatural" title="Supernatural">supernatural</a> causes or regarded as bad <a href="/wiki/Omen" title="Omen">omens</a>. A total solar eclipse can be frightening to people who are unaware of its <a href="/wiki/Astronomy" title="Astronomy">astronomical</a> explanation, as the Sun seems to disappear during the day and the sky darkens in a matter of minutes.</p> 
      <p>Since <a href="/wiki/Sungazing" title="Sungazing">looking directly at the Sun</a> can lead to permanent eye damage or blindness, special eye protection or indirect viewing techniques are used when viewing a solar eclipse. It is technically safe to view only the total phase of a total solar eclipse with the unaided eye and without protection; however, this is a dangerous practice, as most people are not trained to recognize the phases of an eclipse, which can span over two hours while the total phase can only last a maximum of 7.5 minutes for any one location. People referred to as <i><a href="/wiki/Eclipse_chasers" class="mw-redirect" title="Eclipse chasers">eclipse chasers</a></i> or <i>umbraphiles</i> will travel to remote locations to observe or witness predicted central solar eclipses.<sup id="cite_ref-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-3">[3]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-4">[4]</a></sup></p> 
      <p></p>

      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Types">Types</span></h2> 
      <div class="thumb tleft"> 
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:202px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Solar_Eclipse_May_20,2012.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/22/Solar_Eclipse_May_20%2C2012.jpg/200px-Solar_Eclipse_May_20%2C2012.jpg" width="200" height="200" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/22/Solar_Eclipse_May_20%2C2012.jpg/300px-Solar_Eclipse_May_20%2C2012.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/22/Solar_Eclipse_May_20%2C2012.jpg/400px-Solar_Eclipse_May_20%2C2012.jpg 2x" data-file-width="4777" data-file-height="4777"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption"> 
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Solar_Eclipse_May_20,2012.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div> Partial and annular phases of solar eclipse on May 20, 2012
        </div> 
       </div> 
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright"> 
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Comparison_angular_diameter.svg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2c/Comparison_angular_diameter.svg/220px-Comparison_angular_diameter.svg.png" width="220" height="220" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2c/Comparison_angular_diameter.svg/330px-Comparison_angular_diameter.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2c/Comparison_angular_diameter.svg/440px-Comparison_angular_diameter.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="512" data-file-height="512"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption"> 
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Comparison_angular_diameter.svg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div> Comparison of minimum and maximum apparent sizes of the Sun and Moon (and planets). An annular eclipse can occur when the Sun has a larger apparent size than the Moon, whereas a total eclipse can occur when the Moon has a larger apparent size.
        </div> 
       </div> 
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright"> 
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:The_Patrial_Eclipse.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bd/The_Patrial_Eclipse.jpg/220px-The_Patrial_Eclipse.jpg" width="220" height="214" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bd/The_Patrial_Eclipse.jpg/330px-The_Patrial_Eclipse.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bd/The_Patrial_Eclipse.jpg/440px-The_Patrial_Eclipse.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1497" data-file-height="1453"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption"> 
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:The_Patrial_Eclipse.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div> Partial solar eclipse during annular 
         <a href="/wiki/Solar_eclipse_of_May_20,_2012" title="Solar eclipse of May 20, 2012">solar eclipse of May 20, 2012</a>
        </div> 
       </div> 
      </div> 
      <p>There are four types of solar eclipses:</p> 
      <ul> 
       <li>A <b>total eclipse</b> occurs when the dark silhouette of the Moon completely obscures the intensely bright light of the Sun, allowing the much fainter solar <a href="/wiki/Corona" title="Corona">corona</a> to be visible. During any one eclipse, totality occurs at best only in a narrow track on the surface of Earth.<sup id="cite_ref-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-5">[5]</a></sup> This narrow track is called the path of totality.<sup id="cite_ref-6" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-6">[6]</a></sup></li> 
       <li>An <b>annular eclipse</b> occurs when the Sun and Moon are exactly in line with the Earth, but the apparent size of the Moon is smaller than that of the Sun. Hence the Sun appears as a very bright ring, or <a href="/wiki/Annulus_(mathematics)" title="Annulus (mathematics)">annulus</a>, surrounding the dark disk of the Moon.<sup id="cite_ref-Harrington10_7-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Harrington10-7">[7]</a></sup></li> 
       <li>A <b>hybrid eclipse</b> (also called <b>annular/total eclipse</b>) shifts between a total and annular eclipse. At certain points on the surface of Earth, it appears as a total eclipse, whereas at other points it appears as annular. Hybrid eclipses are comparatively rare.<sup id="cite_ref-Harrington10_7-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Harrington10-7">[7]</a></sup></li> 
       <li>A <b>partial eclipse</b> occurs when the Sun and Moon are not exactly in line with the Earth and the Moon only partially obscures the Sun. This phenomenon can usually be seen from a large part of the Earth outside of the track of an annular or total eclipse. However, some eclipses can only be seen as a partial eclipse, because the <a href="/wiki/Umbra" class="mw-redirect" title="Umbra">umbra</a> passes above the Earth's polar regions and never intersects the Earth's surface.<sup id="cite_ref-Harrington10_7-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Harrington10-7">[7]</a></sup> Partial eclipses are virtually unnoticeable in terms of the sun's brightness, as it takes well over 90% coverage to notice any darkening at all. Even at 99%, it would be no darker than <a href="/wiki/Civil_twilight" class="mw-redirect" title="Civil twilight">civil twilight</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-8" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-8">[8]</a></sup> Of course, partial eclipses (and partial stages of other eclipses) can be observed if one is viewing the sun through a darkening filter (which should always be used for safety).</li> 
      </ul> 
      <p>The Sun's distance from Earth is about 400 times the Moon's distance, and the Sun's <a href="/wiki/Diameter" title="Diameter">diameter</a> is about 400 times the Moon's diameter. Because these ratios are approximately the same, the Sun and the Moon as seen from Earth appear to be approximately the same size: about 0.5 <a href="/wiki/Degree_of_arc" class="mw-redirect" title="Degree of arc">degree of arc</a> in angular measure.<sup id="cite_ref-Harrington10_7-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Harrington10-7">[7]</a></sup></p> 
      <p>A separate category of solar eclipses is that of the Sun being occluded by a body other than the Earth's moon, as can be observed at points in space away from the Earth's surface. Two examples are when the crew of <a href="/wiki/Apollo_12" title="Apollo 12">Apollo 12</a> observed the <a href="/wiki/File:Earth_Eclipses_Sun-ap12-s80-37406.jpg" title="File:Earth Eclipses Sun-ap12-s80-37406.jpg">Earth eclipse the Sun</a> in 1969 and when the <a href="/wiki/Cassini%E2%80%93Huygens" title="Cassini–Huygens">Cassini</a> <a href="/wiki/Space_probe" title="Space probe">probe</a> observed <a href="/wiki/File:Saturn_eclipse.jpg" title="File:Saturn eclipse.jpg">Saturn eclipsing the Sun</a> in 2006.</p> 
      <p>The Moon's orbit around the Earth is slightly <a href="/wiki/Ellipse" title="Ellipse">elliptical</a>, as is the Earth's orbit around the Sun. The apparent sizes of the Sun and Moon therefore vary.<sup id="cite_ref-9" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-9">[9]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Magnitude_of_an_eclipse" class="mw-redirect" title="Magnitude of an eclipse">magnitude of an eclipse</a> is the ratio of the apparent size of the Moon to the apparent size of the Sun during an eclipse. An eclipse that occurs when the Moon is near its closest distance to Earth (<i>i.e.,</i> near its <a href="/wiki/Perigee" class="mw-redirect" title="Perigee">perigee</a>) can be a total eclipse because the Moon will appear to be large enough to completely cover the Sun's bright disk or <a href="/wiki/Photosphere" title="Photosphere">photosphere</a>; a total eclipse has a magnitude greater than or equal to 1.000. Conversely, an eclipse that occurs when the Moon is near its farthest distance from Earth (<i>i.e.,</i> near its <a href="/wiki/Apogee" class="mw-redirect" title="Apogee">apogee</a>) can only be an annular eclipse because the Moon will appear to be slightly smaller than the Sun; the magnitude of an annular eclipse is less than 1. Slightly more solar eclipses are annular than total because, on average, the Moon lies too far from Earth to cover the Sun completely.</p> 
      <p>A hybrid eclipse occurs when the magnitude of an eclipse changes during the event from less to greater than one, so the eclipse appears to be total at locations nearer the midpoint, and annular at other locations nearer the beginning and end, since the sides of the Earth are slightly further away from the Moon. These eclipses are extremely narrow in their path width and extremely short in their duration at any point, at most just a few seconds at any location within just a few kilometres of the centerline of the path. Like a <a href="/wiki/Focus_(optics)" title="Focus (optics)">focal point</a>, the width and duration of totality and annularity are near zero at the points where the changes between the two occur.<sup id="cite_ref-10" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-10">[10]</a></sup></p> 
      <p>Because the Earth's orbit around the Sun is also elliptical, the Earth's distance from the Sun similarly varies throughout the year. This affects the apparent size of the Sun in the same way, but not as much as does the Moon's varying distance from Earth.<sup id="cite_ref-Harrington10_7-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Harrington10-7">[7]</a></sup> When Earth approaches its <a href="/wiki/Aphelion" class="mw-redirect" title="Aphelion">farthest distance from the Sun</a> in early July, a total eclipse is somewhat more likely, whereas conditions favour an annular eclipse when Earth approaches its <a href="/wiki/Perihelion" class="mw-redirect" title="Perihelion">closest distance to the Sun</a> in early January.<sup id="cite_ref-11" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-11">[11]</a></sup></p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Terminology_for_central_eclipse">Terminology for central eclipse</span></h3> 
      <div class="thumb tright"> 
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Solar_eclipse_visualisation.svg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ad/Solar_eclipse_visualisation.svg/220px-Solar_eclipse_visualisation.svg.png" width="220" height="220" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ad/Solar_eclipse_visualisation.svg/330px-Solar_eclipse_visualisation.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ad/Solar_eclipse_visualisation.svg/440px-Solar_eclipse_visualisation.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="512" data-file-height="512"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption"> 
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Solar_eclipse_visualisation.svg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div> Each icon shows the view from the centre of its black spot, representing the moon (not to scale)
        </div> 
       </div> 
      </div> 
      <p><i>Central eclipse</i> is often used as a generic term for a total, annular, or hybrid eclipse.<sup id="cite_ref-SEpath_12-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-SEpath-12">[12]</a></sup> This is, however, not completely correct: the definition of a central eclipse is an eclipse during which the central line of the umbra touches the Earth's surface. It is possible, though extremely rare, that part of the umbra intersects with the Earth (thus creating an annular or total eclipse), but not its central line. This is then called a non-central total or annular eclipse.<sup id="cite_ref-SEpath_12-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-SEpath-12">[12]</a></sup> The last (umbral yet) non-central solar eclipse was <a href="/wiki/Solar_eclipse_of_April_29,_2014" title="Solar eclipse of April 29, 2014">on April 29, 2014</a>. This was an annular eclipse. The next non-central total solar eclipse will be <a href="/wiki/Solar_eclipse_of_April_9,_2043" title="Solar eclipse of April 9, 2043">on April 9, 2043</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-13" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-13">[13]</a></sup></p> 
      <div class="thumb tright"> 
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Exit_Diamond_Ring_Effect.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ae/Exit_Diamond_Ring_Effect.jpg/220px-Exit_Diamond_Ring_Effect.jpg" width="220" height="277" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ae/Exit_Diamond_Ring_Effect.jpg/330px-Exit_Diamond_Ring_Effect.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ae/Exit_Diamond_Ring_Effect.jpg/440px-Exit_Diamond_Ring_Effect.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1623" data-file-height="2047"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption"> 
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Exit_Diamond_Ring_Effect.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div> Diamond Ring effect at third contact, marking the end of totality. Some prominences can also be seen.
        </div> 
       </div> 
      </div> 
      <p>The phases observed during a total eclipse are called:<sup id="cite_ref-14" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-14">[14]</a></sup></p> 
      <ul> 
       <li>First contact—when the Moon's limb (edge) is exactly tangential to the Sun's limb.</li> 
       <li>Second contact—starting with <a href="/wiki/Baily%27s_Beads" class="mw-redirect" title="Baily's Beads">Baily's Beads</a> (caused by light shining through valleys on the Moon's surface) and the <a href="/wiki/Diamond_ring_effect" class="mw-redirect" title="Diamond ring effect">diamond ring effect</a>. Almost the entire disk is covered.</li> 
       <li>Totality—the Moon obscures the entire disk of the Sun and only the solar corona is visible.</li> 
       <li>Third contact—when the first bright light becomes visible and the Moon's shadow is moving away from the observer. Again a diamond ring may be observed.</li> 
       <li>Fourth contact—when the trailing edge of the Moon ceases to overlap with the solar disk and the eclipse ends.</li> 
      </ul> 
      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Predictions">Predictions</span></h2> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Geometry">Geometry</span></h3> 
      <div class="thumb tright"> 
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:302px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Geometry_of_a_Total_Solar_Eclipse.svg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/00/Geometry_of_a_Total_Solar_Eclipse.svg/300px-Geometry_of_a_Total_Solar_Eclipse.svg.png" width="300" height="228" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/00/Geometry_of_a_Total_Solar_Eclipse.svg/450px-Geometry_of_a_Total_Solar_Eclipse.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/00/Geometry_of_a_Total_Solar_Eclipse.svg/600px-Geometry_of_a_Total_Solar_Eclipse.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="895" data-file-height="680"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption"> 
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Geometry_of_a_Total_Solar_Eclipse.svg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div> Geometry of a total solar eclipse (not to scale)
        </div> 
       </div> 
      </div> 
      <p>The diagrams to the right show the alignment of the Sun, Moon, and Earth during a solar eclipse. The dark gray region between the Moon and Earth is the <a href="/wiki/Umbra" class="mw-redirect" title="Umbra">umbra</a>, where the Sun is completely obscured by the Moon. The small area where the umbra touches Earth's surface is where a total eclipse can be seen. The larger light gray area is the <a href="/wiki/Penumbra" class="mw-redirect" title="Penumbra">penumbra</a>, in which a partial eclipse can be seen. An observer in the <a href="/wiki/Umbra#Antumbra" class="mw-redirect" title="Umbra">antumbra</a>, the area of shadow beyond the umbra, will see an annular eclipse.<sup id="cite_ref-15" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-15">[15]</a></sup></p> 
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/Orbit_of_the_Moon" title="Orbit of the Moon">Moon's orbit</a> around the Earth is inclined at an angle of just over 5 degrees to the plane of the Earth's orbit around the Sun (the <a href="/wiki/Ecliptic" title="Ecliptic">ecliptic</a>). Because of this, at the time of a new moon, the Moon will usually pass to the north or south of the Sun. A solar eclipse can occur only when new moon occurs close to one of the points (known as <a href="/wiki/Orbital_node" title="Orbital node">nodes</a>) where the Moon's orbit crosses the ecliptic.<sup id="cite_ref-Harrington_16-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Harrington-16">[16]</a></sup></p> 
      <p>As noted above, the Moon's orbit is also <a href="/wiki/Ellipse" title="Ellipse">elliptical</a>. The Moon's distance from the Earth can vary by about 6% from its average value. Therefore, the Moon's apparent size varies with its distance from the Earth, and it is this effect that leads to the difference between total and annular eclipses. The distance of the Earth from the Sun also varies during the year, but this is a smaller effect. On average, the Moon appears to be slightly smaller than the Sun as seen from the Earth, so the majority (about 60%) of central eclipses are annular. It is only when the Moon is closer to the Earth than average (near its <a href="/wiki/Perigee" class="mw-redirect" title="Perigee">perigee</a>) that a total eclipse occurs.<sup id="cite_ref-17" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-17">[17]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-18" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-18">[18]</a></sup></p> 
      <table class="wikitable" style="text-align: center; margin: 0.1em auto;"> 
       <tbody>
        <tr> 
         <th rowspan="2" width="120">&nbsp;</th> 
         <th colspan="2" width="320">Moon</th> 
         <th colspan="2" width="320">Sun</th> 
        </tr> 
        <tr> 
         <th>At perigee<br> (nearest)</th> 
         <th>At apogee<br> (farthest)</th> 
         <th>At perihelion<br> (nearest)</th> 
         <th>At aphelion<br> (farthest)</th> 
        </tr> 
        <tr> 
         <th>Mean radius</th> 
         <td colspan="2">1,737.10&nbsp;km<br> (1,079.38&nbsp;mi)</td> 
         <td colspan="2">696,000&nbsp;km<br> (432,000&nbsp;mi)</td> 
        </tr> 
        <tr> 
         <th>Distance</th> 
         <td>363,104&nbsp;km<br> (225,622&nbsp;mi)</td> 
         <td>405,696&nbsp;km<br> (252,088&nbsp;mi)</td> 
         <td>147,098,070&nbsp;km<br> (91,402,500&nbsp;mi)</td> 
         <td>152,097,700&nbsp;km<br> (94,509,100&nbsp;mi)</td> 
        </tr> 
        <tr> 
         <th style="line-height: 120%;">Angular<br> diameter<sup id="cite_ref-19" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-19">[19]</a></sup></th> 
         <td>33' 30"<br> (0.5583°)</td> 
         <td>29' 26"<br> (0.4905°)</td> 
         <td>32' 42"<br> (0.5450°)</td> 
         <td>31' 36"<br> (0.5267°)</td> 
        </tr> 
        <tr> 
         <th style="line-height: 120%;">Apparent size<br> to scale</th> 
         <td><a href="/wiki/File:-Phase_of_the_moon_NO.16.jpg" class="image"><img alt="-Phase of the moon NO.16.jpg" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/72/-Phase_of_the_moon_NO.16.jpg/56px--Phase_of_the_moon_NO.16.jpg" width="56" height="47" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/72/-Phase_of_the_moon_NO.16.jpg/84px--Phase_of_the_moon_NO.16.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/72/-Phase_of_the_moon_NO.16.jpg/112px--Phase_of_the_moon_NO.16.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1781" data-file-height="1510"></a></td> 
         <td><a href="/wiki/File:-Phase_of_the_moon_NO.16.jpg" class="image"><img alt="-Phase of the moon NO.16.jpg" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/72/-Phase_of_the_moon_NO.16.jpg/49px--Phase_of_the_moon_NO.16.jpg" width="49" height="42" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/72/-Phase_of_the_moon_NO.16.jpg/74px--Phase_of_the_moon_NO.16.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/72/-Phase_of_the_moon_NO.16.jpg/98px--Phase_of_the_moon_NO.16.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1781" data-file-height="1510"></a></td> 
         <td><a href="/wiki/File:The_Sun_by_the_Atmospheric_Imaging_Assembly_of_NASA%27s_Solar_Dynamics_Observatory_-_20100819.jpg" class="image"><img alt="The Sun by the Atmospheric Imaging Assembly of NASA's Solar Dynamics Observatory - 20100819.jpg" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b4/The_Sun_by_the_Atmospheric_Imaging_Assembly_of_NASA%27s_Solar_Dynamics_Observatory_-_20100819.jpg/54px-The_Sun_by_the_Atmospheric_Imaging_Assembly_of_NASA%27s_Solar_Dynamics_Observatory_-_20100819.jpg" width="54" height="52" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b4/The_Sun_by_the_Atmospheric_Imaging_Assembly_of_NASA%27s_Solar_Dynamics_Observatory_-_20100819.jpg/81px-The_Sun_by_the_Atmospheric_Imaging_Assembly_of_NASA%27s_Solar_Dynamics_Observatory_-_20100819.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b4/The_Sun_by_the_Atmospheric_Imaging_Assembly_of_NASA%27s_Solar_Dynamics_Observatory_-_20100819.jpg/108px-The_Sun_by_the_Atmospheric_Imaging_Assembly_of_NASA%27s_Solar_Dynamics_Observatory_-_20100819.jpg 2x" data-file-width="4044" data-file-height="3860"></a></td> 
         <td><a href="/wiki/File:The_Sun_by_the_Atmospheric_Imaging_Assembly_of_NASA%27s_Solar_Dynamics_Observatory_-_20100819.jpg" class="image"><img alt="The Sun by the Atmospheric Imaging Assembly of NASA's Solar Dynamics Observatory - 20100819.jpg" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b4/The_Sun_by_the_Atmospheric_Imaging_Assembly_of_NASA%27s_Solar_Dynamics_Observatory_-_20100819.jpg/53px-The_Sun_by_the_Atmospheric_Imaging_Assembly_of_NASA%27s_Solar_Dynamics_Observatory_-_20100819.jpg" width="53" height="51" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b4/The_Sun_by_the_Atmospheric_Imaging_Assembly_of_NASA%27s_Solar_Dynamics_Observatory_-_20100819.jpg/80px-The_Sun_by_the_Atmospheric_Imaging_Assembly_of_NASA%27s_Solar_Dynamics_Observatory_-_20100819.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b4/The_Sun_by_the_Atmospheric_Imaging_Assembly_of_NASA%27s_Solar_Dynamics_Observatory_-_20100819.jpg/106px-The_Sun_by_the_Atmospheric_Imaging_Assembly_of_NASA%27s_Solar_Dynamics_Observatory_-_20100819.jpg 2x" data-file-width="4044" data-file-height="3860"></a></td> 
        </tr> 
        <tr> 
         <th style="line-height: 120%;">Order by<br> decreasing<br> apparent size</th> 
         <td>1st</td> 
         <td>4th</td> 
         <td>2nd</td> 
         <td>3rd</td> 
        </tr> 
       </tbody>
      </table> 
      <p>The Moon orbits the Earth in approximately 27.3 days, relative to a <a href="/wiki/Inertial_frame_of_reference" title="Inertial frame of reference">fixed frame of reference</a>. This is known as the <a href="/wiki/Sidereal_month" class="mw-redirect" title="Sidereal month">sidereal month</a>. However, during one sidereal month, Earth has revolved part way around the Sun, making the average time between one new moon and the next longer than the sidereal month: it is approximately 29.5 days. This is known as the <a href="/wiki/Synodic_month" class="mw-redirect" title="Synodic month">synodic month</a> and corresponds to what is commonly called the <a href="/wiki/Lunar_month" title="Lunar month">lunar month</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Harrington_16-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Harrington-16">[16]</a></sup></p> 
      <p>The Moon crosses from south to north of the ecliptic at its <a href="/wiki/Ascending_node" class="mw-redirect" title="Ascending node">ascending node</a>, and vice versa at its descending node.<sup id="cite_ref-Harrington_16-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Harrington-16">[16]</a></sup> However, the nodes of the Moon's orbit are gradually moving in a <a href="/wiki/Retrograde_motion" class="mw-redirect" title="Retrograde motion">retrograde motion</a>, due to the action of the Sun's gravity on the Moon's motion, and they make a complete circuit every 18.6 years. This regression means that the time between each passage of the Moon through the ascending node is slightly shorter than the sidereal month. This period is called the nodical or <a href="/wiki/Draconic_month" class="mw-redirect" title="Draconic month">draconic month</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-20" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-20">[20]</a></sup></p> 
      <p>Finally, the Moon's perigee is moving forwards or precessing in its orbit and makes a complete circuit in 8.85 years. The time between one perigee and the next is slightly longer than the sidereal month and known as the <a href="/wiki/Anomalistic_month" class="mw-redirect" title="Anomalistic month">anomalistic month</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-21" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-21">[21]</a></sup></p> 
      <p>The Moon's orbit intersects with the ecliptic at the two nodes that are 180 degrees apart. Therefore, the new moon occurs close to the nodes at two periods of the year approximately six months (173.3 days) apart, known as <a href="/wiki/Eclipse_season" title="Eclipse season">eclipse seasons</a>, and there will always be at least one solar eclipse during these periods. Sometimes the new moon occurs close enough to a node during two consecutive months to eclipse the Sun on both occasions in two partial eclipses. This means that, in any given year, there will always be at least two solar eclipses, and there can be as many as five.<sup id="cite_ref-22" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-22">[22]</a></sup></p> 
      <p>Eclipses can occur only when the Sun is within about 15 to 18 degrees of a node, (10 to 12 degrees for central eclipses). This is referred to as an eclipse limit. In the time it takes for the Moon to return to a node (draconic month), the apparent position of the Sun has moved about 29 degrees, relative to the nodes.<sup id="cite_ref-totality_1-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-totality-1">[1]</a></sup> Since the eclipse limit creates a window of opportunity of up to 36 degrees (24 degrees for central eclipses), it is possible for partial eclipses (or rarely a partial and a central eclipse) to occur in consecutive months.<sup id="cite_ref-period_23-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-period-23">[23]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-24" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-24">[24]</a></sup></p> 
      <div class="thumb tright"> 
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Graph_solar_eclipse_coverage.svg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/97/Graph_solar_eclipse_coverage.svg/220px-Graph_solar_eclipse_coverage.svg.png" width="220" height="220" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/97/Graph_solar_eclipse_coverage.svg/330px-Graph_solar_eclipse_coverage.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/97/Graph_solar_eclipse_coverage.svg/440px-Graph_solar_eclipse_coverage.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="512" data-file-height="512"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption"> 
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Graph_solar_eclipse_coverage.svg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div> Fraction of the Sun's disc covered, 
         <i>f</i>, when the same-sized discs are offset a fraction 
         <i>t</i> of their diameter.
         <sup id="cite_ref-25" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-25">[25]</a></sup>
        </div> 
       </div> 
      </div> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Path">Path</span></h3> 
      <p>During a central eclipse, the Moon's umbra (or antumbra, in the case of an annular eclipse) moves rapidly from west to east across the Earth. The Earth is also rotating from west to east, at about 28&nbsp;km/min at the Equator, but as the Moon is moving in the same direction as the Earth's spin at about 61&nbsp;km/min, the umbra almost always appears to move in a roughly west-east direction across a map of the Earth at the speed of the Moon's orbital velocity minus the Earth's rotational velocity.<sup id="cite_ref-26" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-26">[26]</a></sup></p> 
      <p>The width of the track of a central eclipse varies according to the relative apparent diameters of the Sun and Moon. In the most favourable circumstances, when a total eclipse occurs very close to perigee, the track can be up to 267&nbsp;km (166&nbsp;mi) wide and the duration of totality may be over 7 minutes.<sup id="cite_ref-27" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-27">[27]</a></sup> Outside of the central track, a partial eclipse is seen over a much larger area of the Earth. Typically, the umbra is 100–160&nbsp;km wide, while the penumbral diameter is in excess of 6400&nbsp;km.<sup id="cite_ref-28" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-28">[28]</a></sup></p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Duration">Duration</span></h3> 
      <p>The following factors determine the duration of a total solar eclipse (in order of decreasing importance):<sup id="cite_ref-longest_29-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-longest-29">[29]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-30" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-30">[30]</a></sup></p> 
      <ol> 
       <li>The moon being almost exactly at perigee (making its angular diameter as large as possible).</li> 
       <li>The earth being very near <a href="/wiki/Apsis" title="Apsis">aphelion</a> (furthest away from the sun in its elliptical orbit, making its angular diameter nearly as small as possible).</li> 
       <li>The midpoint of the eclipse being very close to the earth's equator, where the rotational velocity is greatest.</li> 
       <li>The vector of the eclipse path at the midpoint of the eclipse aligning with the vector of the earth's rotation (i.e. not diagonal but due east).</li> 
       <li>The midpoint of the eclipse being near the <a href="/wiki/Subsolar_point" title="Subsolar point">subsolar point</a> (the part of the earth closest to the sun).</li> 
      </ol> 
      <p>The longest eclipse that has been calculated thus far is the eclipse of <a href="/wiki/Solar_eclipse_of_July_16,_2186" title="Solar eclipse of July 16, 2186">July 16, 2186</a> (with a maximum duration of 7 minutes 4 seconds over northern Guyana).</p> 
      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Occurrence_and_cycles">Occurrence and cycles</span></h2> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: 
       <a href="/wiki/Eclipse_cycle" title="Eclipse cycle">Eclipse cycle</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright"> 
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:302px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Total_Solar_Eclipse_Paths-_1001-2000.gif" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/48/Total_Solar_Eclipse_Paths-_1001-2000.gif/300px-Total_Solar_Eclipse_Paths-_1001-2000.gif" width="300" height="226" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/48/Total_Solar_Eclipse_Paths-_1001-2000.gif/450px-Total_Solar_Eclipse_Paths-_1001-2000.gif 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/48/Total_Solar_Eclipse_Paths-_1001-2000.gif/600px-Total_Solar_Eclipse_Paths-_1001-2000.gif 2x" data-file-width="1930" data-file-height="1453"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption"> 
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Total_Solar_Eclipse_Paths-_1001-2000.gif" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div> Total solar eclipse paths: 1001–2000, showing that total solar eclipses occur almost everywhere on Earth. This image was merged from 50 separate images from 
         <a href="/wiki/NASA" title="NASA">NASA</a>.
         <sup id="cite_ref-31" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-31">[31]</a></sup>
        </div> 
       </div> 
      </div> 
      <p>Total solar eclipses are rare events. Although they occur somewhere on Earth every 18 months on average,<sup id="cite_ref-32" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-32">[32]</a></sup> it is estimated that they recur at any given place only once every 360 to 410 years, on average.<sup id="cite_ref-33" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-33">[33]</a></sup> The total eclipse lasts for only a maximum of a few minutes at any location, because the Moon's umbra moves eastward at over 1700&nbsp;km/h.<sup id="cite_ref-34" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-34">[34]</a></sup> Totality currently can never last more than 7&nbsp;min 32&nbsp;s. This value changes over the millennia and is currently decreasing. By the 8th millennium, the longest theoretically possible total eclipse will be less than 7&nbsp;min 2&nbsp;s.<sup id="cite_ref-longest_29-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-longest-29">[29]</a></sup> The last time an eclipse longer than 7 minutes occurred was <a href="/wiki/Solar_eclipse_of_June_30,_1973" title="Solar eclipse of June 30, 1973">June 30, 1973</a> (7 min 3 sec). Observers aboard a <a href="/wiki/Concorde" title="Concorde">Concorde</a> supersonic aircraft were able to stretch totality for this eclipse to about 74 minutes by flying along the path of the Moon's umbra.<sup id="cite_ref-35" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-35">[35]</a></sup> The next total eclipse exceeding seven minutes in duration will not occur until <a href="/wiki/Solar_eclipse_of_June_25,_2150" title="Solar eclipse of June 25, 2150">June 25, 2150</a>. The longest total solar eclipse during the 11,000 year period from 3000 BC to at least 8000 AD will occur on <a href="/wiki/Solar_eclipse_of_July_16,_2186" title="Solar eclipse of July 16, 2186">July 16, 2186</a>, when totality will last 7&nbsp;min 29&nbsp;s.<sup id="cite_ref-longest_29-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-longest-29">[29]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-36" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-36">[36]</a></sup> For comparison, the longest total eclipse of the 20th century at 7&nbsp;min 8&nbsp;s occurred on <a href="/wiki/Solar_eclipse_of_June_20,_1955" title="Solar eclipse of June 20, 1955">June 20, 1955</a>, and there are no total solar eclipses over 7&nbsp;min in duration in the 21st century.<sup id="cite_ref-37" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-37">[37]</a></sup></p> 
      <p>If the date and time of any solar eclipse are known, it is possible to predict other eclipses using <a href="/wiki/Eclipse_cycle" title="Eclipse cycle">eclipse cycles</a>. The <a href="/wiki/Saros_cycle" class="mw-redirect" title="Saros cycle">saros</a> is probably the best known and one of the most accurate. A saros lasts 6,585.3 days (a little over 18 years), which means that, after this period, a practically identical eclipse will occur. The most notable difference will be a westward shift of about 120° in longitude (due to the 0.3 days) and a little in latitude (north-south for odd-numbered cycles, the reverse for even-numbered ones). A saros series always starts with a partial eclipse near one of Earth's polar regions, then shifts over the globe through a series of annular or total eclipses, and ends with a partial eclipse at the opposite polar region. A saros series lasts 1226 to 1550 years and 69 to 87 eclipses, with about 40 to 60 of them being central.<sup id="cite_ref-38" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-38">[38]</a></sup></p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Frequency_per_year">Frequency per year</span></h3> 
      <p>Between two and five solar eclipses occur every year, with at least one per <a href="/wiki/Eclipse_season" title="Eclipse season">eclipse season</a>. Since the <a href="/wiki/Gregorian_calendar" title="Gregorian calendar">Gregorian calendar</a> was instituted in 1582, years that have had five solar eclipses were 1693, 1758, 1805, 1823, 1870, and 1935. The next occurrence will be 2206.<sup id="cite_ref-39" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-39">[39]</a></sup> On average, there are about 240 solar eclipses each century.<sup id="cite_ref-40" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-40">[40]</a></sup></p> 
      <table class="wikitable"> 
       <caption>
        The 5 solar eclipses of 1935
       </caption> 
       <tbody>
        <tr> 
         <th><a href="/wiki/Solar_eclipse_of_January_5,_1935" title="Solar eclipse of January 5, 1935">January 5</a></th> 
         <th><a href="/wiki/Solar_eclipse_of_February_3,_1935" title="Solar eclipse of February 3, 1935">February 3</a></th> 
         <th><a href="/wiki/Solar_eclipse_of_June_30,_1935" title="Solar eclipse of June 30, 1935">June 30</a></th> 
         <th><a href="/wiki/Solar_eclipse_of_July_30,_1935" title="Solar eclipse of July 30, 1935">July 30</a></th> 
         <th><a href="/wiki/Solar_eclipse_of_December_25,_1935" title="Solar eclipse of December 25, 1935">December 25</a></th> 
        </tr> 
        <tr> 
         <th>Partial<br> (south)</th> 
         <th>Partial<br> (north)</th> 
         <th>Partial<br> (north)</th> 
         <th>Partial<br> (south)</th> 
         <th>Annular<br> (south)</th> 
        </tr> 
        <tr align="center"> 
         <td><a href="/wiki/File:SE1935Jan05P.png" class="image"><img alt="SE1935Jan05P.png" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1b/SE1935Jan05P.png/150px-SE1935Jan05P.png" width="150" height="150" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1b/SE1935Jan05P.png/225px-SE1935Jan05P.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1b/SE1935Jan05P.png/300px-SE1935Jan05P.png 2x" data-file-width="728" data-file-height="729"></a><br> Saros 111</td> 
         <td><a href="/wiki/File:SE1935Feb03P.png" class="image"><img alt="SE1935Feb03P.png" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7d/SE1935Feb03P.png/150px-SE1935Feb03P.png" width="150" height="150" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7d/SE1935Feb03P.png/225px-SE1935Feb03P.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7d/SE1935Feb03P.png/300px-SE1935Feb03P.png 2x" data-file-width="728" data-file-height="729"></a><br> Saros 149</td> 
         <td><a href="/wiki/File:SE1935Jun30P.png" class="image"><img alt="SE1935Jun30P.png" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/92/SE1935Jun30P.png/150px-SE1935Jun30P.png" width="150" height="150" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/92/SE1935Jun30P.png/225px-SE1935Jun30P.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/92/SE1935Jun30P.png/300px-SE1935Jun30P.png 2x" data-file-width="728" data-file-height="729"></a><br> Saros 116</td> 
         <td><a href="/wiki/File:SE1935Jul30P.png" class="image"><img alt="SE1935Jul30P.png" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/30/SE1935Jul30P.png/150px-SE1935Jul30P.png" width="150" height="150" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/30/SE1935Jul30P.png/225px-SE1935Jul30P.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/30/SE1935Jul30P.png/300px-SE1935Jul30P.png 2x" data-file-width="728" data-file-height="729"></a><br> Saros 154</td> 
         <td><a href="/wiki/File:SE1935Dec25A.png" class="image"><img alt="SE1935Dec25A.png" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ea/SE1935Dec25A.png/150px-SE1935Dec25A.png" width="150" height="150" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ea/SE1935Dec25A.png/225px-SE1935Dec25A.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ea/SE1935Dec25A.png/300px-SE1935Dec25A.png 2x" data-file-width="728" data-file-height="729"></a><br> Saros 121</td> 
        </tr> 
       </tbody>
      </table> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Final_totality">Final totality</span></h3> 
      <p>Total solar eclipses are seen on Earth because of a fortuitous combination of circumstances. Even on Earth, the diversity of eclipses familiar to people today is a temporary (on a geological time scale) phenomenon. Hundreds of millions of years in the past, the Moon was closer to the Earth and therefore apparently larger, so every solar eclipse was total or partial, and there were no annular eclipses. Due to <a href="/wiki/Tidal_acceleration" title="Tidal acceleration">tidal acceleration</a>, the orbit of the Moon around the Earth becomes approximately 3.8&nbsp;cm more distant each year. Millions of years in the future, the Moon will be too far away to fully occlude the Sun, and no total eclipses will occur. In the same timeframe, the Sun may become brighter, making it appear larger in size.<sup id="cite_ref-fourmilab_41-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-fourmilab-41">[41]</a></sup> Estimates of the when the moon will be unable to occlude the entire sun when viewed from the Earth range between 1.4 billion<sup id="cite_ref-fourmilab_41-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-fourmilab-41">[41]</a></sup> and 650 million years in the future.<sup id="cite_ref-42" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-42">[42]</a></sup></p> 
      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Historical_eclipses">Historical eclipses</span></h2> 
      <div class="thumb tright"> 
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Antoine_Caron_Astronomers_Studying_an_Eclipse.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/85/Antoine_Caron_Astronomers_Studying_an_Eclipse.jpg/170px-Antoine_Caron_Astronomers_Studying_an_Eclipse.jpg" width="170" height="220" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/85/Antoine_Caron_Astronomers_Studying_an_Eclipse.jpg/255px-Antoine_Caron_Astronomers_Studying_an_Eclipse.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/85/Antoine_Caron_Astronomers_Studying_an_Eclipse.jpg/340px-Antoine_Caron_Astronomers_Studying_an_Eclipse.jpg 2x" data-file-width="398" data-file-height="514"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption"> 
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Antoine_Caron_Astronomers_Studying_an_Eclipse.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div> 
         <i>Astronomers Studying an Eclipse</i> painted by 
         <a href="/wiki/Antoine_Caron" title="Antoine Caron">Antoine Caron</a> in 1571
        </div> 
       </div> 
      </div> 
      <p>Historical eclipses are a very valuable resource for historians, in that they allow a few historical events to be dated precisely, from which other dates and ancient calendars may be deduced. A <a href="/wiki/Assyrian_eclipse" title="Assyrian eclipse">solar eclipse of June 15, 763 BC</a> mentioned in an <a href="/wiki/Assyrian_people" title="Assyrian people">Assyrian</a> text is important for the <a href="/wiki/Chronology_of_the_ancient_Near_East" title="Chronology of the ancient Near East">chronology of the ancient Near East</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-43" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-43">[43]</a></sup> There have been other claims to date earlier eclipses. The <a href="/wiki/Book_of_Joshua" title="Book of Joshua">Book of Joshua</a> 10:13 could refer to an annular eclipse on 30 October 1207 BC.<sup id="cite_ref-44" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-44">[44]</a></sup> The King <a href="/wiki/Zhong_Kang" title="Zhong Kang">Zhong Kang</a> supposedly beheaded two astronomers, Hsi and Ho, who failed to predict an eclipse 4,000 years ago.<sup id="cite_ref-45" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-45">[45]</a></sup> Perhaps the earliest still-unproven claim is that of archaeologist Bruce Masse, who putatively links an eclipse that occurred on May 10, 2807 BC with a possible <a href="/wiki/Impact_event" title="Impact event">meteor impact</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Indian_Ocean" title="Indian Ocean">Indian Ocean</a> on the basis of several ancient <a href="/wiki/Flood_(mythology)" class="mw-redirect" title="Flood (mythology)">flood myths</a> that mention a total solar eclipse.<sup id="cite_ref-46" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-46">[46]</a></sup></p> 
      <p>Eclipses have been interpreted as <a href="/wiki/Omen" title="Omen">omens</a>, or portents.<sup id="cite_ref-47" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-47">[47]</a></sup> The ancient Greek historian <a href="/wiki/Herodotus" title="Herodotus">Herodotus</a> wrote that <a href="/wiki/Thales" class="mw-redirect" title="Thales">Thales of Miletus</a> predicted <a href="/wiki/Eclipse_of_Thales" title="Eclipse of Thales">an eclipse that occurred during a battle</a> between the <a href="/wiki/Medes" title="Medes">Medes</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Lydia" title="Lydia">Lydians</a>. Both sides put down their weapons and declared peace as a result of the eclipse.<sup id="cite_ref-48" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-48">[48]</a></sup> The exact eclipse involved remains uncertain, although the issue has been studied by hundreds of ancient and modern authorities. One likely candidate took place on May 28, 585 BC, probably near the <a href="/wiki/Halys_River" class="mw-redirect" title="Halys River">Halys</a> river in <a href="/wiki/Asia_Minor" class="mw-redirect" title="Asia Minor">Asia Minor</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-49" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-49">[49]</a></sup> An eclipse recorded by Herodotus before <a href="/wiki/Xerxes_I" title="Xerxes I">Xerxes</a> departed for his expedition against <a href="/wiki/Ancient_Greece" title="Ancient Greece">Greece</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-50" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-50">[50]</a></sup> which is traditionally dated to 480 BC, was matched by <a href="/wiki/John_Russell_Hind" title="John Russell Hind">John Russell Hind</a> to an annular eclipse of the Sun at <a href="/wiki/Sardis" title="Sardis">Sardis</a> on February 17, 478 BC.<sup id="cite_ref-51" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-51">[51]</a></sup> Alternatively, a partial eclipse was visible from Persia on October 2, 480 BC.<sup id="cite_ref-Espenak_52-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Espenak-52">[52]</a></sup> Herodotus also reports a solar eclipse at <a href="/wiki/Sparta" title="Sparta">Sparta</a> during the <a href="/wiki/Second_Persian_invasion_of_Greece" title="Second Persian invasion of Greece">Second Persian invasion of Greece</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-53" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-53">[53]</a></sup> The date of the eclipse (August 1, 477 BC) does not match exactly the conventional dates for the invasion accepted by historians.<sup id="cite_ref-54" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-54">[54]</a></sup></p> 
      <p>Chinese records of eclipses begin at around 720 BC.<sup id="cite_ref-SciAm_55-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-SciAm-55">[55]</a></sup> The 4th century BC astronomer <a href="/wiki/Shi_Shen" title="Shi Shen">Shi Shen</a> described the prediction of eclipses by using the relative positions of the Moon and Sun.<sup id="cite_ref-Needham411_56-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Needham411-56">[56]</a></sup> The "radiating influence" theory (i.e., the Moon's light was reflection from the Sun) was existent in Chinese thought from about the sixth century BC (in the <i>Zhi Ran</i> of Zhi Ni Zi),<sup id="cite_ref-Needham227_57-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Needham227-57">[57]</a></sup> though it was opposed by the 1st century AD philosopher <a href="/wiki/Wang_Chong" title="Wang Chong">Wang Chong</a>, who made clear in his writing that this theory was nothing new.<sup id="cite_ref-Needham411_56-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Needham411-56">[56]</a></sup> Ancient Greeks, such as <a href="/wiki/Parmenides" title="Parmenides">Parmenides</a> and <a href="/wiki/Aristotle" title="Aristotle">Aristotle</a>, also supported the theory of the Moon shining because of reflected light.<sup id="cite_ref-Needham227_57-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Needham227-57">[57]</a></sup></p> 
      <p>Attempts have been made to establish the exact date of <a href="/wiki/Good_Friday" title="Good Friday">Good Friday</a> by assuming that the <a href="/wiki/Crucifixion_darkness_and_eclipse" class="mw-redirect" title="Crucifixion darkness and eclipse">darkness described at Jesus's crucifixion</a> was a solar eclipse. This research has not yielded conclusive results,<sup id="cite_ref-58" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-58">[58]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-59" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-59">[59]</a></sup> and Good Friday is recorded as being at <a href="/wiki/Passover" title="Passover">Passover</a>, which is held at the time of a full moon. Further, the darkness lasted from the sixth hour to the ninth, or three hours, which is much, much longer than the eight-minute upper limit for any solar eclipse's totality. In the Western hemisphere, there are few reliable records of eclipses before 800 AD, until the advent of Arab and monastic observations in the early medieval period.<sup id="cite_ref-SciAm_55-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-SciAm-55">[55]</a></sup> The first recorded observation of the corona was made in <a href="/wiki/Constantinople" title="Constantinople">Constantinople</a> in 968 AD.<sup id="cite_ref-Espenak_52-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Espenak-52">[52]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-SciAm_55-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-SciAm-55">[55]</a></sup></p> 
      <p>The first known telescopic observation of a total solar eclipse was made in France in 1706.<sup id="cite_ref-SciAm_55-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-SciAm-55">[55]</a></sup> Nine years later, English astronomer <a href="/wiki/Edmund_Halley" class="mw-redirect" title="Edmund Halley">Edmund Halley</a> accurately predicted and observed the <a href="/wiki/Solar_eclipse_of_May_3,_1715" title="Solar eclipse of May 3, 1715">solar eclipse of May 3, 1715</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Espenak_52-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Espenak-52">[52]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-SciAm_55-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-SciAm-55">[55]</a></sup> By the mid-19th century, scientific understanding of the Sun was improving through observations of the Sun's corona during solar eclipses. The corona was identified as part of the Sun's atmosphere in <a href="/wiki/Solar_eclipse_of_July_8,_1842" title="Solar eclipse of July 8, 1842">1842</a>, and the first photograph (or <a href="/wiki/Daguerreotype" title="Daguerreotype">daguerreotype</a>) of a total eclipse was taken of the <a href="/wiki/Solar_eclipse_of_July_28,_1851" title="Solar eclipse of July 28, 1851">solar eclipse of July 28, 1851</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Espenak_52-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Espenak-52">[52]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Spectroscope" class="mw-redirect" title="Spectroscope">Spectroscope</a> observations were made of the <a href="/wiki/Solar_eclipse_of_August_18,_1868" title="Solar eclipse of August 18, 1868">solar eclipse of August 18, 1868</a>, which helped to determine the chemical composition of the Sun.<sup id="cite_ref-Espenak_52-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Espenak-52">[52]</a></sup></p> 
      <div class="thumb tright"> 
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Acta_Eruditorum_-_I_astronomia,_1762_%E2%80%93_BEIC_13450778.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/aa/Acta_Eruditorum_-_I_astronomia%2C_1762_%E2%80%93_BEIC_13450778.jpg/220px-Acta_Eruditorum_-_I_astronomia%2C_1762_%E2%80%93_BEIC_13450778.jpg" width="220" height="168" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/aa/Acta_Eruditorum_-_I_astronomia%2C_1762_%E2%80%93_BEIC_13450778.jpg/330px-Acta_Eruditorum_-_I_astronomia%2C_1762_%E2%80%93_BEIC_13450778.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/aa/Acta_Eruditorum_-_I_astronomia%2C_1762_%E2%80%93_BEIC_13450778.jpg/440px-Acta_Eruditorum_-_I_astronomia%2C_1762_%E2%80%93_BEIC_13450778.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2039" data-file-height="1557"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption"> 
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Acta_Eruditorum_-_I_astronomia,_1762_%E2%80%93_BEIC_13450778.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div> Illustration from 
         <i>De magna eclipsi solari, quae continget anno 1764</i> published in 
         <i>Acta Eruditorum</i>, 1762
        </div> 
       </div> 
      </div> 
      <p><a href="/wiki/John_Fiske_(philosopher)" title="John Fiske (philosopher)">John Fiske</a> summed up myths about the solar eclipse like this in his 1872 book <i>Myth and Myth-Makers</i>,</p> 
      <blockquote class="templatequote"> 
       <p>the myth of Hercules and Cacus, the fundamental idea is the victory of the solar god over the robber who steals the light. Now whether the robber carries off the light in the evening when Indra has gone to sleep, or boldly rears his black form against the sky during the daytime, causing darkness to spread over the earth, would make little difference to the framers of the myth. To a chicken a solar eclipse is the same thing as nightfall, and he goes to roost accordingly. Why, then, should the primitive thinker have made a distinction between the darkening of the sky caused by black clouds and that caused by the rotation of the earth? He had no more conception of the scientific explanation of these phenomena than the chicken has of the scientific explanation of an eclipse. For him it was enough to know that the solar radiance was stolen, in the one case as in the other, and to suspect that the same demon was to blame for both robberies.<sup id="cite_ref-60" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-60">[60]</a></sup></p> 
      </blockquote> 
      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Viewing">Viewing</span></h2> 
      <p>Looking directly at the <a href="/wiki/Photosphere" title="Photosphere">photosphere</a> of the Sun (the bright disk of the Sun itself), even for just a few seconds, can cause permanent <a href="/wiki/Solar_retinopathy" class="mw-redirect" title="Solar retinopathy">damage</a> to the <a href="/wiki/Retina" title="Retina">retina</a> of the eye, because of the intense visible and invisible radiation that the photosphere emits. This damage can result in impairment of vision, up to and including <a href="/wiki/Blindness" class="mw-redirect" title="Blindness">blindness</a>. The retina has no sensitivity to pain, and the effects of retinal damage may not appear for hours, so there is no warning that injury is occurring.<sup id="cite_ref-61" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-61">[61]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-62" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-62">[62]</a></sup></p> 
      <p>Under normal conditions, the Sun is so bright that it is difficult to stare at it directly. However, during an eclipse, with so much of the Sun covered, it is easier and more tempting to stare at it. Looking at the Sun during an eclipse is as dangerous as looking at it outside an eclipse, except during the brief period of totality, when the Sun's disk is completely covered (totality occurs only during a total eclipse and only very briefly; it does not occur during a partial or annular eclipse). Viewing the Sun's disk through any kind of optical aid (binoculars, a telescope, or even an optical camera viewfinder) is extremely hazardous and can cause irreversible eye damage within a fraction of a second.<sup id="cite_ref-63" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-63">[63]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-64" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-64">[64]</a></sup></p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Partial_and_annular_eclipses">Partial and annular eclipses</span></h3> 
      <div class="thumb tright"> 
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Eclipsbrilletje.JPG" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/23/Eclipsbrilletje.JPG/220px-Eclipsbrilletje.JPG" width="220" height="165" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/23/Eclipsbrilletje.JPG/330px-Eclipsbrilletje.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/23/Eclipsbrilletje.JPG/440px-Eclipsbrilletje.JPG 2x" data-file-width="2560" data-file-height="1920"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption"> 
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Eclipsbrilletje.JPG" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div> 
         <a href="/wiki/Solar_viewer" title="Solar viewer">Eclipse glasses</a>
        </div> 
       </div> 
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright"> 
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Solar_eclipse_in_Turkey_March_2006.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/10/Solar_eclipse_in_Turkey_March_2006.jpg/220px-Solar_eclipse_in_Turkey_March_2006.jpg" width="220" height="136" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/10/Solar_eclipse_in_Turkey_March_2006.jpg/330px-Solar_eclipse_in_Turkey_March_2006.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/10/Solar_eclipse_in_Turkey_March_2006.jpg/440px-Solar_eclipse_in_Turkey_March_2006.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2190" data-file-height="1356"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption"> 
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Solar_eclipse_in_Turkey_March_2006.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div> Pinhole projection method of observing partial solar eclipse. Insert (upper left): partially eclipsed Sun photographed with a white solar filter. Main image: projections of the partially eclipsed Sun (bottom right)
        </div> 
       </div> 
      </div> 
      <p>Viewing the Sun during partial and annular eclipses (and during total eclipses outside the brief period of totality) requires special eye protection, or indirect viewing methods if eye damage is to be avoided. The Sun's disk can be viewed using appropriate filtration to block the harmful part of the Sun's radiation. Sunglasses do not make viewing the Sun safe. Only properly designed and certified solar filters should be used for direct viewing of the Sun's disk.<sup id="cite_ref-65" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-65">[65]</a></sup> Especially, self-made filters using common objects such as a <a href="/wiki/Floppy_disk" title="Floppy disk">floppy disk</a> removed from its case, a <a href="/wiki/Compact_Disc" class="mw-redirect" title="Compact Disc">Compact Disc</a>, a black colour slide film, smoked glass, etc. must be avoided.<sup id="cite_ref-66" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-66">[66]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-perkins_67-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-perkins-67">[67]</a></sup></p> 
      <p>The safest way to view the Sun's disk is by indirect projection.<sup id="cite_ref-Harrington25_68-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Harrington25-68">[68]</a></sup> This can be done by projecting an image of the disk onto a white piece of paper or card using a pair of binoculars (with one of the lenses covered), a telescope, or another piece of cardboard with a small hole in it (about 1&nbsp;mm diameter), often called a <a href="/wiki/Pinhole_camera" title="Pinhole camera">pinhole camera</a>. The projected image of the Sun can then be safely viewed; this technique can be used to observe <a href="/wiki/Sunspot" title="Sunspot">sunspots</a>, as well as eclipses. Care must be taken, however, to ensure that no one looks through the projector (telescope, pinhole, etc.) directly.<sup id="cite_ref-69" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-69">[69]</a></sup> Viewing the Sun's disk on a video display screen (provided by a <a href="/wiki/Video_camera" title="Video camera">video camera</a> or <a href="/wiki/Digital_camera" title="Digital camera">digital camera</a>) is safe, although the camera itself may be damaged by direct exposure to the Sun. The optical viewfinders provided with some video and digital cameras are not safe. Securely mounting #14 welder's glass in front of the lens and viewfinder protects the equipment and makes viewing possible.<sup id="cite_ref-perkins_67-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-perkins-67">[67]</a></sup> Professional workmanship is essential because of the dire consequences any gaps or detaching mountings will have. In the partial eclipse path, one will not be able to see the corona or nearly complete darkening of the sky. However, depending on how much of the Sun's disk is obscured, some darkening may be noticeable. If three-quarters or more of the sun is obscured, then an effect can be observed by which the daylight appears to be dim, as if the sky were overcast, yet objects still cast sharp shadows.<sup id="cite_ref-70" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-70">[70]</a></sup></p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Totality">Totality</span></h3> 
      <div class="thumb tleft"> 
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:122px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:August_21_2017_solar_eclipse_baily_beads_TLR2.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6b/August_21_2017_solar_eclipse_baily_beads_TLR2.jpg/120px-August_21_2017_solar_eclipse_baily_beads_TLR2.jpg" width="120" height="138" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6b/August_21_2017_solar_eclipse_baily_beads_TLR2.jpg/180px-August_21_2017_solar_eclipse_baily_beads_TLR2.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6b/August_21_2017_solar_eclipse_baily_beads_TLR2.jpg/240px-August_21_2017_solar_eclipse_baily_beads_TLR2.jpg 2x" data-file-width="673" data-file-height="776"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption"> 
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:August_21_2017_solar_eclipse_baily_beads_TLR2.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div> 
         <a href="/wiki/Baily%27s_beads" title="Baily's beads">Baily's beads</a>
        </div> 
       </div> 
      </div> 
      <p>When the shrinking visible part of the photosphere becomes very small, <a href="/wiki/Baily%27s_beads" title="Baily's beads">Baily's beads</a> will occur. These are caused by the sunlight still being able to reach the Earth through lunar valleys. Totality then begins with the <a href="/wiki/Diamond_ring_effect" class="mw-redirect" title="Diamond ring effect">diamond ring effect</a>, the last bright flash of sunlight.<sup id="cite_ref-total_71-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-total-71">[71]</a></sup></p> 
      <p>It is safe to observe the total phase of a solar eclipse directly only when the Sun's photosphere is completely covered by the Moon, and not before or after totality.<sup id="cite_ref-Harrington25_68-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Harrington25-68">[68]</a></sup> During this period, the Sun is too dim to be seen through filters. The Sun's faint <a href="/wiki/Corona" title="Corona">corona</a> will be visible, and the <a href="/wiki/Chromosphere" title="Chromosphere">chromosphere</a>, <a href="/wiki/Solar_prominence" title="Solar prominence">solar prominences</a>, and possibly even a <a href="/wiki/Solar_flare" title="Solar flare">solar flare</a> may be seen. At the end of totality, the same effects will occur in reverse order, and on the opposite side of the Moon.<sup id="cite_ref-total_71-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-total-71">[71]</a></sup></p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Photography">Photography</span></h3> 
      <div class="thumb tright"> 
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:272px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:2008-08-01_Solar_eclipse_progression_with_timestamps.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/58/2008-08-01_Solar_eclipse_progression_with_timestamps.jpg/270px-2008-08-01_Solar_eclipse_progression_with_timestamps.jpg" width="270" height="154" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/58/2008-08-01_Solar_eclipse_progression_with_timestamps.jpg/405px-2008-08-01_Solar_eclipse_progression_with_timestamps.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/58/2008-08-01_Solar_eclipse_progression_with_timestamps.jpg/540px-2008-08-01_Solar_eclipse_progression_with_timestamps.jpg 2x" data-file-width="5104" data-file-height="2904"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption"> 
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:2008-08-01_Solar_eclipse_progression_with_timestamps.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div> The progression of a 
         <a href="/wiki/Solar_eclipse_of_August_1,_2008" title="Solar eclipse of August 1, 2008">solar eclipse on August 1, 2008</a> in 
         <a href="/wiki/Novosibirsk" title="Novosibirsk">Novosibirsk</a>, 
         <a href="/wiki/Russia" title="Russia">Russia</a>. All times UTC (local time was UTC+7). The time span between shots is three minutes.
        </div> 
       </div> 
      </div> 
      <p>Photographing an eclipse is possible with fairly common camera equipment. In order for the disk of the Sun/Moon to be easily visible, a fairly high magnification <a href="/wiki/Long_focus_lens" class="mw-redirect" title="Long focus lens">long focus lens</a> is needed (at least 200&nbsp;mm for a 35&nbsp;mm camera), and for the disk to fill most of the frame, a longer lens is needed (over 500&nbsp;mm). As with viewing the Sun directly, looking at it through the optical viewfinder of a camera can produce damage to the retina, so care is recommended.<sup id="cite_ref-72" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-72">[72]</a></sup> Solar filters are required for digital photography even if an optical viewfinder is not used. Using a camera's live view feature or an electronic viewfinder is safe for the human eye, but the Sun's rays could potentially irreparably damage digital image sensors unless the lens is covered by a properly designed solar filter.<sup id="cite_ref-73" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-73">[73]</a></sup></p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Eclipse_chasing">Eclipse chasing</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: 
       <a href="/wiki/Eclipse_chasing" title="Eclipse chasing">Eclipse chasing</a>
      </div> 
      <p>A decidated group of eclipse chasers have pursued the observation of solar eclipses when they occur around the <a href="/wiki/Earth" title="Earth">Earth</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-74" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-74">[74]</a></sup> A person who chases eclipses is known as an umbraphile, meaning shadow lover.<sup id="cite_ref-sola_Umbr_75-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-sola_Umbr-75">[75]</a></sup> Umbraphiles travel for eclipses and use various tools to help view the sun including <a href="/wiki/Solar_viewer" title="Solar viewer">solar viewing glasses</a>, also known as eclipse glasses, as well as telescopes.<sup id="cite_ref-ecli_Safe_76-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ecli_Safe-76">[76]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-atla_Chas_77-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-atla_Chas-77">[77]</a></sup></p> 
      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Other_observations">Other observations</span></h2> 
      <p>A total solar eclipse provides a rare opportunity to observe the <a href="/wiki/Corona" title="Corona">corona</a> (the outer layer of the Sun's atmosphere). Normally this is not visible because the <a href="/wiki/Photosphere" title="Photosphere">photosphere</a> is much brighter than the corona. According to the point reached in the <a href="/wiki/Solar_cycle" title="Solar cycle">solar cycle</a>, the corona may appear small and symmetric, or large and fuzzy. It is very hard to predict this in advance.<sup id="cite_ref-78" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-78">[78]</a></sup></p> 
      <p>As the light filters through leaves of trees during a partial eclipse, the overlapping leaves create natural pinholes, displaying mini eclipses on the ground.<sup id="cite_ref-79" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-79">[79]</a></sup></p> 
      <p>Phenomena associated with eclipses include <a href="/wiki/Shadow_bands" title="Shadow bands">shadow bands</a> (also known as <i>flying shadows</i>), which are similar to shadows on the bottom of a swimming pool. They only occur just prior to and after totality, when a narrow solar crescent acts as an <a href="/wiki/Anisotropy" title="Anisotropy">anisotropic</a> light source.<sup id="cite_ref-80" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-80">[80]</a></sup></p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="1919_observations">1919 observations</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       See also: 
       <a href="/wiki/Tests_of_general_relativity#Deflection_of_light_by_the_Sun" title="Tests of general relativity">Tests of general relativity §&nbsp;Deflection of light by the Sun</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright"> 
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:1919_eclipse_negative.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/da/1919_eclipse_negative.jpg/170px-1919_eclipse_negative.jpg" width="170" height="218" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/da/1919_eclipse_negative.jpg/255px-1919_eclipse_negative.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/da/1919_eclipse_negative.jpg/340px-1919_eclipse_negative.jpg 2x" data-file-width="700" data-file-height="899"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption"> 
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:1919_eclipse_negative.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div> Eddington's original photograph of the 1919 eclipse, which provided evidence for 
         <a href="/wiki/Albert_Einstein" title="Albert Einstein">Einstein</a>'s theory of 
         <a href="/wiki/General_relativity" title="General relativity">general relativity</a>.
        </div> 
       </div> 
      </div> 
      <p>The observation of a total <a href="/wiki/Solar_eclipse_of_May_29,_1919" title="Solar eclipse of May 29, 1919">solar eclipse of May 29, 1919</a>, helped to confirm <a href="/wiki/Albert_Einstein" title="Albert Einstein">Einstein</a>'s theory of <a href="/wiki/General_relativity" title="General relativity">general relativity</a>. By comparing the apparent distance between stars in the constellation <a href="/wiki/Taurus_(constellation)" title="Taurus (constellation)">Taurus</a>, with and without the Sun between them, <a href="/wiki/Arthur_Eddington" title="Arthur Eddington">Arthur Eddington</a> stated that the <a href="/wiki/Predictive_power" title="Predictive power">theoretical predictions</a> about <a href="/wiki/Gravitational_lens" title="Gravitational lens">gravitational lenses</a> were confirmed.<sup id="cite_ref-Eddington1920_81-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Eddington1920-81">[81]</a></sup> The observation with the Sun between the stars was only possible during totality since the stars are then visible. Though Eddington's observations were near the experimental limits of accuracy at the time, work in the later half of the 20th century confirmed his results.<sup id="cite_ref-82" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-82">[82]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-83" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-83">[83]</a></sup></p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Gravity_anomalies">Gravity anomalies</span></h3> 
      <p>There is a long history of observations of gravity-related phenomena during solar eclipses, especially during the period of totality.
