In 1954, and again in 1959, <a href="/wiki/Maurice_Allais" title="Maurice Allais">Maurice Allais</a> reported observations of strange and unexplained movement during solar eclipses.<sup id="cite_ref-84" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-84">[84]</a></sup> The reality of this phenomenon, named the <a href="/wiki/Allais_effect" title="Allais effect">Allais effect</a>, has remained controversial. Similarly, in 1970, <a href="/wiki/Erwin_Saxl" title="Erwin Saxl">Saxl</a> and <a href="/wiki/Mildred_Allen" title="Mildred Allen">Allen</a> observed the sudden change in motion of a torsion pendulum; this phenomenon is called the Saxl effect.<sup id="cite_ref-85" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-85">[85]</a></sup></p> 
      <p>A recent published observation during the 1997 solar eclipse by Wang <i>et al.</i> suggested a possible <a href="/wiki/Gravitational_shielding" title="Gravitational shielding">gravitational shielding</a> effect,<sup id="cite_ref-86" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-86">[86]</a></sup> which generated debate. Later in 2002, Yang and Wang published detailed data analysis, which suggested that the phenomenon still remains unexplained.<sup id="cite_ref-87" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-87">[87]</a></sup></p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Eclipses_and_transits">Eclipses and transits</span></h3> 
      <p>In principle, the simultaneous occurrence of a Solar eclipse and a <a href="/wiki/Astronomical_transit" class="mw-redirect" title="Astronomical transit">transit</a> of a planet is possible. But these events are extremely rare because of their short durations. The next anticipated simultaneous occurrence of a Solar eclipse and a <a href="/wiki/Transit_of_Mercury" title="Transit of Mercury">transit of Mercury</a> will be on July 5, 6757, and a Solar eclipse and a <a href="/wiki/Transit_of_Venus" title="Transit of Venus">transit of Venus</a> is expected on April 5, 15232.<sup id="cite_ref-88" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-88">[88]</a></sup></p> 
      <p>More common, but still infrequent, is a <a href="/wiki/Astronomical_conjunction" class="mw-redirect" title="Astronomical conjunction">conjunction</a> of a planet (especially, but not only, Mercury or Venus) at the time of a total solar eclipse, in which event the planet will be visible very near the eclipsed Sun, when without the eclipse it would have been lost in the Sun's glare. At one time, some scientists hypothesized that there may be a planet (often given the name <a href="/wiki/Vulcan_(hypothetical_planet)" title="Vulcan (hypothetical planet)">Vulcan</a>) even closer to the Sun than Mercury; the only way to confirm its existence would have been to observe it in transit or during a total solar eclipse. No such planet was ever found, and <a href="/wiki/General_relativity" title="General relativity">general relativity</a> has since explained the observations that led astronomers to suggest that Vulcan might exist.<sup id="cite_ref-89" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-89">[89]</a></sup></p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Earthshine">Earthshine</span></h3> 
      <p>During a total solar eclipse, the Moon's shadow covers only a small fraction of the Earth. The Earth continues to receive at least 92 percent of the amount of sunlight it receives without an eclipse&nbsp;–&nbsp;more if the <a href="/wiki/Penumbra" class="mw-redirect" title="Penumbra">penumbra</a> of the Moon's shadow partly misses the Earth. Seen from the Moon, the Earth during a total solar eclipse is mostly brilliantly illuminated, with only a small dark patch showing the Moon's shadow. The brilliantly-lit Earth reflects a lot of light to the Moon. If the <a href="/wiki/Corona" title="Corona">corona</a> of the eclipsed Sun were not present, the Moon, illuminated by earthlight, would be easily visible from Earth. This would be essentially the same as the <a href="/wiki/Earthshine" class="mw-redirect" title="Earthshine">earthshine</a> which can frequently be seen when the Moon's <a href="/wiki/Lunar_phase" title="Lunar phase">phase</a> is a narrow crescent. In reality, the corona, though much less brilliant than the Sun's <a href="/wiki/Photosphere" title="Photosphere">photosphere</a>, is much brighter than the Moon illuminated by earthlight. Therefore, by contrast, the Moon during a total solar eclipse appears to be black, with the corona surrounding it.</p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Artificial_satellites">Artificial satellites</span></h3> 
      <div class="thumb tleft"> 
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:An_EPIC_Eclipse.gif" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cb/An_EPIC_Eclipse.gif/220px-An_EPIC_Eclipse.gif" width="220" height="147" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cb/An_EPIC_Eclipse.gif/330px-An_EPIC_Eclipse.gif 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cb/An_EPIC_Eclipse.gif/440px-An_EPIC_Eclipse.gif 2x" data-file-width="720" data-file-height="480"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption"> 
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:An_EPIC_Eclipse.gif" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div> From space, the Moon's shadow during a solar eclipse appears as a dark spot moving across the Earth.
        </div> 
       </div> 
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright"> 
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Eclipse_fromISS_2006-03-29.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/42/Eclipse_fromISS_2006-03-29.jpg/220px-Eclipse_fromISS_2006-03-29.jpg" width="220" height="146" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/42/Eclipse_fromISS_2006-03-29.jpg/330px-Eclipse_fromISS_2006-03-29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/42/Eclipse_fromISS_2006-03-29.jpg/440px-Eclipse_fromISS_2006-03-29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3040" data-file-height="2016"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption"> 
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Eclipse_fromISS_2006-03-29.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div> The Moon's shadow over 
         <a href="/wiki/Turkey" title="Turkey">Turkey</a> and 
         <a href="/wiki/Cyprus" title="Cyprus">Cyprus</a>, seen from the 
         <a href="/wiki/International_Space_Station" title="International Space Station">ISS</a> during a 
         <a href="/wiki/Solar_eclipse_of_March_29,_2006" title="Solar eclipse of March 29, 2006">2006 total solar eclipse</a>.
        </div> 
       </div> 
      </div> 
      <p>Artificial satellites can also pass in front of the Sun as seen from the Earth, but none is large enough to cause an eclipse. At the altitude of the <a href="/wiki/International_Space_Station" title="International Space Station">International Space Station</a>, for example, an object would need to be about 3.35&nbsp;km (2.08&nbsp;mi) across to blot the Sun out entirely. These transits are difficult to watch because the zone of visibility is very small. The satellite passes over the face of the Sun in about a second, typically. As with a transit of a planet, it will not get dark.<sup id="cite_ref-90" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-90">[90]</a></sup></p> 
      <p>Observations of eclipses from spacecraft or artificial satellites orbiting above the Earth's atmosphere are not subject to weather conditions. The crew of <a href="/wiki/Gemini_12" title="Gemini 12">Gemini 12</a> observed a total solar eclipse from space in 1966.<sup id="cite_ref-91" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-91">[91]</a></sup> The partial phase of the <a href="/wiki/Solar_eclipse_of_August_11,_1999" title="Solar eclipse of August 11, 1999">1999 total eclipse</a> was visible from <a href="/wiki/Mir" title="Mir">Mir</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-92" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-92">[92]</a></sup></p> 
      <p>During the <a href="/wiki/Apollo%E2%80%93Soyuz_Test_Project" title="Apollo–Soyuz Test Project">Apollo–Soyuz Test Project</a> conducted in July 1975, the Apollo spacecraft was positioned to create an artificial solar eclipse giving the Soyuz crew an opportunity to photograph the <a href="/wiki/Solar_corona" class="mw-redirect" title="Solar corona">solar corona</a>.</p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Impact">Impact</span></h3> 
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/Solar_eclipse_of_March_20,_2015" title="Solar eclipse of March 20, 2015">solar eclipse of March 20, 2015</a>, was the first occurrence of an eclipse estimated to potentially have a significant impact on the power system, with the electricity sector taking measures to mitigate any impact. The <a href="/wiki/Synchronous_grid_of_Continental_Europe" title="Synchronous grid of Continental Europe">continental Europe</a> and <a href="/wiki/National_Grid_(Great_Britain)" title="National Grid (Great Britain)">Great Britain</a> synchronous areas were estimated to have about 90 <a href="/wiki/Gigawatt" class="mw-redirect" title="Gigawatt">gigawatts</a> of <a href="/wiki/Solar_power" title="Solar power">solar power</a> and it was estimated that production would temporarily decrease by up to 34 GW compared to a clear sky day.<sup id="cite_ref-eclImp_93-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-eclImp-93">[93]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-94" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-94">[94]</a></sup> The temperature may decrease by 3&nbsp;°C, and <a href="/wiki/Wind_power" title="Wind power">wind power</a> potentially decreases as winds are reduced by 0.7&nbsp;m/s.<sup id="cite_ref-RSwind_95-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-RSwind-95">[95]</a></sup></p> 
      <p>In addition to the drop in light level and air temperature, animals change their behavior during totality. For example, birds and squirrels return to their nests and crickets chirp.<sup id="cite_ref-96" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-96">[96]</a></sup></p> 
      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Recent_and_forthcoming_solar_eclipses">Recent and forthcoming solar eclipses</span></h2> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: 
       <a href="/wiki/List_of_solar_eclipses_in_the_21st_century" title="List of solar eclipses in the 21st century">List of solar eclipses in the 21st century</a>
      </div> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Further information: 
       <a href="/wiki/Lists_of_solar_eclipses" title="Lists of solar eclipses">Lists of solar eclipses</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright"> 
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:302px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Central_eclipses_2001-2020.png" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/43/Central_eclipses_2001-2020.png/300px-Central_eclipses_2001-2020.png" width="300" height="226" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/43/Central_eclipses_2001-2020.png/450px-Central_eclipses_2001-2020.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/43/Central_eclipses_2001-2020.png/600px-Central_eclipses_2001-2020.png 2x" data-file-width="1942" data-file-height="1465"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption"> 
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Central_eclipses_2001-2020.png" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div> Eclipse path for total and hybrid eclipses from 2001 to 2020.
        </div> 
       </div> 
      </div> 
      <p>Eclipses only occur in the <a href="/wiki/Eclipse_season" title="Eclipse season">eclipse season</a>, when the Sun is close to either the ascending or descending <a href="/wiki/Lunar_node" title="Lunar node">node of the Moon</a>. Each eclipse is separated by one, five or six <a href="/wiki/Lunation" class="mw-redirect" title="Lunation">lunations</a> (<a href="/wiki/Synodic_month" class="mw-redirect" title="Synodic month">synodic months</a>), and the midpoint of each season is separated by 173.3 days, which is the mean time for the Sun to travel from one node to the next. The period is a little less than half a calendar year because the lunar nodes slowly regress. Because 223 synodic months is roughly equal to 239 <a href="/wiki/Anomalistic_month" class="mw-redirect" title="Anomalistic month">anomalistic months</a> and 242 <a href="/wiki/Draconic_month" class="mw-redirect" title="Draconic month">draconic months</a>, eclipses with similar geometry recur 223 synodic months (about 6,585.3 days) apart. This period (18 years 11.3 days) is a <a href="/wiki/Saros_(astronomy)" title="Saros (astronomy)">saros</a>. Because 223 synodic months is not identical to 239 anomalistic months or 242 draconic months, saros cycles do not endlessly repeat. Each cycle begins with the Moon's shadow crossing the earth near the north or south pole, and subsequent events progress toward the other pole until the Moon's shadow misses the earth and the series ends.<sup id="cite_ref-period_23-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-period-23">[23]</a></sup> Saros cycles are numbered; currently, cycles 117 to 156 are active. The next solar eclipse will occur on <a href="/wiki/Solar_eclipse_of_February_15,_2018" title="Solar eclipse of February 15, 2018">February 15, 2018</a>. It will be a partial solar eclipse visible from Antarctica and south South America.<sup id="cite_ref-97" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-97">[97]</a></sup></p> 
      <table border="1" cellpadding="7" cellspacing="0" align="center"> 
       <tbody>
        <tr> 
         <td colspan="9" align="center"><b>Solar eclipses</b></td> 
        </tr>

         <td><b><a href="/wiki/Template:Solar_eclipse_set_2000-2003" title="Template:Solar eclipse set 2000-2003">2000–2003</a></b></td> 
         <td><b><a href="/wiki/Template:Solar_eclipse_set_2004-2007" title="Template:Solar eclipse set 2004-2007">2004–2007</a></b></td> 
         <td><b><a href="/wiki/Template:Solar_eclipse_set_2008-2011" class="mw-redirect" title="Template:Solar eclipse set 2008-2011">2008–2011</a></b></td> 
         <td><b><a href="/wiki/Template:Solar_eclipse_set_2011-2014" title="Template:Solar eclipse set 2011-2014">2011–2014</a></b></td> 
         <td><b><a href="/wiki/Template:Solar_eclipse_set_2015-2018" title="Template:Solar eclipse set 2015-2018">2015–2018</a></b></td> 
         <td><b><a href="/wiki/Template:Solar_eclipse_set_2018-2021" class="mw-redirect" title="Template:Solar eclipse set 2018-2021">2018–2021</a></b></td> 
         <td><b><a href="/wiki/Template:Solar_eclipse_set_2022-2025" title="Template:Solar eclipse set 2022-2025">2022–2025</a></b></td>

        </tr> 
       </tbody>
      </table>

        <li id="cite_note-19"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-19">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://education.gsfc.nasa.gov/eclipse/pages/faq.html">NASA – Eclipse 99 – Frequently Asked Questions</a> <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20100527142627/http://education.gsfc.nasa.gov/eclipse/pages/faq.html">Archived</a> 2010-05-27 at the <a href="/wiki/Wayback_Machine" title="Wayback Machine">Wayback Machine</a>. – There is a mistake in the <i>How long will we continue to be able to see total eclipses of the Sun?</i> answer, "...the Sun's angular diameter varies from 32.7 minutes of arc when the Earth is at its farthest point in its orbit (aphelion), and 31.6 arc minutes when it is at its closest (perihelion)." It should appear smaller when farther, so the values should be swapped.</span></li>

       <div style="text-align: center; font-size: 90%; margin-bottom: .4em;">
        <i><a href="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/9/95/Solar_eclipse_Part_1.ogg" class="internal" title="Solar eclipse Part 1.ogg">Part 1</a>&nbsp;• <a href="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/5/56/Solar_eclipse_Part_2.ogg" class="internal" title="Solar eclipse Part 2.ogg">Part 2</a></i>
       </div> 
       <div style="float: left; margin-left: 5px;"> 
        <div class="floatnone">
         <img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/47/Sound-icon.svg/45px-Sound-icon.svg.png" title="Spoken Wikipedia" width="45" height="34" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/47/Sound-icon.svg/68px-Sound-icon.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/47/Sound-icon.svg/90px-Sound-icon.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="128" data-file-height="96">
        </div> 
       </div> 
       <div style="font-size: xx-small; line-height: 1.6em; margin-left: 60px;">
        This audio file was created from a revision of the article "
        <span class="fn">Solar eclipse</span>" dated 2006-05-03, and does not reflect subsequent edits to the article. (
        <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Media_help" class="mw-redirect" title="Wikipedia:Media help">Audio help</a>)
       </div>

       <li><a href="/wiki/File:Wikisource-logo.svg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4c/Wikisource-logo.svg/12px-Wikisource-logo.svg.png" width="12" height="13" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4c/Wikisource-logo.svg/18px-Wikisource-logo.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4c/Wikisource-logo.svg/24px-Wikisource-logo.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="410" data-file-height="430"></a>&nbsp;<cite class="citation encyclopaedia">"<a href="https://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Collier%27s_New_Encyclopedia_(1921)/Sun,_Eclipses_of_the" class="extiw" title="s:Collier's New Encyclopedia (1921)/Sun, Eclipses of the">Sun, Eclipses of the</a>". <i><a href="/wiki/Collier%27s_Encyclopedia" title="Collier's Encyclopedia">Collier's New Encyclopedia</a></i>. 1921.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=bookitem&amp;rft.atitle=Sun%2C+Eclipses+of+the&amp;rft.btitle=Collier%27s+New+Encyclopedia&amp;rft.date=1921&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ASolar+eclipse" class="Z3988"><span style="display:none;">&nbsp;</span></span></li>

       <li><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://digitalcollections.ucsc.edu/cdm/search/collection/p265101coll10/searchterm/Solar%20eclipses/mode/exact">Solar eclipse photographs taken from the Lick Observatory from the Lick Observatory Records Digital Archive, UC Santa Cruz Library’s Digital Collections</a></li> 
       <li><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=sr8ASPwrs58"><span class="plainlinks">Video with Total Solar Eclipse March 09 2016 (From the Beginning to the Total Phase)</span></a> on <a href="/wiki/YouTube" title="YouTube">YouTube</a></li> 
       <li><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=2i4PJWCNBaM">Total Solar Eclipse Shadow on Earth March 09 2016</a> <a href="/w/index.php?title=CIMSSSatelite&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="CIMSSSatelite (page does not exist)">CIMSSSatelite</a></li>

              <th scope="row" class="navbox-group" style="width:1%">Visibility</th> 
              <td class="navbox-list navbox-odd" style="text-align:left;border-left-width:2px;border-left-style:solid;width:100%;padding:0px"> 
               <div style="padding:0em 0.25em"> 
                <ul> 
                 <li><a href="/wiki/List_of_solar_eclipses_visible_from_Australia" title="List of solar eclipses visible from Australia">Australia</a></li> 
                 <li><a href="/wiki/List_of_solar_eclipses_visible_from_China" title="List of solar eclipses visible from China">China</a></li> 
                 <li><a href="/wiki/List_of_solar_eclipses_visible_from_the_Philippines" title="List of solar eclipses visible from the Philippines">Philippines</a></li> 
                 <li><a href="/wiki/List_of_solar_eclipses_visible_from_Russia" title="List of solar eclipses visible from Russia">Russia</a></li> 
                 <li><a href="/wiki/List_of_solar_eclipses_visible_from_Ukraine" title="List of solar eclipses visible from Ukraine">Ukraine</a></li> 
                 <li><a href="/wiki/List_of_solar_eclipses_visible_from_the_United_Kingdom" title="List of solar eclipses visible from the United Kingdom">United Kingdom</a></li> 
                 <li><a href="/wiki/List_of_solar_eclipses_visible_from_the_United_States" title="List of solar eclipses visible from the United States">United States</a></li> 
                </ul> 
               </div> </td> 
             </tr> 
             <tr> 
              <th scope="row" class="navbox-group" style="width:1%">Historical</th> 
              <td class="navbox-list navbox-even" style="text-align:left;border-left-width:2px;border-left-style:solid;width:100%;padding:0px"> 
               <div style="padding:0em 0.25em"> 
                <ul> 
                 <li><a href="/wiki/Mursili%27s_eclipse" title="Mursili's eclipse">Mursili's eclipse</a> (1312 BC)</li> 
                 <li><a href="/wiki/Assyrian_eclipse" title="Assyrian eclipse">Assyrian eclipse</a> (763 BC)</li> 
                 <li><a href="/wiki/Eclipse_of_Thales" title="Eclipse of Thales">Eclipse of Thales</a> (585 BC)</li> 
                </ul> 
               </div> </td> 
             </tr> 
            </tbody>
           </table> </td> 
         </tr> 
         <tr> 
          <th scope="row" class="navbox-group" style="width:1%;text-align:center;"><a href="/wiki/File:Total_Solar_Eclipse,_9_March_2016,_from_Balikpapan,_East_Kalimantan,_Indonesia.JPG" class="image" title="9 March 2016 total solar eclipse"><img alt="9 March 2016 total solar eclipse" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ec/Total_Solar_Eclipse%2C_9_March_2016%2C_from_Balikpapan%2C_East_Kalimantan%2C_Indonesia.JPG/80px-Total_Solar_Eclipse%2C_9_March_2016%2C_from_Balikpapan%2C_East_Kalimantan%2C_Indonesia.JPG" width="80" height="80" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ec/Total_Solar_Eclipse%2C_9_March_2016%2C_from_Balikpapan%2C_East_Kalimantan%2C_Indonesia.JPG/120px-Total_Solar_Eclipse%2C_9_March_2016%2C_from_Balikpapan%2C_East_Kalimantan%2C_Indonesia.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ec/Total_Solar_Eclipse%2C_9_March_2016%2C_from_Balikpapan%2C_East_Kalimantan%2C_Indonesia.JPG/160px-Total_Solar_Eclipse%2C_9_March_2016%2C_from_Balikpapan%2C_East_Kalimantan%2C_Indonesia.JPG 2x" data-file-width="750" data-file-height="751"></a><br> Total/hybrid eclipses<br> <span style="background-color: #F3D6D6">?</span> <small>next total/hybrid</small></th>

             <li><a href="/wiki/Solar_eclipse_of_March_10,_2100" title="Solar eclipse of March 10, 2100">2100</a></li> 
            </ul> 
           </div> </td> 
         </tr> 
         <tr> 
          <th scope="row" class="navbox-group" style="width:1%;text-align:center;"><a href="/wiki/File:Partial_solar_eclipse_Oct_23_2014_Minneapolis_5-36pm_Ruen1.png" class="image" title="23 October 2014 partial eclipse"><img alt="23 October 2014 partial eclipse" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/09/Partial_solar_eclipse_Oct_23_2014_Minneapolis_5-36pm_Ruen1.png/80px-Partial_solar_eclipse_Oct_23_2014_Minneapolis_5-36pm_Ruen1.png" width="80" height="80" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/09/Partial_solar_eclipse_Oct_23_2014_Minneapolis_5-36pm_Ruen1.png/120px-Partial_solar_eclipse_Oct_23_2014_Minneapolis_5-36pm_Ruen1.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/09/Partial_solar_eclipse_Oct_23_2014_Minneapolis_5-36pm_Ruen1.png/160px-Partial_solar_eclipse_Oct_23_2014_Minneapolis_5-36pm_Ruen1.png 2x" data-file-width="1181" data-file-height="1180"></a><br> Partial eclipses<br> <span style="background-color: #F3D6D6">?</span> <small>next partial</small></th>

   <h1 id="firstHeading" class="firstHeading" lang="en">Solar eclipse of August 11, 1999</h1> 
   <div id="bodyContent" class="mw-body-content"> 
    <div id="siteSub" class="noprint">
     From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia
    </div> 
    <div id="contentSub"></div> 
    <div id="jump-to-nav" class="mw-jump">
      Jump to: 
     <a href="#mw-head">navigation</a>, 
     <a href="#p-search">search</a> 
    </div> 
    <div id="mw-content-text" lang="en" dir="ltr" class="mw-content-ltr">
     <div class="mw-parser-output">
      <table class="infobox vevent" style="width:22em;width:25em; text-align:left; font-size:90%;">

        </tr> 
        <tr> 
         <td colspan="2" style="text-align:center;padding-bottom:0.5em;"><a href="/wiki/File:Solar_eclipse_1999_4_NR.jpg" class="image"><img alt="Solar eclipse 1999 4 NR.jpg" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1c/Solar_eclipse_1999_4_NR.jpg/320px-Solar_eclipse_1999_4_NR.jpg" width="320" height="315" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1c/Solar_eclipse_1999_4_NR.jpg/480px-Solar_eclipse_1999_4_NR.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1c/Solar_eclipse_1999_4_NR.jpg/640px-Solar_eclipse_1999_4_NR.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3543" data-file-height="3489"></a>

            Map
           </div> 
          </div> </td> 
        </tr>

        </tr>

         <th scope="row" style="padding:0 0.5em 0 0; line-height:1.1em;"><a href="/wiki/Magnitude_of_eclipse" title="Magnitude of eclipse">Magnitude</a></th> 
         <td style="padding:0; line-height:1.2em; vertical-align:middle;">1.0286</td> 
        </tr> 
        <tr>

        </tr> 
        <tr> 
         <th scope="row" style="padding:0 0.5em 0 0; line-height:1.1em;">Duration</th>

        </tr> 
        <tr> 
         <th scope="row" style="padding:0 0.5em 0 0; line-height:1.1em;">Coordinates</th> 
         <td style="padding:0; line-height:1.2em; vertical-align:middle;"><span class="plainlinks nourlexpansion"><a class="external text" href="//tools.wmflabs.org/geohack/geohack.php?pagename=Solar_eclipse_of_August_11,_1999&amp;params=45.1_N_24.3_E_type:landmark"><span class="geo-nondefault"><span class="geo-dms" title="Maps, aerial photos, and other data for this location"><span class="latitude">45°06?N</span> <span class="longitude">24°18?E</span></span></span><span class="geo-multi-punct">? / ?</span><span class="geo-default"><span class="geo-dec" title="Maps, aerial photos, and other data for this location">45.1°N 24.3°E</span><span style="display:none">? / <span class="geo">45.1; 24.3</span></span></span></a></span></td> 
        </tr> 
        <tr> 
         <th scope="row" style="padding:0 0.5em 0 0; line-height:1.1em;">Max.&nbsp;width of&nbsp;band</th>

        </tr> 
        <tr> 
         <th colspan="2" style="text-align:center;background:#eee; font-size:105%;">Times (<a href="/wiki/UTC" class="mw-redirect" title="UTC">UTC</a>)</th>

         <th scope="row" style="padding:0 0.5em 0 0; line-height:1.1em;">Greatest eclipse</th>

        </tr> 
        <tr>

        </tr> 
        <tr> 
         <th scope="row" style="padding:0 0.5em 0 0; line-height:1.1em;"><a href="/wiki/Saros_(astronomy)" title="Saros (astronomy)">Saros</a></th> 
         <td style="padding:0; line-height:1.2em; vertical-align:middle;"><a href="/wiki/Solar_Saros_145" title="Solar Saros 145">145</a> (21 of 77)</td> 
        </tr> 
        <tr> 
         <th scope="row" style="padding:0 0.5em 0 0; line-height:1.1em;">Catalog # (SE5000)</th> 
         <td style="padding:0; line-height:1.2em; vertical-align:middle;"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://eclipse.gsfc.nasa.gov/SEcat5/SE1991-2090.html">9506</a></td> 
        </tr> 
       </tbody>
      </table> 
      <p>A total <a href="/wiki/Solar_eclipse" title="Solar eclipse">solar eclipse</a> occurred on 11 August 1999 with an <a href="/wiki/Magnitude_of_eclipse" title="Magnitude of eclipse">eclipse magnitude</a> of 1.029. A <a href="/wiki/Solar_eclipse" title="Solar eclipse">solar eclipse</a> occurs when the <a href="/wiki/Moon" title="Moon">Moon</a> passes between <a href="/wiki/Earth" title="Earth">Earth</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Sun" title="Sun">Sun</a>, thereby totally or partly obscuring the image of the Sun for a viewer on Earth. A total solar eclipse occurs when the Moon's <a href="/wiki/Apparent_diameter" class="mw-redirect" title="Apparent diameter">apparent diameter</a> is larger than the Sun's, blocking all direct sunlight, turning day into darkness. Totality occurs in a narrow path across Earth's surface, with the partial solar eclipse visible over a surrounding region thousands of kilometres wide. The path of the <a href="/wiki/Moon" title="Moon">Moon</a>'s shadow began in the <a href="/wiki/Atlantic_Ocean" title="Atlantic Ocean">Atlantic Ocean</a> and, before noon, was traversing the southern <a href="/wiki/United_Kingdom" title="United Kingdom">United Kingdom</a>, northern <a href="/wiki/France" title="France">France</a>, <a href="/wiki/Belgium" title="Belgium">Belgium</a>, <a href="/wiki/Luxembourg" title="Luxembourg">Luxembourg</a>, southern <a href="/wiki/Germany" title="Germany">Germany</a>, <a href="/wiki/Austria" title="Austria">Austria</a>, <a href="/wiki/Slovenia" title="Slovenia">Slovenia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Croatia" title="Croatia">Croatia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hungary" title="Hungary">Hungary</a>, and northern <a href="/wiki/FR_Yugoslavia" class="mw-redirect" title="FR Yugoslavia">FR Yugoslavia</a> (<a href="/wiki/Vojvodina" title="Vojvodina">Vojvodina</a>). The eclipse's maximum was at 11:03 UTC at <span class="plainlinks nourlexpansion"><a class="external text" href="//tools.wmflabs.org/geohack/geohack.php?pagename=Solar_eclipse_of_August_11,_1999&amp;params=45.1_N_24.3_E_"><span class="geo-nondefault"><span class="geo-dms" title="Maps, aerial photos, and other data for this location"><span class="latitude">45°06?N</span> <span class="longitude">24°18?E</span></span></span><span class="geo-multi-punct">? / ?</span><span class="geo-default"><span class="geo-dec" title="Maps, aerial photos, and other data for this location">45.1°N 24.3°E</span><span style="display:none">? / <span class="geo">45.1; 24.3</span></span></span></a></span> in <a href="/wiki/Romania" title="Romania">Romania</a> (next to a town called <a href="/wiki/Ocnele_Mari" title="Ocnele Mari">Ocnele Mari</a> near <a href="/wiki/R%C3%A2mnicu_V%C3%A2lcea" title="Râmnicu Vâlcea">Râmnicu Vâlcea</a>); and it continued across <a href="/wiki/Bulgaria" title="Bulgaria">Bulgaria</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Black_Sea" title="Black Sea">Black Sea</a>, <a href="/wiki/Turkey" title="Turkey">Turkey</a>, northeastern tip of <a href="/wiki/Syria" title="Syria">Syria</a>, northern <a href="/wiki/Iraq" title="Iraq">Iraq</a>, <a href="/wiki/Iran" title="Iran">Iran</a>, southern <a href="/wiki/Pakistan" title="Pakistan">Pakistan</a> and <a href="/wiki/Srikakulam" title="Srikakulam">Srikakulam</a> in <a href="/wiki/India" title="India">India</a> and ended in the <a href="/wiki/Bay_of_Bengal" title="Bay of Bengal">Bay of Bengal</a>.</p> 
      <p>It was the first total eclipse visible from Europe since <a href="/wiki/Solar_eclipse_of_July_22,_1990" title="Solar eclipse of July 22, 1990">22 July 1990</a>, and the first visible in the <a href="/wiki/United_Kingdom" title="United Kingdom">United Kingdom</a> since <a href="/wiki/Solar_eclipse_of_June_29,_1927" title="Solar eclipse of June 29, 1927">29 June 1927</a>.</p> 
      <p></p> 
      <div id="toc" class="toc"> 
       <div class="toctitle" lang="en" dir="ltr" xml:lang="en">

      <p></p> 
      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Observations">Observations</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Solar_eclipse_of_August_11,_1999&amp;action=edit&amp;section=1" title="Edit section: Observations">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2> 
      <div class="thumb tleft"> 
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Film_eclipse_soleil_1999.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5d/Film_eclipse_soleil_1999.jpg/220px-Film_eclipse_soleil_1999.jpg" width="220" height="31" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5d/Film_eclipse_soleil_1999.jpg/330px-Film_eclipse_soleil_1999.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5d/Film_eclipse_soleil_1999.jpg/440px-Film_eclipse_soleil_1999.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1276" data-file-height="179"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption"> 
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Film_eclipse_soleil_1999.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div> The eclipse as seen from France
        </div> 
       </div> 
      </div> 
      <p>Because of the high population densities in areas of the path, this was one of the most-viewed total solar eclipses in <a href="/wiki/Human_history" class="mw-redirect" title="Human history">human history</a>;<sup id="cite_ref-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-1">[1]</a></sup> although some areas in the path of totality (mainly in Western Europe) offered impaired visibility due to adverse weather conditions.</p> 
      <p>Some of the organized eclipse-watching parties along the path of totality set up video projectors on which people could watch the Moon's shadow as it raced towards them.<sup id="cite_ref-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2">[2]</a></sup> There was substantial coverage on International TV stations of the progress of the eclipse shadow. The Moon's shadow was also observed from the Russian <a href="/wiki/Mir" title="Mir">Mir</a> space station; during the eclipse, video from Mir was broadcast live on television.</p> 
      <ul> 
       <li>The <a href="/wiki/BBC" title="BBC">BBC</a> concentrated its coverage efforts on the first landfall of the shadow across the western end of <a href="/wiki/Cornwall" title="Cornwall">Cornwall</a> (from <a href="/wiki/St_Ives,_Cornwall" title="St Ives, Cornwall">St Ives</a> to <a href="/wiki/Lizard_(village)" title="Lizard (village)">Lizard</a>), which was packed with an extraordinary number of visitors, although Cornwall did not have nearly as many as expected leading to many specially organised events being left with very small attendance. The veteran amateur astronomer, broadcaster and eclipse-watcher <a href="/wiki/Patrick_Moore" title="Patrick Moore">Patrick Moore</a> was brought in to head a live programme, but the eclipse was clouded out. <a href="/wiki/BBC_One" title="BBC One">BBC One</a> also produced a special version of their <a href="/wiki/BBC_One_%27Balloon%27_idents" title="BBC One 'Balloon' idents">Balloon Idents</a> for the event. The BBC did not have a presence at <a href="/wiki/Goonhilly_Satellite_Earth_Station" title="Goonhilly Satellite Earth Station">Goonhilly</a> on the <a href="/wiki/The_Lizard" title="The Lizard">Lizard Peninsula</a>, one of the few places in Cornwall where the clouds parted just in time for the total eclipse to be visible.</li> 
       <li>Some of the best viewing conditions were to be had mid-<a href="/wiki/English_Channel" title="English Channel">Channel</a>, where ferries were halted in calm conditions to obtain an excellent view. Hundreds of people who gathered on the island of <a href="/wiki/Alderney" title="Alderney">Alderney</a> also experienced the event. There was extensive cloud in <a href="/wiki/Perranporth" title="Perranporth">Perranporth</a> which parted just in time, allowing the very large crowd that filled the beach and hillsides to witness this spectacular event. The clouds' parting was as magical as the eclipse itself.</li> 
       <li>A gathering of several thousand people at the airport in <a href="/wiki/Soissons" title="Soissons">Soissons</a>, <a href="/wiki/France" title="France">France</a>, which was on the path of totality, were denied all but a few fleeting glimpses of the eclipse through the overcast sky. The clouds cleared completely just a few minutes after the eclipse.</li> 
       <li>In contrast, the overcast sky in <a href="/wiki/Amiens" title="Amiens">Amiens</a>, France, where thousands had gathered, cleared only minutes before the eclipse began.</li> 
       <li>Further inland, viewing conditions were also perfect at <a href="/wiki/Vouziers" title="Vouziers">Vouziers</a>, a French country town gridlocked by Belgian cars from day-visitors. The patchy cloud covering cleared a short time before the shadow arrived. Some photos from Vouziers were used on the subsequent BBC <a href="/wiki/The_Sky_at_Night" title="The Sky at Night">Sky at Night</a> programme.</li> 
       <li>The San Francisco <a href="/wiki/Exploratorium" title="Exploratorium">Exploratorium</a> featured a live webcast from a crowded town square in <a href="/wiki/Amasya" title="Amasya">Amasya</a>, <a href="/wiki/Turkey" title="Turkey">Turkey</a>.</li> 
       <li><a href="/wiki/Doordarshan" title="Doordarshan">Doordarshan</a>, the national TV channel in India, broadcast live coverage from <a href="/wiki/Srikakulam" title="Srikakulam">Srikakulam</a>, hosted by the TV personality <a href="/wiki/Monoranjan_Bhattacharya" class="mw-redirect" title="Monoranjan Bhattacharya">Mona Bhattacharya</a>.</li> 
       <li>A <a href="/wiki/Bulgarian_Air_Force" title="Bulgarian Air Force">Bulgarian Air Force</a> <a href="/wiki/Mikoyan-Gurevich_MiG-21" title="Mikoyan-Gurevich MiG-21">MiG-21</a> two-seater was used by the <a href="/wiki/Bulgarian_Academy_of_Sciences" title="Bulgarian Academy of Sciences">Bulgarian Academy of Sciences</a> to study the solar <a href="/wiki/Corona" title="Corona">corona</a>. The MiG-21, flying at 1600–1700&nbsp;km/h (M=1,4-1,5) at an altitude of 13,000 m, was able to stay in the Moon's <a href="/wiki/Umbra" class="mw-redirect" title="Umbra">umbra</a> for 6 min. The photographer, an air force pilot, used two film cameras, both fitted with 200&nbsp;mm lenses and <a href="/wiki/Infrared" title="Infrared">infrared</a> filters, and one <a href="/wiki/Digital8" title="Digital8">Digital8</a> video camera.</li> 
       <li>Hungary's most popular tourist destination, <a href="/wiki/Lake_Balaton" title="Lake Balaton">Lake Balaton</a> and its surrounding area, fell into the path of the eclipse entirely, which made the area even more popular for that day. The motorway leading there was so crowded, many people had to watch the eclipse while caught in a traffic jam.</li> 
       <li>One French and two British <a href="/wiki/Concorde" title="Concorde">Concordes</a> briefly followed the eclipse with tourists on board.<sup id="cite_ref-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-3">[3]</a></sup></li> 
       <li>The <a href="/wiki/BBC" title="BBC">BBC</a> was filming one of its episodes for its TV series <i><a href="/wiki/Airport_(TV_series)" title="Airport (TV series)">Airport</a></i> that day and, during the show, resident press officers Russell Clisby and Steve Meller took photographs of the eclipse at <a href="/wiki/Heathrow_Airport" title="Heathrow Airport">Heathrow Airport</a>, as well as <a href="/wiki/Aeroflot" title="Aeroflot">Aeroflot</a> supervisor <a href="/wiki/Jeremy_Spake" title="Jeremy Spake">Jeremy Spake</a> witnessing the eclipse on a special charter flight.</li> 
       <li><a href="/wiki/Radio_Television_of_Serbia" title="Radio Television of Serbia">RTS</a>, the national public broadcaster of <a href="/wiki/Serbia" title="Serbia">Serbia</a>, urged people to remain inside, citing dangers to public health. This caused the streets of all Serbian cities, towns and villages to be entirely deserted during the eclipse, with many opting to watch it on TV instead.<sup id="cite_ref-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-4">[4]</a></sup></li> 
       <li><a href="/wiki/The_BMJ" title="The BMJ">The BMJ</a> a month after the eclipse reported only 14 cases of eye damage from improper viewing of the eclipse, a number lower than initially feared. In one of the most serious cases the patient had looked at the sun without eye protection for twenty minutes, but overall the public health campaign had succeeded. <sup id="cite_ref-UK_Public_Health_Assessment_5-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-UK_Public_Health_Assessment-5">[5]</a></sup></li> 
      </ul>

      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Type_of_the_eclipse">Type of the eclipse</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Solar_eclipse_of_August_11,_1999&amp;action=edit&amp;section=4" title="Edit section: Type of the eclipse">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2> 
      <table border="0" style="border:1px solid #999; background:#fff;"> 
       <tbody>
        <tr> 
         <td>Nature of the eclipse</td> 
         <td>Total</td> 
        </tr>

         <td>Gamma</td> 
         <td>0.5063</td> 
        </tr>

         <td>1.0286</td> 
        </tr> 
        <tr style="background:#efefef;"> 
         <td>Duration at greatest eclipse point</td>

      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Related_eclipses">Related eclipses</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Solar_eclipse_of_August_11,_1999&amp;action=edit&amp;section=5" title="Edit section: Related eclipses">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2> 
      <h3><span id="Solar_eclipses_1997.E2.80.932000"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Solar_eclipses_1997–2000">Solar eclipses 1997–2000</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Solar_eclipse_of_August_11,_1999&amp;action=edit&amp;section=6" title="Edit section: Solar eclipses 1997–2000">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3> 
      <p>Each member in a <a href="/wiki/Eclipse_cycle#Eclipse_cycles" title="Eclipse cycle">semester series</a> of solar eclipses repeats approximately every 177 days and 4 hours (a semester) at alternating <a href="/wiki/Lunar_node" title="Lunar node">nodes</a> of the Moon's orbit.</p> 
      <table class="wikitable collapsible collapsed"> 
       <tbody>
        <tr> 
         <th colspan="5"><a href="/wiki/Solar_eclipse" title="Solar eclipse">Solar eclipse</a> series sets from 1997 to 2000</th> 
        </tr> 
        <tr> 
         <th colspan="2">Descending node</th> 
         <td rowspan="6">&nbsp;</td> 
         <th colspan="2">Ascending node</th> 
        </tr> 
        <tr style="text-align:center;"> 
         <th>Saros</th> 
         <th>Map</th> 
         <th>Saros</th> 
         <th>Map</th> 
        </tr> 
        <tr style="text-align:center;vertical-align:top;"> 
         <td>120<br> <a href="/wiki/File:Total_solar_eclipse_of_March_9_1997.jpg" class="image"><img alt="Total solar eclipse of March 9 1997.jpg" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c5/Total_solar_eclipse_of_March_9_1997.jpg/150px-Total_solar_eclipse_of_March_9_1997.jpg" width="150" height="122" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c5/Total_solar_eclipse_of_March_9_1997.jpg/225px-Total_solar_eclipse_of_March_9_1997.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c5/Total_solar_eclipse_of_March_9_1997.jpg/300px-Total_solar_eclipse_of_March_9_1997.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3033" data-file-height="2461"></a><br> <a href="/wiki/Chita,_Zabaykalsky_Krai" title="Chita, Zabaykalsky Krai">Chita, Russia</a></td> 
         <td><a href="/wiki/Solar_eclipse_of_March_9,_1997" title="Solar eclipse of March 9, 1997">March 9, 1997</a><br> <a href="/wiki/File:SE1997Mar09T.png" class="image"><img alt="SE1997Mar09T.png" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4c/SE1997Mar09T.png/150px-SE1997Mar09T.png" width="150" height="150" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4c/SE1997Mar09T.png/225px-SE1997Mar09T.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4c/SE1997Mar09T.png/300px-SE1997Mar09T.png 2x" data-file-width="728" data-file-height="729"></a><br> Total</td>

        </tr> 
        <tr> 
         <th colspan="7">Partial solar eclipses on <a href="/wiki/Solar_eclipse_of_July_1,_2000" title="Solar eclipse of July 1, 2000">July 1, 2000</a> and <a href="/wiki/Solar_eclipse_of_December_25,_2000" title="Solar eclipse of December 25, 2000">December 25, 2000</a> occur in the next lunar year eclipse set.</th> 
        </tr> 
       </tbody>
      </table> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Saros_145">Saros 145</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Solar_eclipse_of_August_11,_1999&amp;action=edit&amp;section=7" title="Edit section: Saros 145">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3> 
      <p>This solar eclipse is a part of <a href="/wiki/Solar_Saros_145" title="Solar Saros 145">Saros cycle 145</a>, repeating every 18 years, 11 days, 8 hours, containing 77 events. The series started with a partial solar eclipse on January 4, 1639, and reached a first annular eclipse on June 6, 1891. It was a hybrid event on June 17, 1909, and total eclipses from June 29, 1927, through September 9, 2648. The series ends at member 77 as a partial eclipse on April 17, 3009. The longest eclipse will occur on June 25, 2522, with a maximum duration of totality of 7 minutes, 12 seconds. <sup id="cite_ref-8" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-8">[8]</a></sup></p> 
      <table class="wikitable collapsible collapsed"> 
       <tbody>
        <tr> 
         <th colspan="3">Series members 16–26 occur between 1901 and 2100</th> 
        </tr> 
        <tr> 
         <th>16</th>

      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Metonic_series">Metonic series</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Solar_eclipse_of_August_11,_1999&amp;action=edit&amp;section=8" title="Edit section: Metonic series">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3> 
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/Metonic_cycle" title="Metonic cycle">metonic series</a> repeats eclipses every 19 years (6939.69 days), lasting about 5 cycles. Eclipses occur in nearly the same calendar date. In addition, the octon subseries repeats 1/5 of that or every 3.8 years (1387.94 days).</p> 
      <table class="wikitable collapsible collapsed"> 
       <tbody>
        <tr> 
         <th colspan="5">21 eclipse events between August 12, 1942 and August 11, 2018</th> 
        </tr>

         <th>January 4-5</th> 
         <th>October 23-24</th> 
        </tr>

         <td><a href="/wiki/File:SE2011Jan04P.png" class="image"><img alt="SE2011Jan04P.png" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5b/SE2011Jan04P.png/150px-SE2011Jan04P.png" width="150" height="150" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5b/SE2011Jan04P.png/225px-SE2011Jan04P.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5b/SE2011Jan04P.png/300px-SE2011Jan04P.png 2x" data-file-width="728" data-file-height="729"></a><br> <a href="/wiki/Solar_eclipse_of_January_4,_2011" title="Solar eclipse of January 4, 2011">January 4, 2011</a></td> 
         <td><a href="/wiki/File:SE2014Oct23P.png" class="image"><img alt="SE2014Oct23P.png" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/ce/SE2014Oct23P.png/150px-SE2014Oct23P.png" width="150" height="150" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/ce/SE2014Oct23P.png/225px-SE2014Oct23P.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/ce/SE2014Oct23P.png/300px-SE2014Oct23P.png 2x" data-file-width="728" data-file-height="729"></a><br> <a href="/wiki/Solar_eclipse_of_October_23,_2014" title="Solar eclipse of October 23, 2014">October 23, 2014</a></td> 
        </tr> 
        <tr style="text-align:center;"> 
         <th>155</th> 
        </tr> 
        <tr style="text-align:center;"> 
         <td><a href="/wiki/File:SE2018Aug11P.png" class="image"><img alt="SE2018Aug11P.png" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/eb/SE2018Aug11P.png/150px-SE2018Aug11P.png" width="150" height="150" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/eb/SE2018Aug11P.png/225px-SE2018Aug11P.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/eb/SE2018Aug11P.png/300px-SE2018Aug11P.png 2x" data-file-width="728" data-file-height="729"></a><br> <a href="/wiki/Solar_eclipse_of_August_11,_2018" title="Solar eclipse of August 11, 2018">August 11, 2018</a></td> 
        </tr> 
       </tbody>
      </table> 
      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="See_also">See also</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Solar_eclipse_of_August_11,_1999&amp;action=edit&amp;section=9" title="Edit section: See also">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2> 
      <ul> 
       <li><a href="/wiki/List_of_solar_eclipses_visible_from_the_United_Kingdom" title="List of solar eclipses visible from the United Kingdom">List of solar eclipses visible from the United Kingdom</a></li> 
      </ul> 
      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Notes">Notes</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Solar_eclipse_of_August_11,_1999&amp;action=edit&amp;section=10" title="Edit section: Notes">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2> 
      <div class="reflist" style="list-style-type: decimal;"> 
       <div class="mw-references-wrap">

         </tr>

 <body class="mediawiki ltr sitedir-ltr mw-hide-empty-elt ns-0 ns-subject page-Solar_prominence rootpage-Solar_prominence skin-vector action-view"> 
  <div id="mw-page-base" class="noprint"></div> 
  <div id="mw-head-base" class="noprint"></div> 
  <div id="content" class="mw-body" role="main"> 
   <a id="top"></a>

   <div class="mw-indicators mw-body-content"> 
   </div> 
   <h1 id="firstHeading" class="firstHeading" lang="en">Solar prominence</h1> 
   <div id="bodyContent" class="mw-body-content"> 
    <div id="siteSub" class="noprint">
     From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia
    </div> 
    <div id="contentSub"></div> 
    <div id="jump-to-nav" class="mw-jump">
      Jump to: 
     <a href="#mw-head">navigation</a>, 
     <a href="#p-search">search</a> 
    </div> 
    <div id="mw-content-text" lang="en" dir="ltr" class="mw-content-ltr">
     <div class="mw-parser-output">
      <div class="thumb tright"> 
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Sun_earth_jupiter_whole_600.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/39/Sun_earth_jupiter_whole_600.jpg/220px-Sun_earth_jupiter_whole_600.jpg" width="220" height="220" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/39/Sun_earth_jupiter_whole_600.jpg/330px-Sun_earth_jupiter_whole_600.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/39/Sun_earth_jupiter_whole_600.jpg/440px-Sun_earth_jupiter_whole_600.jpg 2x" data-file-width="600" data-file-height="599"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption"> 
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Sun_earth_jupiter_whole_600.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div> Solar Prominence with images of Jupiter and Earth for size comparison.
        </div> 
       </div> 
      </div> 
      <p>A <b>prominence</b> is a large, bright, gaseous feature extending outward from the <a href="/wiki/Sun" title="Sun">Sun</a>'s surface, often in a <a href="/wiki/Coronal_loops" class="mw-redirect" title="Coronal loops">loop</a> shape. Prominences are anchored to the Sun's surface in the <a href="/wiki/Photosphere" title="Photosphere">photosphere</a>, and extend outwards into the Sun's <a href="/wiki/Corona" title="Corona">corona</a>. While the corona consists of extremely hot <a href="/wiki/Ionized" class="mw-redirect" title="Ionized">ionized</a> <a href="/wiki/Gas" title="Gas">gases</a>, known as <a href="/wiki/Plasma_(physics)" title="Plasma (physics)">plasma</a>, which do not emit much <a href="/wiki/Visible_light" class="mw-redirect" title="Visible light">visible light</a>, prominences contain much cooler plasma, similar in composition to that of the <a href="/wiki/Chromosphere" title="Chromosphere">chromosphere</a>. The prominence plasma is typically a hundred times more lit and denser than the coronal plasma. A prominence forms over timescales of about a day and may persist in the corona for several weeks or months, looping hundreds of thousands of miles into space. Some prominences break apart and may then give rise to <a href="/wiki/Coronal_mass_ejection" title="Coronal mass ejection">coronal mass ejections</a>. Scientists are currently researching how and why prominences are formed.</p> 
      <p>The red-glowing looped material is plasma, a hot gas composed of electrically charged hydrogen and helium. The prominence plasma flows along a tangled and twisted structure of magnetic fields generated by the sun’s internal dynamo. An erupting prominence occurs when such a structure becomes unstable and bursts outward, releasing the plasma.</p> 
      <p>A typical prominence extends over many thousands of kilometers; the largest on record was estimated at over 800,000 kilometres (500,000&nbsp;mi) long<sup id="cite_ref-univtoday_1-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-univtoday-1">[1]</a></sup> – roughly the radius of the Sun.</p> 
      <p></p> 
      <div id="toc" class="toc"> 
       <div class="toctitle" lang="en" dir="ltr" xml:lang="en"> 
        <h2>Contents</h2> 
       </div> 
       <ul> 
        <li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-1"><a href="#Historical"><span class="tocnumber">1</span> <span class="toctext">Historical</span></a></li> 
        <li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-2"><a href="#Prominences_and_Filaments"><span class="tocnumber">2</span> <span class="toctext">Prominences and Filaments</span></a></li> 
        <li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-3"><a href="#Videos"><span class="tocnumber">3</span> <span class="toctext">Videos</span></a></li> 
        <li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-4"><a href="#Gallery"><span class="tocnumber">4</span> <span class="toctext">Gallery</span></a></li> 
        <li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-5"><a href="#See_also"><span class="tocnumber">5</span> <span class="toctext">See also</span></a></li> 
        <li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-6"><a href="#References"><span class="tocnumber">6</span> <span class="toctext">References</span></a></li> 
        <li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-7"><a href="#Further_reading"><span class="tocnumber">7</span> <span class="toctext">Further reading</span></a></li> 
       </ul> 
      </div> 
      <p></p> 
      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Historical">Historical</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Solar_prominence&amp;action=edit&amp;section=1" title="Edit section: Historical">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2> 
      <p>The first detailed description of a solar prominence was in 14th-century <a href="/wiki/Laurentian_Codex" title="Laurentian Codex">Laurentian Codex</a>, describing the <a href="/wiki/Solar_eclipse_of_1_May_1185" title="Solar eclipse of 1 May 1185">Solar eclipse of 1 May 1185</a>. They were described as "flame-like tongues of live embers."<sup id="cite_ref-Montreal_2-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Montreal-2">[2]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Newsletter_3-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Newsletter-3">[3]</a></sup></p> 
      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Prominences_and_Filaments">Prominences and Filaments</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Solar_prominence&amp;action=edit&amp;section=2" title="Edit section: Prominences and Filaments">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2> 
      <p>When a prominence is viewed from a different perspective so that it is against the sun instead of against space, it appears darker than the surrounding background. This formation is instead called a solar filament.<sup id="cite_ref-univtoday_1-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-univtoday-1">[1]</a></sup> It is possible for a projection to be both a filament and a prominence. Some prominences are so powerful that they throw out matter from the Sun into space at speeds ranging from 600&nbsp;km/s to more than 1000&nbsp;km/s. Other prominences form huge loops or arching columns of glowing gases over sunspots that can reach heights of hundreds of thousands of kilometers. Prominences may last for a few days or even for a few months.<sup id="cite_ref-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-4">[4]</a></sup></p> 
      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Videos">Videos</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Solar_prominence&amp;action=edit&amp;section=3" title="Edit section: Videos">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2> 
      <ul class="gallery mw-gallery-traditional center"> 
       <li class="gallerybox" style="width: 195px">

         <div class="gallerytext"> 
          <p>An eclipse followed by an unusually large, dark prominence.</p> 
         </div>

          <p>On September 23, 2012 the sun emitted a large blast of plasma in the form of a prominence.</p>

type=&quot;video/webm; codecs=&amp;quot;vp8, vorbis&amp;quot;&quot; data-title=&quot;WebM (360P)&quot; data-shorttitle=&quot;WebM 360P&quot; data-transcodekey=&quot;360p.webm&quot; data-width=&quot;640&quot;             <img alt="File:Sun Shreds Its Own Eruption.webm" style="width:160px;height:90px" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cf/Sun_Shreds_Its_Own_Eruption.webm/160px--Sun_Shreds_Its_Own_Eruption.webm.jpg">
            <a href="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/c/cf/Sun_Shreds_Its_Own_Eruption.webm" title="Play media" target="new"><span class="play-btn-large"><span class="mw-tmh-playtext">Play media</span></span></a>
           </div> 
          </div> 
         </div> 
         <div class="gallerytext"> 
          <p>On September 30, 2014, multiple NASA observatories watched a filament rise, but instead of erupting from the Sun, the filament collapsed.</p> 
         </div> 
        </div> </li> 
      </ul> 
      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Gallery">Gallery</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Solar_prominence&amp;action=edit&amp;section=4" title="Edit section: Gallery">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>

      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Further_reading">Further reading</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Solar_prominence&amp;action=edit&amp;section=7" title="Edit section: Further reading">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2> 
      <ul> 
       <li><cite class="citation journal">Galsgaard, K.; Longbottom, A.W. (1999). "Formation of solar prominences by flux convergence". <i>Astrophysical Journal</i>. <b>510</b>: 444. <a href="/wiki/Bibcode" title="Bibcode">Bibcode</a>:<a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://adsabs.harvard.edu/abs/1999ApJ...510..444G">1999ApJ...510..444G</a>. <a href="/wiki/Digital_object_identifier" title="Digital object identifier">doi</a>:<a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="//doi.org/10.1086%2F306559">10.1086/306559</a>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Astrophysical+Journal&amp;rft.atitle=Formation+of+solar+prominences+by+flux+convergence&amp;rft.volume=510&amp;rft.pages=444&amp;rft.date=1999&amp;rft_id=info%3Adoi%2F10.1086%2F306559&amp;rft_id=info%3Abibcode%2F1999ApJ...510..444G&amp;rft.aulast=Galsgaard&amp;rft.aufirst=K.&amp;rft.au=Longbottom%2C+A.W.&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ASolar+prominence" class="Z3988"><span style="display:none;">&nbsp;</span></span></li> 
       <li><cite class="citation journal">Low, B.C.; Fong, B.; Fan, Y. (2003). "The mass of a solar quiescent prominence". <i>Astrophysical Journal</i>. <b>594</b> (2): 1060. <a href="/wiki/Bibcode" title="Bibcode">Bibcode</a>:<a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://adsabs.harvard.edu/abs/2003ApJ...594.1060L">2003ApJ...594.1060L</a>. <a href="/wiki/Digital_object_identifier" title="Digital object identifier">doi</a>:<a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="//doi.org/10.1086%2F377042">10.1086/377042</a>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Astrophysical+Journal&amp;rft.atitle=The+mass+of+a+solar+quiescent+prominence&amp;rft.volume=594&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.pages=1060&amp;rft.date=2003&amp;rft_id=info%3Adoi%2F10.1086%2F377042&amp;rft_id=info%3Abibcode%2F2003ApJ...594.1060L&amp;rft.aulast=Low&amp;rft.aufirst=B.C.&amp;rft.au=Fong%2C+B.&amp;rft.au=Fan%2C+Y.&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ASolar+prominence" class="Z3988"><span style="display:none;">&nbsp;</span></span></li> 
       <li><cite class="citation book">Golub, L.; Pasachoff J.M. (1997). <i>The Solar Corona</i>. <a href="/wiki/Cambridge_University_Press" title="Cambridge University Press">Cambridge University Press</a>. <a href="/wiki/International_Standard_Book_Number" title="International Standard Book Number">ISBN</a>&nbsp;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/0-521-48535-5" title="Special:BookSources/0-521-48535-5">0-521-48535-5</a>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=The+Solar+Corona&amp;rft.pub=Cambridge+University+Press&amp;rft.date=1997&amp;rft.isbn=0-521-48535-5&amp;rft.aulast=Golub&amp;rft.aufirst=L.&amp;rft.au=Pasachoff+J.M.&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ASolar+prominence" class="Z3988"><span style="display:none;">&nbsp;</span></span></li> 
       <li><cite class="citation book"><a href="/wiki/Einar_Tandberg-Hanssen" title="Einar Tandberg-Hanssen">Tandberg-Hanssen, Einar</a> (1995). <i>The Nature of Solar Prominences</i>. Dordrecht: Kluwer Acad. <a href="/wiki/International_Standard_Book_Number" title="International Standard Book Number">ISBN</a>&nbsp;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0792333746" title="Special:BookSources/978-0792333746">978-0792333746</a>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=The+Nature+of+Solar+Prominences&amp;rft.place=Dordrecht&amp;rft.pub=Kluwer+Acad.&amp;rft.date=1995&amp;rft.isbn=978-0792333746&amp;rft.aulast=Tandberg-Hanssen&amp;rft.aufirst=Einar&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ASolar+prominence" class="Z3988"><span style="display:none;">&nbsp;</span></span></li> 
      </ul> 
      <div role="navigation" class="navbox" aria-labelledby="The_Sun" style="padding:3px">

   <h1 id="firstHeading" class="firstHeading" lang="en">Corona</h1> 
   <div id="bodyContent" class="mw-body-content"> 
    <div id="siteSub" class="noprint">
     From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia
    </div> 
    <div id="contentSub"></div> 
    <div id="jump-to-nav" class="mw-jump">
      Jump to: 
     <a href="#mw-head">navigation</a>, 
     <a href="#p-search">search</a> 
    </div> 
    <div id="mw-content-text" lang="en" dir="ltr" class="mw-content-ltr">
     <div class="mw-parser-output">
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       This article is about the astronomical term. For other uses, see 
       <a href="/wiki/Corona_(disambiguation)" class="mw-disambig" title="Corona (disambiguation)">Corona (disambiguation)</a>.
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright"> 
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Solar_eclipse_1999_4_NR.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1c/Solar_eclipse_1999_4_NR.jpg/220px-Solar_eclipse_1999_4_NR.jpg" width="220" height="217" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1c/Solar_eclipse_1999_4_NR.jpg/330px-Solar_eclipse_1999_4_NR.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1c/Solar_eclipse_1999_4_NR.jpg/440px-Solar_eclipse_1999_4_NR.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3543" data-file-height="3489"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption"> 
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Solar_eclipse_1999_4_NR.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div> During a total 
         <a href="/wiki/Solar_eclipse" title="Solar eclipse">solar eclipse</a>, the Sun's corona and 
         <a href="/wiki/Solar_prominence" title="Solar prominence">prominences</a> are visible to the 
         <a href="/wiki/Naked_eye" title="Naked eye">naked eye</a>.
        </div> 
       </div> 
      </div> 
      <p>A <b>corona</b> (Latin, '<a href="/wiki/Crown_(headgear)" title="Crown (headgear)">crown</a>') is an aura of <a href="/wiki/Plasma_(physics)" title="Plasma (physics)">plasma</a> that surrounds the <a href="/wiki/Sun" title="Sun">Sun</a> and other <a href="/wiki/Star" title="Star">stars</a>. The Sun's corona extends millions of kilometres into space and is most easily seen during a total <a href="/wiki/Solar_eclipse" title="Solar eclipse">solar eclipse</a>, but it is also observable with a <a href="/wiki/Coronagraph" title="Coronagraph">coronagraph</a>. The word <i>corona</i> is a <a href="/wiki/Latin_language" class="mw-redirect" title="Latin language">Latin</a> word meaning "crown", from the <a href="/wiki/Ancient_Greek" title="Ancient Greek">Ancient Greek</a> ?????? (kor?nè, “garland, wreath”).</p> 
      <p>The high temperature of the Sun's corona gives it unusual <a href="/wiki/Spectroscopy" title="Spectroscopy">spectral</a> features, which led some in the 19th century to suggest that it contained a previously unknown element, "<a href="/wiki/Coronium" title="Coronium">coronium</a>". Instead, these spectral features have since been explained by <a href="/wiki/Highly_charged_ion" title="Highly charged ion">highly ionized</a> <a href="/wiki/Iron" title="Iron">iron</a> (Fe-XIV). <a href="/wiki/Bengt_Edl%C3%A9n" title="Bengt Edlén">Bengt Edlén</a>, following the work of Grotrian (1939), first identified the coronal spectral lines in 1940 (observed since 1869) as transitions from low-lying metastable levels of the ground configuration of highly ionised metals (the green Fe-XIV line at 5303&nbsp;Å, but also the red line Fe-X at 6374&nbsp;Å). These high stages of <a href="/wiki/Ionisation" class="mw-redirect" title="Ionisation">ionisation</a> indicate a plasma temperature in excess of 1,000,000 <a href="/wiki/Kelvin" title="Kelvin">kelvin</a>s,<sup id="cite_ref-Aschwanden_1-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Aschwanden-1">[1]</a></sup> much hotter than the surface of the sun.</p> 
      <p>Light from the corona comes from three primary sources, from the same volume of space. The K-corona (K&nbsp;for <i>kontinuierlich</i>, "continuous" in German) is created by sunlight <a href="/wiki/Scattering_(physics)" class="mw-redirect" title="Scattering (physics)">scattering</a> off free <a href="/wiki/Electron" title="Electron">electrons</a>; <a href="/wiki/Doppler_broadening" title="Doppler broadening">Doppler broadening</a> of the reflected photospheric <a href="/wiki/Absorption_line" class="mw-redirect" title="Absorption line">absorption lines</a> spreads them so greatly as to completely obscure them, giving the spectral appearance of a continuum with no absorption lines. The F-corona (F&nbsp;for <a href="/wiki/Joseph_von_Fraunhofer" title="Joseph von Fraunhofer">Fraunhofer</a>) is created by sunlight bouncing off dust particles, and is observable because its light contains the Fraunhofer absorption lines that are seen in raw sunlight; the F-corona extends to very high <a href="/wiki/Elongation_(astronomy)" title="Elongation (astronomy)">elongation</a> angles from the Sun, where it is called the <a href="/wiki/Zodiacal_light" title="Zodiacal light">zodiacal light</a>. The E-corona (E for emission) is due to spectral emission lines produced by ions that are present in the coronal plasma; it may be observed in broad or <a href="/wiki/Forbidden_line" class="mw-redirect" title="Forbidden line">forbidden</a> or hot <a href="/wiki/Spectral_line" title="Spectral line">spectral emission lines</a> and is the main source of information about the corona's composition.<sup id="cite_ref-Corfield_2-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Corfield-2">[2]</a></sup></p> 
      <p></p> 
      <div id="toc" class="toc"> 
       <div class="toctitle" lang="en" dir="ltr" xml:lang="en">
