      <p></p> 
      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Physical_features">Physical features</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Corona&amp;action=edit&amp;section=1" title="Edit section: Physical features">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2> 
      <div class="thumb tright"> 
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Twistedflux.png" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2a/Twistedflux.png/220px-Twistedflux.png" width="220" height="149" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2a/Twistedflux.png/330px-Twistedflux.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2a/Twistedflux.png/440px-Twistedflux.png 2x" data-file-width="541" data-file-height="367"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption"> 
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Twistedflux.png" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div> A drawing demonstrating the configuration of solar magnetic flux during the solar cycle
        </div> 
       </div> 
      </div> 
      <p>The sun's corona is much hotter (by a factor from 150 to 450) than the visible surface of the Sun: the <a href="/wiki/Photosphere" title="Photosphere">photosphere</a>'s average <a href="/wiki/Temperature" title="Temperature">temperature</a> is 5800 <a href="/wiki/Kelvin" title="Kelvin">kelvin</a>s compared to the corona's one to three million kelvins. The corona is 10<sup>?12</sup> times as dense as the photosphere, and so produces about one-millionth as much visible light. The corona is separated from the photosphere by the relatively shallow <a href="/wiki/Chromosphere" title="Chromosphere">chromosphere</a>. The exact mechanism by which the corona is heated is still the subject of some debate, but likely possibilities include induction by the Sun's <a href="/wiki/Magnetic_field" title="Magnetic field">magnetic field</a> and <a href="/wiki/Magnetohydrodynamics" title="Magnetohydrodynamics">magnetohydrodynamic waves</a> from below. The outer edges of the Sun's corona are constantly being transported away due to open magnetic flux and hence generating the <a href="/wiki/Solar_wind" title="Solar wind">solar wind</a>.</p> 
      <p>The corona is not always evenly distributed across the surface of the sun. During periods of quiet, the corona is more or less confined to the <a href="/wiki/Equator" title="Equator">equatorial</a> regions, with <a href="/wiki/Coronal_hole" title="Coronal hole">coronal holes</a> covering the <a href="/wiki/Geographical_pole" title="Geographical pole">polar</a> regions. However, during the Sun's active periods, the corona is evenly distributed over the equatorial and polar regions, though it is most prominent in areas with <a href="/wiki/Sunspot" title="Sunspot">sunspot</a> activity. The <a href="/wiki/Solar_cycle" title="Solar cycle">solar cycle</a> spans approximately 11 years, from <a href="/wiki/Solar_minimum" title="Solar minimum">solar minimum</a> to the following minimum. Since the solar magnetic field is continually wound up due to the faster rotation of mass at the sun's equator (<a href="/wiki/Differential_rotation" title="Differential rotation">differential rotation</a>), sunspot activity will be more pronounced at <a href="/wiki/Solar_maximum" title="Solar maximum">solar maximum</a> where the <a href="/wiki/Magnetic_field" title="Magnetic field">magnetic field</a> is more twisted. Associated with sunspots are <a href="/wiki/Coronal_loop" title="Coronal loop">coronal loops</a>, loops of <a href="/wiki/Magnetic_flux" title="Magnetic flux">magnetic flux</a>, upwelling from the solar interior. The magnetic flux pushes the hotter <a href="/wiki/Photosphere" title="Photosphere">photosphere</a> aside, exposing the cooler plasma below, thus creating the relatively dark sun spots.</p> 
      <p>Since the corona has been photographed at high resolution in the X-ray range of the spectrum by the satellite <a href="/wiki/Skylab" title="Skylab">Skylab</a> in 1973, and then later by <a href="/wiki/Yohkoh" title="Yohkoh">Yohkoh</a> and the other following space instruments, it has been seen that the structure of the corona is quite varied and complex: different zones have been immediately classified on the coronal disc.<sup id="cite_ref-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-3">[3]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-4">[4]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-5">[5]</a></sup> The astronomers usually distinguish several regions,<sup id="cite_ref-Gibson_6-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Gibson-6">[6]</a></sup> as described below.</p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Active_regions">Active regions</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Corona&amp;action=edit&amp;section=2" title="Edit section: Active regions">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3> 
      <p><b>Active regions</b> are ensembles of loop structures connecting points of opposite magnetic polarity in the photosphere, the so-called <a href="/wiki/Coronal_loops" class="mw-redirect" title="Coronal loops">coronal loops</a>. They generally distribute in two zones of activity, which are parallel to the solar equator. The average temperature is between two and four million kelvins, while the density goes from 10<sup>9</sup> to 10<sup>10</sup> particle per cm<sup>3</sup>.</p> 
      <div class="thumb tright"> 
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Prominence_(PSF).png" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/03/Prominence_%28PSF%29.png/220px-Prominence_%28PSF%29.png" width="220" height="88" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/03/Prominence_%28PSF%29.png/330px-Prominence_%28PSF%29.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/03/Prominence_%28PSF%29.png/440px-Prominence_%28PSF%29.png 2x" data-file-width="3636" data-file-height="1452"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption"> 
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Prominence_(PSF).png" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div> Illustration depicting 
         <a href="/wiki/Solar_prominences" class="mw-redirect" title="Solar prominences">solar prominences</a> and 
         <a href="/wiki/Sunspot" title="Sunspot">sunspots</a>
        </div> 
       </div> 
      </div> 
      <p>Active regions involve all the phenomena directly linked to the magnetic field, which occur at different heights above the Sun's surface:<sup id="cite_ref-Gibson_6-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Gibson-6">[6]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Sunspot" title="Sunspot">sunspots</a> and <a href="/wiki/Facula" title="Facula">faculae</a>, occur in the photosphere, <a href="/wiki/Spicule_(solar_physics)" title="Spicule (solar physics)">spicules</a>, <a href="/wiki/H%CE%B1" class="mw-redirect" title="H?">H?</a> <a href="/wiki/Solar_prominence" title="Solar prominence">filaments</a> and <a href="/wiki/Plage_(astronomy)" title="Plage (astronomy)">plages</a> in the chromosphere, <a href="/wiki/Solar_prominences" class="mw-redirect" title="Solar prominences">prominences</a> in the chromosphere and transition region, and <a href="/wiki/Solar_flare" title="Solar flare">flares</a> and <a href="/wiki/Coronal_mass_ejection" title="Coronal mass ejection">coronal mass ejections</a> happen in the corona and chromosphere. If flares are very violent, they can also perturb the photosphere and generate a <a href="/wiki/Moreton_wave" title="Moreton wave">Moreton wave</a>. On the contrary, quiescent prominences are large, cool dense structures which are observed as dark, "snake-like" H? ribbons (appearing like filaments) on the solar disc. Their temperature is about 5000–8000&nbsp;K, and so they are usually considered as chromospheric features.</p> 
      <p>In 2013, images from the <a href="/wiki/High_Resolution_Coronal_Imager" title="High Resolution Coronal Imager">High Resolution Coronal Imager</a> revealed never-before-seen "magnetic braids" of plasma within the outer layers of these active regions.<sup id="cite_ref-7" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-7">[7]</a></sup></p> 
      <h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Coronal_loops">Coronal loops</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Corona&amp;action=edit&amp;section=3" title="Edit section: Coronal loops">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h4> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: 
       <a href="/wiki/Coronal_loop" title="Coronal loop">Coronal loop</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tleft"> 
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Traceimage.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/93/Traceimage.jpg/220px-Traceimage.jpg" width="220" height="220" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/93/Traceimage.jpg/330px-Traceimage.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/93/Traceimage.jpg/440px-Traceimage.jpg 2x" data-file-width="768" data-file-height="768"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption"> 
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Traceimage.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div> TRACE 171Å coronal loops
        </div> 
       </div> 
      </div> 
      <p><a href="/wiki/Coronal_loop" title="Coronal loop">Coronal loops</a> are the basic structures of the magnetic solar corona. These loops are the closed-magnetic flux cousins of the open-magnetic flux that can be found in <a href="/wiki/Coronal_hole" title="Coronal hole">coronal hole</a> (polar) regions and the <a href="/wiki/Solar_wind" title="Solar wind">solar wind</a>. Loops of magnetic flux well-up from the solar body and fill with hot solar plasma.<sup id="cite_ref-8" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-8">[8]</a></sup> Due to the heightened magnetic activity in these coronal loop regions, coronal loops can often be the precursor to <a href="/wiki/Solar_flares" class="mw-redirect" title="Solar flares">solar flares</a> and <a href="/wiki/Coronal_mass_ejection" title="Coronal mass ejection">coronal mass ejections</a> (CMEs).</p> 
      <p>The Solar plasma that feed these structures is heated from under 6000 K to well over 10<sup>6</sup>&nbsp;K from the photosphere, through the transition region, and into the corona. Often, the solar plasma will fill these loops from one point and drain to another, called foot points (<a href="/wiki/Siphon" title="Siphon">siphon</a> flow due to a pressure difference,<sup id="cite_ref-9" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-9">[9]</a></sup> or asymmetric flow due to some other driver).</p> 
      <p>When the plasma rises from the foot points towards the loop top, as always occurs during the initial phase of a compact flare, it is defined as chromospheric <a href="/wiki/Evaporation" title="Evaporation">evaporation</a>. When the plasma rapidly cools and falls toward the photosphere, it is called chromospheric <a href="/wiki/Condensation" title="Condensation">condensation</a>. There may also be <a href="/wiki/Symmetric" class="mw-redirect" title="Symmetric">symmetric</a> flow from both loop foot points, causing a build-up of mass in the loop structure. The plasma may cool rapidly in this region (for a thermal instability), its dark <a href="/wiki/Solar_prominence" title="Solar prominence">filaments</a> obvious against the solar disk or <a href="/wiki/Solar_prominence" title="Solar prominence">prominences</a> off the <a href="/wiki/Limb_darkening" title="Limb darkening">Sun's limb</a>.</p> 
      <p>Coronal loops may have lifetimes in the order of seconds (in the case of flare events), minutes, hours or days. Where there is a balance in loop energy sources and sinks, coronal loops can last for long periods of time and are known as <i><a href="/wiki/Steady_state" title="Steady state">steady state</a></i> or <i><a href="https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/quiescent" class="extiw" title="wikt:quiescent">quiescent</a></i> coronal loops. (<a href="/wiki/File:Energyfig.png" title="File:Energyfig.png">example</a>).</p> 
      <p>Coronal loops are very important to our understanding of the current <i>coronal heating problem</i>. Coronal loops are highly radiating sources of plasma and are therefore easy to observe by instruments such as <i><a href="/wiki/TRACE" title="TRACE">TRACE</a></i>. An explanation of the coronal heating problem remains as these structures are being observed remotely, where many ambiguities are present (i.e. radiation contributions along the <a href="/wiki/Line-of-sight_propagation" title="Line-of-sight propagation">LOS</a>). <i><a href="/wiki/In-situ" class="mw-redirect" title="In-situ">In-situ</a></i> measurements are required before a definitive answer can be had, but due to the high plasma temperatures in the corona, <i>in-situ</i> measurements are, at present, impossible. The next mission of the NASA <a href="/wiki/Solar_Probe_Plus" class="mw-redirect" title="Solar Probe Plus">Solar Probe Plus</a> will approach the Sun very closely allowing more direct observations.</p> 
      <div class="thumb tright"> 
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Coronal_Hole_Magnetic_Field_Lines.svg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/09/Coronal_Hole_Magnetic_Field_Lines.svg/220px-Coronal_Hole_Magnetic_Field_Lines.svg.png" width="220" height="398" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/09/Coronal_Hole_Magnetic_Field_Lines.svg/330px-Coronal_Hole_Magnetic_Field_Lines.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/09/Coronal_Hole_Magnetic_Field_Lines.svg/440px-Coronal_Hole_Magnetic_Field_Lines.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="151" data-file-height="273"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption"> 
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Coronal_Hole_Magnetic_Field_Lines.svg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div> Coronal arches connecting regions of opposite magnetic polarity (A) and the unipolar magnetic field in the coronal hole (B)
        </div> 
       </div> 
      </div> 
      <h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Large-scale_structures">Large-scale structures</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Corona&amp;action=edit&amp;section=4" title="Edit section: Large-scale structures">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h4> 
      <p><b>Large-scale structures</b> are very long arcs which can cover over a quarter of the solar disk but contain plasma less dense than in the coronal loops of the active regions.</p> 
      <p>They were first detected in the June 8, 1968 flare observation during a rocket flight.<sup id="cite_ref-Giacconi_10-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Giacconi-10">[10]</a></sup></p> 
      <p>The large-scale structure of the corona changes over the 11-year <a href="/wiki/Solar_cycle" title="Solar cycle">solar cycle</a> and becomes particularly simple during the minimum period, when the magnetic field of the Sun is almost similar to a dipolar configuration (plus a quadrupolar component).</p> 
      <h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Interconnections_of_active_regions">Interconnections of active regions</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Corona&amp;action=edit&amp;section=5" title="Edit section: Interconnections of active regions">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h4> 
      <p>The <b>interconnections of active regions</b> are arcs connecting zones of opposite magnetic field, of different active regions. Significant variations of these structures are often seen after a flare.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (July 2016)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup></p> 
      <p>Some other features of this kind are <a href="/wiki/Helmet_streamer" title="Helmet streamer">helmet streamers</a>—large cap-like coronal structures with long pointed peaks that usually overlie sunspots and active regions. Coronal streamers are considered as sources of the slow <a href="/wiki/Solar_wind" title="Solar wind">solar wind</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-11" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-11">[11]</a></sup></p> 
      <h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Filament_cavities">Filament cavities</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Corona&amp;action=edit&amp;section=6" title="Edit section: Filament cavities">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h4> 
      <div class="thumb tleft"> 
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Crackling_with_Solar_Flares.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c6/Crackling_with_Solar_Flares.jpg/220px-Crackling_with_Solar_Flares.jpg" width="220" height="220" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c6/Crackling_with_Solar_Flares.jpg/330px-Crackling_with_Solar_Flares.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c6/Crackling_with_Solar_Flares.jpg/440px-Crackling_with_Solar_Flares.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2048" data-file-height="2048"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption"> 
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Crackling_with_Solar_Flares.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div> Image taken by the 
         <a href="/wiki/Solar_Dynamics_Observatory" title="Solar Dynamics Observatory">Solar Dynamics Observatory</a> on Oct 16 2010. A very long filament cavity is visible across the Sun's southern hemisphere.
        </div> 
       </div> 
      </div> 
      <p><b>Filament cavities</b> are zones which look dark in the X-rays and are above the regions where <a href="/wiki/H%CE%B1" class="mw-redirect" title="H?">H?</a> filaments are observed in the chromosphere. They were first observed in the two 1970 rocket flights which also detected <i>coronal holes</i>.<sup id="cite_ref-Giacconi_10-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Giacconi-10">[10]</a></sup></p> 
      <p>Filament cavities are cooler clouds of gases (plasma) suspended above the Sun's surface by magnetic forces. The regions of intense magnetic field look dark in images because they are empty of hot plasma. In fact, the sum of the <a href="/wiki/Magnetic_pressure" title="Magnetic pressure">magnetic pressure</a> and plasma pressure must be constant everywhere on the heliosphere in order to have an equilibrium configuration: where the magnetic field is higher, the plasma must be cooler or less dense. The plasma pressure <span class="mwe-math-element"><span class="mwe-math-mathml-inline mwe-math-mathml-a11y" style="display: none;">
         <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" alttext="{\displaystyle p}"> 
          <semantics> 
           <mrow class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD"> 
            <mstyle displaystyle="true" scriptlevel="0"> 
             <mi>
              p
             </mi> 
            </mstyle> 
           </mrow> 
           <annotation encoding="application/x-tex">
            {\displaystyle p}
           </annotation> 
          </semantics> 
         </math></span><img src="https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/81eac1e205430d1f40810df36a0edffdc367af36" class="mwe-math-fallback-image-inline" aria-hidden="true" style="vertical-align: -0.671ex; margin-left: -0.089ex; width:1.259ex; height:2.009ex;" alt="p"></span> can be calculated by the <a href="/wiki/State_equation" class="mw-redirect" title="State equation">state equation</a> of a perfect gas <span class="mwe-math-element"><span class="mwe-math-mathml-inline mwe-math-mathml-a11y" style="display: none;">
         <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" alttext="{\displaystyle p=nK_{B}T}"> 
          <semantics> 
           <mrow class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD"> 
            <mstyle displaystyle="true" scriptlevel="0"> 
             <mi>
              p
             </mi> 
             <mo>
              =
             </mo> 
             <mi>
              n
             </mi> 
             <msub> 
              <mi>
               K
              </mi> 
              <mrow class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD"> 
               <mi>
                B
               </mi> 
              </mrow> 
             </msub> 
             <mi>
              T
             </mi> 
            </mstyle> 
           </mrow> 
           <annotation encoding="application/x-tex">
            {\displaystyle p=nK_{B}T}
           </annotation> 
          </semantics> 
         </math></span><img src="https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/d5ca46d8dd7a2d075b38e1d039c28459a0c56716" class="mwe-math-fallback-image-inline" aria-hidden="true" style="vertical-align: -0.671ex; margin-left: -0.089ex; width:10.841ex; height:2.509ex;" alt="p=nK_{B}T"></span>, where <span class="mwe-math-element"><span class="mwe-math-mathml-inline mwe-math-mathml-a11y" style="display: none;">
         <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" alttext="{\displaystyle n}"> 
          <semantics> 
           <mrow class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD"> 
            <mstyle displaystyle="true" scriptlevel="0"> 
             <mi>
              n
             </mi> 
            </mstyle> 
           </mrow> 
           <annotation encoding="application/x-tex">
            {\displaystyle n}
           </annotation> 
          </semantics> 
         </math></span><img src="https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/a601995d55609f2d9f5e233e36fbe9ea26011b3b" class="mwe-math-fallback-image-inline" aria-hidden="true" style="vertical-align: -0.338ex; width:1.395ex; height:1.676ex;" alt="n"></span> is the <a href="/wiki/Particle_number_density" class="mw-redirect" title="Particle number density">particle number density</a>, <span class="mwe-math-element"><span class="mwe-math-mathml-inline mwe-math-mathml-a11y" style="display: none;">
         <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" alttext="{\displaystyle K_{B}}"> 
          <semantics> 
           <mrow class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD"> 
            <mstyle displaystyle="true" scriptlevel="0"> 
             <msub> 
              <mi>
               K
              </mi> 
              <mrow class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD"> 
               <mi>
                B
               </mi> 
              </mrow> 
             </msub> 
            </mstyle> 
           </mrow> 
           <annotation encoding="application/x-tex">
            {\displaystyle K_{B}}
           </annotation> 
          </semantics> 
         </math></span><img src="https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/041770ed83382d595875532cc29acd938c39a74b" class="mwe-math-fallback-image-inline" aria-hidden="true" style="vertical-align: -0.671ex; width:3.453ex; height:2.509ex;" alt="K_{B}"></span> the <a href="/wiki/Boltzmann_constant" title="Boltzmann constant">Boltzmann constant</a> and <span class="mwe-math-element"><span class="mwe-math-mathml-inline mwe-math-mathml-a11y" style="display: none;">
         <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" alttext="{\displaystyle T}"> 
          <semantics> 
           <mrow class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD"> 
            <mstyle displaystyle="true" scriptlevel="0"> 
             <mi>
              T
             </mi> 
            </mstyle> 
           </mrow> 
           <annotation encoding="application/x-tex">
            {\displaystyle T}
           </annotation> 
          </semantics> 
         </math></span><img src="https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/ec7200acd984a1d3a3d7dc455e262fbe54f7f6e0" class="mwe-math-fallback-image-inline" aria-hidden="true" style="vertical-align: -0.338ex; width:1.636ex; height:2.176ex;" alt="T"></span> the plasma temperature. It is evident from the equation that the plasma pressure lowers when the plasma temperature decreases with respect to the surrounding regions or when the zone of intense magnetic field empties. The same physical effect renders <a href="/wiki/Sunspot" title="Sunspot">sunspots</a> apparently dark in the <a href="/wiki/Photosphere" title="Photosphere">photosphere</a>.</p> 
      <h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Bright_points">Bright points</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Corona&amp;action=edit&amp;section=7" title="Edit section: Bright points">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h4> 
      <p><b>Bright points</b> are small active regions found on the solar disk. X-ray bright points were first detected on April 8, 1969 during a rocket flight.<sup id="cite_ref-Giacconi_10-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Giacconi-10">[10]</a></sup></p> 
      <p>The fraction of the solar surface covered by bright points varies with the <a href="/wiki/Solar_cycle" title="Solar cycle">solar cycle</a>. They are associated with small bipolar regions of the magnetic field. Their average temperature ranges from 1.1x10<sup>6</sup> K to 3.4x10<sup>6</sup> K. The variations in temperature are often correlated with changes in the X-ray emission.<sup id="cite_ref-12" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-12">[12]</a></sup></p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Coronal_holes">Coronal holes</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Corona&amp;action=edit&amp;section=8" title="Edit section: Coronal holes">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: 
       <a href="/wiki/Coronal_hole" title="Coronal hole">Coronal hole</a>
      </div> 
      <p><b><a href="/wiki/Coronal_hole" title="Coronal hole">Coronal holes</a></b> are the Polar Regions which look dark in the X-rays since they do not emit much radiation.<sup id="cite_ref-13" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-13">[13]</a></sup> These are wide zones of the Sun where the magnetic field is unipolar and opens towards the interplanetary space. The high speed <a href="/wiki/Solar_wind" title="Solar wind">solar wind</a> arises mainly from these regions.</p> 
      <p>In the UV images of the coronal holes, some small structures, similar to elongated bubbles, are often seen as they were suspended in the solar wind. These are the coronal <b>plumes</b>. More exactly, they are long thin streamers that project outward from the Sun's north and south poles.<sup id="cite_ref-14" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-14">[14]</a></sup></p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="The_quiet_Sun">The quiet Sun</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Corona&amp;action=edit&amp;section=9" title="Edit section: The quiet Sun">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3> 
      <p>The solar regions which are not part of active regions and coronal holes are commonly identified as the <b>quiet Sun</b>.</p> 
      <p>The equatorial region has a faster rotation speed than the polar zones. The result of the Sun's differential rotation is that the active regions always arise in two bands parallel to the equator and their extension increases during the periods of maximum of the <a href="/wiki/Solar_cycle" title="Solar cycle">solar cycle</a>, while they almost disappear during each minimum. Therefore, the quiet Sun always coincides with the equatorial zone and its surface is less active during the maximum of the solar cycle. Approaching the minimum of the solar cycle (also named butterfly cycle), the extension of the quiet Sun increases until it covers the whole disk surface excluding some bright points on the hemisphere and the poles, where there are the coronal holes.</p> 
      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Variability_of_the_corona">Variability of the corona</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Corona&amp;action=edit&amp;section=10" title="Edit section: Variability of the corona">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2> 
      <p>A portrait as diversified as the one already pointed out for the coronal features is emphasized by the analysis of the dynamics of the main structures of the corona, which evolve in times very different among them. Studying the coronal variability in its complexity is not easy because the times of evolution of the different structures can vary considerably: from seconds to several months. The typical sizes of the regions where coronal events take place vary in the same way, as it is shown in the following table.</p> 
      <table class="wikitable" title="Typical length of observable coronal features"> 
       <tbody>
        <tr> 
         <th><b>Coronal event</b></th> 
         <th><b>Typical time-scale</b></th> 
         <th><b>Typical length-scale (Mm)</b></th> 
        </tr> 
        <tr> 
         <td>Active region <a href="/wiki/Solar_flare" title="Solar flare">flare</a></td> 
         <td>10 to 10,000 seconds</td> 
         <td>10–100</td> 
        </tr> 
        <tr> 
         <td>X-ray bright point</td> 
         <td>minutes</td> 
         <td>1–10</td> 
        </tr> 
        <tr> 
         <td>Transient in large-scale structures</td> 
         <td>from minutes to hours</td> 
         <td>~100</td> 
        </tr> 
        <tr> 
         <td>Transient in interconnecting arcs</td> 
         <td>from minutes to hours</td> 
         <td>~100</td> 
        </tr> 
        <tr> 
         <td>Quiet Sun</td> 
         <td>from hours to months</td> 
         <td>100–1,000</td> 
        </tr> 
        <tr> 
         <td><a href="/wiki/Coronal_hole" title="Coronal hole">Coronal hole</a></td> 
         <td>several rotations</td> 
         <td>100–1,000</td> 
        </tr> 
       </tbody>
      </table> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Flares">Flares</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Corona&amp;action=edit&amp;section=11" title="Edit section: Flares">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: 
       <a href="/wiki/Solar_flares" class="mw-redirect" title="Solar flares">Solar flares</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright"> 
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Magnificent_CME_Erupts_on_the_Sun_-_August_31.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e3/Magnificent_CME_Erupts_on_the_Sun_-_August_31.jpg/220px-Magnificent_CME_Erupts_on_the_Sun_-_August_31.jpg" width="220" height="124" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e3/Magnificent_CME_Erupts_on_the_Sun_-_August_31.jpg/330px-Magnificent_CME_Erupts_on_the_Sun_-_August_31.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e3/Magnificent_CME_Erupts_on_the_Sun_-_August_31.jpg/440px-Magnificent_CME_Erupts_on_the_Sun_-_August_31.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1920" data-file-height="1080"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption"> 
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Magnificent_CME_Erupts_on_the_Sun_-_August_31.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div> On August 31, 2012 a long filament of solar material that had been hovering in the Sun's outer atmosphere, the corona, erupted at 4:36 p.m. EDT
        </div> 
       </div> 
      </div> 
      <p>Flares take place in active regions and are characterized by a sudden increase of the radiative flux emitted from small regions of the corona. They are very complex phenomena, visible at different wavelengths; they involve several zones of the solar atmosphere and many physical effects, thermal and not thermal, and sometimes wide reconnections of the magnetic field lines with material expulsion.</p> 
      <p>Flares are impulsive phenomena, of average duration of 15 minutes, and the most energetic events can last several hours. Flares produce a high and rapid increase of the density and temperature.</p> 
      <p>An emission in white light is only seldom observed: usually, flares are only seen at extreme UV wavelengths and into the X-rays, typical of the chromospheric and coronal emission.</p> 
      <p>In the corona, the morphology of flares, is described by observations in the UV, soft and hard X-rays, and in <a href="/wiki/H%CE%B1" class="mw-redirect" title="H?">H?</a> wavelengths, and is very complex. However, two kinds of basic structures can be distinguished: <sup id="cite_ref-15" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-15">[15]</a></sup></p> 
      <ul> 
       <li><b>Compact flares</b>, when each of the two arches where the event is happening maintains its morphology: only an increase of the emission is observed without significant structural variations. The emitted energy is of the order of 10<sup>22</sup>&nbsp;– 10<sup>23</sup> J.</li> 
       <li><b>Flares of long duration</b>, associated with eruptions of <a href="/wiki/Solar_prominence" title="Solar prominence">prominences</a>, transients in white light and <i>two-ribbon flares</i>:<sup id="cite_ref-16" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-16">[16]</a></sup> in this case the magnetic loops change their configuration during the event. The energies emitted during these flares are of such great proportion they can reach 10<sup>25</sup> J.</li> 
      </ul> 
      <div class="thumb tright"> 
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Solar-filament.gif" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b4/Solar-filament.gif/220px-Solar-filament.gif" width="220" height="157" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b4/Solar-filament.gif/330px-Solar-filament.gif 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b4/Solar-filament.gif/440px-Solar-filament.gif 2x" data-file-width="669" data-file-height="478"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption"> 
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Solar-filament.gif" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div> Filament erupting during a solar flare, seen at EUV wavelengths (
         <a href="/wiki/TRACE" title="TRACE">TRACE</a>)
        </div> 
       </div> 
      </div> 
      <p>As for temporal dynamics, three different phases are generally distinguished, whose duration are not comparable. The durations of those periods depend on the range of wavelengths used to observe the event:</p> 
      <ul> 
       <li><b>An initial impulsive phase</b>, whose duration is on the order of minutes, strong emissions of energy are often observed even in the microwaves, EUV wavelengths and in the hard X-ray frequencies.</li> 
       <li><b>A maximum phase</b></li> 
       <li><b>A decay phase</b>, which can last several hours.</li> 
      </ul> 
      <p>Sometimes also a phase preceding the flare can be observed, usually called as "pre-flare" phase.</p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Transients">Transients</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Corona&amp;action=edit&amp;section=12" title="Edit section: Transients">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: 
       <a href="/wiki/Coronal_mass_ejection" title="Coronal mass ejection">Coronal mass ejection</a>
      </div> 
      <p>Accompanying <a href="/wiki/Solar_flare" title="Solar flare">solar flares</a> or large <a href="/wiki/Solar_prominence" title="Solar prominence">solar prominences</a>, <b>"coronal transients"</b> (also called <a href="/wiki/Coronal_mass_ejection" title="Coronal mass ejection">coronal mass ejections</a>) are sometimes released. These are enormous loops of coronal material that travel outward from the Sun at over a million kilometers per hour, containing roughly 10 times the energy of the solar flare or prominence that accompanies them. Some larger ejections can propel hundreds of millions of tons of material into <a href="/wiki/Space" title="Space">space</a> at roughly 1.5 million kilometers an hour.</p> 
      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Stellar_coronae">Stellar coronae</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Corona&amp;action=edit&amp;section=13" title="Edit section: Stellar coronae">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2> 
      <p>Coronal stars are ubiquitous among the <a href="/wiki/Star" title="Star">stars</a> in the cool half of the <a href="/wiki/Hertzsprung%E2%80%93Russell_diagram" title="Hertzsprung–Russell diagram">Hertzsprung–Russell diagram</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Gudel_17-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Gudel-17">[17]</a></sup> These coronae can be detected using <a href="/wiki/X-ray_telescope" title="X-ray telescope">X-ray telescopes</a>. Some stellar coronae, particularly in young stars, are much more luminous than the Sun's. For example, <a href="/wiki/FK_Comae_Berenices" title="FK Comae Berenices">FK Comae Berenices</a> is the prototype for the <a href="/wiki/Variable_star" title="Variable star">FK Com</a> class of <a href="/wiki/Variable_star" title="Variable star">variable star</a>. These are giants of spectral types G and K with an unusually rapid rotation and signs of extreme activity. Their X-ray coronae are among the most luminous (<i>L</i><sub>x</sub> ? 10<sup>32</sup> erg·s<sup>?1</sup> or 10<sup>25</sup>W) and the hottest known with dominant temperatures up to 40 MK.<sup id="cite_ref-Gudel_17-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Gudel-17">[17]</a></sup></p> 
      <p>The astronomical observations planned with the <a href="/wiki/Einstein_Observatory" title="Einstein Observatory">Einstein Observatory</a> by Giuseppe Vaiana and his group<sup id="cite_ref-Vaianaetal81_18-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Vaianaetal81-18">[18]</a></sup> showed that F-, G-, K- and M-stars have chromospheres and often coronae much like our Sun. The <i>O-B stars</i>, which do not have surface convection zones, have a strong X-ray emission. However these stars do not have coronae, but the outer stellar envelopes emit this radiation during shocks due to thermal instabilities in rapidly moving gas blobs. Also A-stars do not have convection zones but they do not emit at the UV and X-ray wavelengths. Thus they appear to have neither chromospheres nor coronae.</p> 
      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Physics_of_the_corona">Physics of the corona</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Corona&amp;action=edit&amp;section=14" title="Edit section: Physics of the corona">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2> 
      <div class="thumb tleft"> 
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:171879main_LimbFlareJan12_lg.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/da/171879main_LimbFlareJan12_lg.jpg/220px-171879main_LimbFlareJan12_lg.jpg" width="220" height="154" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/da/171879main_LimbFlareJan12_lg.jpg/330px-171879main_LimbFlareJan12_lg.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/da/171879main_LimbFlareJan12_lg.jpg/440px-171879main_LimbFlareJan12_lg.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1014" data-file-height="712"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption"> 
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:171879main_LimbFlareJan12_lg.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div> This image, taken by 
         <a href="/wiki/Hinode" title="Hinode">Hinode</a> on 12 January 2007, reveals the filamentary nature of the corona.
        </div> 
       </div> 
      </div> 
      <p>The matter in the external part of the solar atmosphere is in the state of <a href="/wiki/Plasma_(physics)" title="Plasma (physics)">plasma</a>, at very high temperature (a few million kelvins) and at very low density (of the order of 10<sup>15</sup> particles/m<sup>3</sup>). According to the definition of plasma, it is a quasi-neutral ensemble of particles which exhibits a collective behaviour.</p> 
      <p>The composition is the same as the one in the Sun's interior, mainly hydrogen, but completely ionized, thence protons and electrons, and a small fraction of the other atoms in the same percentages as they are present in the photosphere. Heavier metals, such as iron, are partially ionized and have lost most of the external electrons. The ionization state of a chemical element depends strictly on the temperature and is regulated by the <a href="/wiki/Saha_equation" class="mw-redirect" title="Saha equation">Saha equation</a>. Historically, the presence of the spectral lines emitted from highly ionized states of iron allowed determination of the high temperature of the coronal plasma, revealing that the corona is much hotter than the internal layers of the chromosphere.</p> 
      <p>The corona behaves like a gas which is very hot but very light at the same time: the pressure in the corona is usually only 0.1 to 0.6 Pa in active regions, while on the Earth the atmospheric pressure is about 100 kPa, approximately a million times higher than on the solar surface. However it is not properly a gas, because it is made of charged particles, basically protons and electrons, moving at different velocities. Supposing that they have the same kinetic energy on average (for the <a href="/wiki/Equipartition_theorem" title="Equipartition theorem">equipartition theorem</a>), electrons have a mass roughly 1800 times smaller than protons, therefore they acquire more velocity. Metal ions are always slower. This fact has relevant physical consequences either on radiative processes (that are very different from the photospheric radiative processes), or on thermal conduction. Furthermore, the presence of electric charges induces the generation of electric currents and high magnetic fields. Magnetohydrodynamic waves (MHD waves) can also propagate in this plasma,<sup id="cite_ref-Jeffrey_19-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Jeffrey-19">[19]</a></sup> even if it is not still clear how they can be transmitted or generated in the corona.</p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Radiation">Radiation</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Corona&amp;action=edit&amp;section=15" title="Edit section: Radiation">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: 
       <a href="/wiki/Coronal_radiative_losses" title="Coronal radiative losses">Coronal radiative losses</a>
      </div> 
      <p>The corona emits radiation mainly in the X-rays, observable only from space.</p> 
      <p>The plasma is transparent to its own radiation and to that one coming from below, therefore we say that it is <b>optically-thin</b>. The gas, in fact, is very rarefied and the photon mean free-path overcomes by far all the other length-scales, including the typical sizes of the coronal features.</p> 
      <p>Different processes of radiation take place in the emission, due to binary collisions between plasma particles, while the interactions with the photons, coming from below; are very rare. Because the emission is due to collisions between ions and electrons, the energy emitted from a unit volume in the time unit is proportional to the squared number of particles in a unit volume, or more exactly, to the product of the electron density and proton density.<sup id="cite_ref-20" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-20">[20]</a></sup></p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Thermal_conduction">Thermal conduction</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Corona&amp;action=edit&amp;section=16" title="Edit section: Thermal conduction">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3> 
      <div class="thumb tright"> 
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:STEREO-A_first_images.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c8/STEREO-A_first_images.jpg/220px-STEREO-A_first_images.jpg" width="220" height="220" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c8/STEREO-A_first_images.jpg/330px-STEREO-A_first_images.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c8/STEREO-A_first_images.jpg/440px-STEREO-A_first_images.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2700" data-file-height="2700"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption"> 
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:STEREO-A_first_images.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div> A mosaic of the extreme ultraviolet images taken from 
         <a href="/wiki/STEREO" title="STEREO">STEREO</a> on December 4, 2006. These false color images show the Sun's atmospheres at a range of different temperatures. Clockwise from top left: 1 million degrees C (171 Å—blue), 1.5 million °C (195 Å—green), 60,000–80,000 °C (304 Å—red), and 2.5 million °C (286 Å—yellow).
        </div> 
       </div> 
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright"> 
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:STEREO-A_first_images_slow_anim.gif" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e3/STEREO-A_first_images_slow_anim.gif/220px-STEREO-A_first_images_slow_anim.gif" width="220" height="219" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e3/STEREO-A_first_images_slow_anim.gif/330px-STEREO-A_first_images_slow_anim.gif 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e3/STEREO-A_first_images_slow_anim.gif/440px-STEREO-A_first_images_slow_anim.gif 2x" data-file-width="1423" data-file-height="1418"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption"> 
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:STEREO-A_first_images_slow_anim.gif" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div> 
         <a href="/wiki/STEREO" title="STEREO">STEREO</a>&nbsp;– First images as a slow animation
        </div> 
       </div> 
      </div> 
      <p>In the corona <a href="/wiki/Thermal_conduction" title="Thermal conduction">thermal conduction</a> occurs from the external hotter atmosphere towards the inner cooler layers. Responsible for the diffusion process of the heat are the electrons, which are much lighter than ions and move faster, as explained above.</p> 
      <p>When there is a magnetic field the <a href="/wiki/Thermal_conductivity" title="Thermal conductivity">thermal conductivity</a> of the plasma becomes higher in the direction which is parallel to the field lines rather than in the perpendicular direction.<sup id="cite_ref-Spitzer_21-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Spitzer-21">[21]</a></sup> A charged particle moving in the direction perpendicular to the magnetic field line is subject to the <a href="/wiki/Lorentz_force" title="Lorentz force">Lorentz force</a> which is normal to the plane individuated by the velocity and the magnetic field. This force bends the path of the particle. In general, since particles also have a velocity component along the magnetic field line, the <a href="/wiki/Lorentz_force" title="Lorentz force">Lorentz force</a> constrains them to bend and move along spirals around the field lines at the <a href="/wiki/Cyclotron" title="Cyclotron">cyclotron</a> frequency.</p> 
      <p>If collisions between the particles are very frequent, they are scattered in every direction. This happens in the photosphere, where the plasma carries the magnetic field in its motion. In the corona, on the contrary, the mean free-path of the electrons is of the order of kilometres and even more, so each electron can do a helicoidal motion long before being scattered after a collision. Therefore, the heat transfer is enhanced along the magnetic field lines and inhibited in the perpendicular direction.</p> 
      <p>In the direction longitudinal to the magnetic field, the <a href="/wiki/Thermal_conductivity" title="Thermal conductivity">thermal conductivity</a> of the corona is<sup id="cite_ref-Spitzer_21-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Spitzer-21">[21]</a></sup></p> 
      <p><span class="mwe-math-element"><span class="mwe-math-mathml-inline mwe-math-mathml-a11y" style="display: none;">
         <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" alttext="{\displaystyle k=20\left({\frac {2}{\pi }}\right)^{3/2}{\frac {\left(k_{B}T\right)^{5/2}k_{B}}{m_{e}^{1/2}e^{4}\ln \Lambda }}\approx 1.8~10^{-10}~{\frac {T^{5/2}}{\ln \Lambda }}~Wm^{-1}K^{-1}}">

      <p>the Coulomb logarithm, and</p> 
      <p><span class="mwe-math-element"><span class="mwe-math-mathml-inline mwe-math-mathml-a11y" style="display: none;">
         <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" alttext="{\displaystyle \lambda _{D}={\sqrt {\frac {k_{B}T}{4\pi ne^{2}}}}}">

      <p>the <a href="/wiki/Debye_length" title="Debye length">Debye length</a> of the plasma with particle density <span class="mwe-math-element"><span class="mwe-math-mathml-inline mwe-math-mathml-a11y" style="display: none;">
         <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" alttext="{\displaystyle n}"> 
          <semantics> 
           <mrow class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD"> 
            <mstyle displaystyle="true" scriptlevel="0">

             </mi> 
            </mstyle> 
           </mrow> 
           <annotation encoding="application/x-tex">
            {\displaystyle n}
           </annotation> 
          </semantics> 
         </math></span><img src="https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/a601995d55609f2d9f5e233e36fbe9ea26011b3b" class="mwe-math-fallback-image-inline" aria-hidden="true" style="vertical-align: -0.338ex; width:1.395ex; height:1.676ex;" alt="n"></span>. The Coulomb logarithm <span class="mwe-math-element"><span class="mwe-math-mathml-inline mwe-math-mathml-a11y" style="display: none;">
         <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" alttext="{\displaystyle \ln \Lambda }"> 
          <semantics> 
           <mrow class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD"> 
            <mstyle displaystyle="true" scriptlevel="0"> 
             <mi>
              ln
             </mi> 
             <mo>
              ?
              <!-- ? -->
             </mo> 
             <mi mathvariant="normal">
              ?
              <!-- ? -->
             </mi> 
            </mstyle> 
           </mrow> 
           <annotation encoding="application/x-tex">
            {\displaystyle \ln \Lambda }
           </annotation> 
          </semantics> 
         </math></span><img src="https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/28b8691dd99b06547958f2cf02eed02fdb8744e0" class="mwe-math-fallback-image-inline" aria-hidden="true" style="vertical-align: -0.338ex; width:3.939ex; height:2.176ex;" alt="\ln \Lambda "></span> is roughly 20 in the corona, with a mean temperature of 1 MK and a density of 10<sup>15</sup> particles/m<sup>3</sup>, and about 10 in the chromosphere, where the temperature is approximately 10kK and the particle density is of the order of 10<sup>18</sup> particles/m<sup>3</sup>, and in practice it can be assumed constant.</p> 
      <p>Thence, if we indicate with <span class="mwe-math-element"><span class="mwe-math-mathml-inline mwe-math-mathml-a11y" style="display: none;">
         <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" alttext="{\displaystyle q}"> 
          <semantics> 
           <mrow class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD"> 
            <mstyle displaystyle="true" scriptlevel="0"> 
             <mi>
              q
             </mi> 
            </mstyle> 
           </mrow> 
           <annotation encoding="application/x-tex">
            {\displaystyle q}
           </annotation> 
          </semantics> 
         </math></span><img src="https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/06809d64fa7c817ffc7e323f85997f783dbdf71d" class="mwe-math-fallback-image-inline" aria-hidden="true" style="vertical-align: -0.671ex; width:1.07ex; height:2.009ex;" alt="q"></span> the heat for a volume unit, expressed in J m<sup>?3</sup>, the Fourier equation of heat transfer, to be computed only along the direction <span class="mwe-math-element"><span class="mwe-math-mathml-inline mwe-math-mathml-a11y" style="display: none;">
         <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" alttext="{\displaystyle x}"> 
          <semantics> 
           <mrow class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD"> 
            <mstyle displaystyle="true" scriptlevel="0"> 
             <mi>
              x
             </mi> 
            </mstyle> 
           </mrow> 
           <annotation encoding="application/x-tex">
            {\displaystyle x}
           </annotation> 
          </semantics> 
         </math></span><img src="https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/87f9e315fd7e2ba406057a97300593c4802b53e4" class="mwe-math-fallback-image-inline" aria-hidden="true" style="vertical-align: -0.338ex; width:1.33ex; height:1.676ex;" alt="x"></span> of the field line, becomes</p> 
      <p><span class="mwe-math-element"><span class="mwe-math-mathml-inline mwe-math-mathml-a11y" style="display: none;">
         <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" alttext="{\displaystyle {\frac {\partial q}{\partial t}}=0.9~10^{-11}~{\frac {\partial ^{2}T^{7/2}}{\partial x^{2}}}}"> 
          <semantics> 
           <mrow class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD"> 
            <mstyle displaystyle="true" scriptlevel="0"> 
             <mrow class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">

                </mi>

                </mi>

             </mo>

              0.9

             </mtext>

              </mn> 
              <mrow class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">

                <!-- ? -->
               </mo>

               </mn> 
              </mrow> 
             </msup> 
             <mtext>
              &nbsp;
             </mtext> 
             <mrow class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD"> 
              <mfrac>

                 </mi>

                  </mn> 
                  <mrow class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">

                  </mn>

                </mi>

                  </mn>

           </mrow> 
           <annotation encoding="application/x-tex">
            {\displaystyle {\frac {\partial q}{\partial t}}=0.9~10^{-11}~{\frac {\partial ^{2}T^{7/2}}{\partial x^{2}}}}
           </annotation> 
          </semantics> 
         </math></span><img src="https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/fe8073f9da413b7ee59f46082fed0fa24ed06455" class="mwe-math-fallback-image-inline" aria-hidden="true" style="vertical-align: -2.171ex; width:23.587ex; height:6.009ex;" alt="{\frac {\partial q}{\partial t}}=0.9~10^{-11}~{\frac {\partial ^{2}T^{7/2}}{\partial x^{2}}}"></span>.</p> 
      <p>Numerical calculations have shown that the thermal conductivity of the corona is comparable to that of copper.</p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Coronal_seismology">Coronal seismology</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Corona&amp;action=edit&amp;section=17" title="Edit section: Coronal seismology">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: 
       <a href="/wiki/Coronal_seismology" title="Coronal seismology">Coronal seismology</a>
      </div> 
      <p><b>Coronal seismology</b> is a new way of studying the <a href="/wiki/Plasma_(physics)" title="Plasma (physics)">plasma</a> of the solar corona with the use of <a href="/wiki/Magnetohydrodynamics" title="Magnetohydrodynamics">magnetohydrodynamic</a> (MHD) waves. Magnetohydrodynamics studies the <a href="/wiki/Dynamics_(mechanics)" title="Dynamics (mechanics)">dynamics</a> of <a href="/wiki/Electrical_conduction" class="mw-redirect" title="Electrical conduction">electrically conducting</a> <a href="/wiki/Fluid" title="Fluid">fluids</a>—in this case the fluid is the coronal plasma. Philosophically, coronal seismology is similar to the Earth's <a href="/wiki/Seismology" title="Seismology">seismology</a>, the Sun's <a href="/wiki/Helioseismology" title="Helioseismology">helioseismology</a>, and MHD spectroscopy of laboratory plasma devices. In all these approaches, waves of various kinds are used to probe a medium. The potential of coronal seismology in the estimation of the coronal magnetic field, density <a href="/wiki/Scale_height" title="Scale height">scale height</a>, <a href="/wiki/Fine_structure" title="Fine structure">fine structure</a> and heating has been demonstrated by different research groups.</p> 
      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Coronal_heating_problem">Coronal heating problem</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Corona&amp;action=edit&amp;section=18" title="Edit section: Coronal heating problem">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2> 
      <table style="float:right; width:30%; margin:0em 1em 1em 1em; background:#eee; border:#ccc solid"> 
       <tbody>
        <tr> 
         <td><a href="/wiki/File:Question_dropshade.png" class="image"><img alt="Question dropshade.png" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/dd/Question_dropshade.png/20px-Question_dropshade.png" width="20" height="20" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/dd/Question_dropshade.png/30px-Question_dropshade.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/dd/Question_dropshade.png/40px-Question_dropshade.png 2x" data-file-width="50" data-file-height="50"></a></td> 
         <td><b>Unsolved problem in physics</b>:<br> 
          <div style="padding:5px">
           <i>Why is the Sun's corona so much hotter than the Sun's surface?</i>
           <br> 
           <small><a href="/wiki/List_of_unsolved_problems_in_physics" title="List of unsolved problems in physics">(more unsolved problems in physics)</a></small>
          </div> </td> 
        </tr> 
       </tbody>
      </table> 
      <div class="thumb tright"> 
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"> 
        <div id="mwe_player_0" class="PopUpMediaTransform" style="width:220px;" videopayload="<div class=&quot;mediaContainer&quot; style=&quot;width:854px&quot;><video id=&quot;mwe_player_1&quot; poster=&quot;//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b6/Van_Gogh_Sun.ogv/854px--Van_Gogh_Sun.ogv.jpg&quot; data-height=&quot;720&quot; data-bandwidth=&quot;1933128&quot; data-framerate=&quot;30&quot;/><source src=&quot;//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/b/b6/Van_Gogh_Sun.ogv&quot; type=&quot;video/ogg; codecs=&amp;quot;vp8, vorbis&amp;quot;&quot; data-title=&quot;Low bandwidth WebM (160P)&quot; data-shorttitle=&quot;WebM 160P&quot; data-transcodekey=&quot;160p.webm&quot; data-width=&quot;284&quot; data-height=&quot;160&quot; data-bandwidth=&quot;218552&quot; data-framerate=&quot;30&quot;/><source src=&quot;//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/transcoded/b/b6/Van_Gogh_Sun.ogv/Van_Gogh_Sun.ogv.240p.webm&quot; type=&quot;video/webm;
