data-bandwidth=&quot;564632&quot; data-framerate=&quot;30&quot;/></video></div>">
         <img alt="File:Van Gogh Sun.ogv" style="width:220px;height:124px" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b6/Van_Gogh_Sun.ogv/220px--Van_Gogh_Sun.ogv.jpg">
         <a href="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/b/b6/Van_Gogh_Sun.ogv" title="Play media" target="new"><span class="play-btn-large"><span class="mw-tmh-playtext">Play media</span></span></a>
        </div> 
        <div class="thumbcaption"> 
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Van_Gogh_Sun.ogv" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div> A new visualisation technique can provide clues to the coronal heating problem.
        </div> 
       </div> 
      </div> 
      <p>The coronal heating problem in <a href="/wiki/Solar_physics" title="Solar physics">solar physics</a> relates to the question of why the temperature of the Sun's corona is millions of kelvins higher than that of the surface. The high temperatures require energy to be carried from the solar interior to the corona by non-thermal processes, because the <a href="/wiki/Second_law_of_thermodynamics" title="Second law of thermodynamics">second law of thermodynamics</a> prevents heat from flowing directly from the solar photosphere (surface), which is at about 5800 K, to the much hotter corona at about 1 to 3 <a href="/wiki/SI_prefix" class="mw-redirect" title="SI prefix">MK</a> (parts of the corona can even reach 10 MK).</p> 
      <p>Between the photosphere and the corona, is the thin region through which the temperature increases known as the <a href="/wiki/Solar_transition_region" title="Solar transition region">transition region</a>. It ranges from only tens to hundreds of kilometers thick. Energy cannot be transferred from the cooler photosphere to the corona by conventional heat transfer as this would violate the <a href="/wiki/Second_law_of_thermodynamics" title="Second law of thermodynamics">second law of thermodynamics</a>. An analogy of this would be a light bulb raising the temperature of the air surrounding it to something greater than its glass surface. Hence, some other manner of energy transfer must be involved in the heating of the corona.</p> 
      <p>The amount of power required to heat the solar corona can easily be calculated as the difference between <a href="/wiki/Coronal_radiative_losses" title="Coronal radiative losses">coronal radiative losses</a> and heating by thermal conduction toward the <a href="/wiki/Chromosphere" title="Chromosphere">chromosphere</a> through the transition region. It is about 1 kilowatt for every square meter of surface area on the Sun's chromosphere, or 1/40000 of the amount of light energy that escapes the Sun.</p> 
      <p>Many coronal heating theories have been proposed,<sup id="cite_ref-22" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-22">[22]</a></sup> but two theories have remained as the most likely candidates: wave heating and <a href="/wiki/Magnetic_reconnection" title="Magnetic reconnection">magnetic reconnection</a> (or <a href="/wiki/Nanoflares" title="Nanoflares">nanoflares</a>).<sup id="cite_ref-23" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-23">[23]</a></sup> Through most of the past 50 years, neither theory has been able to account for the extreme coronal temperatures.</p> 
      <p>In 2012, high resolution (&lt;0.2?) <a href="/wiki/Soft_X-ray" class="mw-redirect" title="Soft X-ray">soft X-ray</a> imaging with the <a href="/wiki/High_Resolution_Coronal_Imager" title="High Resolution Coronal Imager">High Resolution Coronal Imager</a> aboard a <a href="/wiki/Sounding_rocket" title="Sounding rocket">sounding rocket</a> revealed tightly wound braids in the corona. It is hypothesized that the reconnection and unravelling of braids can act as primary sources of heating of the active solar corona to temperatures of up to 4 million kelvins. The main heat source in the quiescent corona (about 1.5 million kelvins) is assumed to originate from <a href="/wiki/Magnetohydrodynamics" title="Magnetohydrodynamics">MHD waves</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Cirtain2013_24-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Cirtain2013-24">[24]</a></sup></p> 
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/NASA" title="NASA">NASA</a> mission <a href="/wiki/Parker_Solar_Probe" title="Parker Solar Probe">Parker Solar Probe</a> is intended to approach the Sun to a distance of approximately 9.5 solar radii to investigate coronal heating and the origin of the solar wind. It is scheduled to launch on July 31, 2018.<sup id="cite_ref-25" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-25">[25]</a></sup></p> 
      <table class="wikitable" style="margin: 1em auto 1em auto"> 
       <caption>
        <b>Competing heating mechanisms</b>
       </caption> 
       <tbody>
        <tr> 
         <th colspan="3">Heating Models</th> 
        </tr> 
        <tr> 
         <th>Hydrodynamic</th> 
         <th colspan="2">Magnetic</th> 
        </tr> 
        <tr> 
         <td rowspan="2"> 
          <ul> 
           <li>No magnetic field</li> 
           <li>Slow rotating stars</li> 
          </ul> </td> 
         <th><a href="/wiki/Direct_current" title="Direct current">DC</a> (<i>reconnection</i>)</th> 
         <th><a href="/wiki/Alternating_current" title="Alternating current">AC</a> (<i>waves</i>)</th> 
        </tr> 
        <tr> 
         <td> 
          <ul> 
           <li>B-field stresses</li> 
           <li>Reconnection events</li> 
           <li><a href="/wiki/Solar_flare" title="Solar flare">Flares</a>-<a href="/wiki/Nanoflares" title="Nanoflares">nanoflares</a></li> 
           <li><i>Uniform heating rates</i></li> 
          </ul> </td> 
         <td> 
          <ul> 
           <li>Photospheric foot point <i>shuffling</i></li> 
           <li>MHD wave propagation</li> 
           <li>High Alfvén wave flux</li> 
           <li><i>Non-uniform heating rates</i></li> 
          </ul> </td> 
        </tr> 
        <tr> 
         <th></th> 
         <th colspan="2">Competing theories</th> 
        </tr> 
       </tbody>
      </table> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Wave_heating_theory">Wave heating theory</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Corona&amp;action=edit&amp;section=19" title="Edit section: Wave heating theory">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3> 
      <p>The wave heating theory, proposed in 1949 by <a href="/wiki/Evry_Schatzman" class="mw-redirect" title="Evry Schatzman">Evry Schatzman</a>, proposes that waves carry energy from the solar interior to the solar chromosphere and corona. The Sun is made of <a href="/wiki/Plasma_(physics)" title="Plasma (physics)">plasma</a> rather than ordinary gas, so it supports several types of waves analogous to <a href="/wiki/Sound_waves" class="mw-redirect" title="Sound waves">sound waves</a> in air. The most important types of wave are <a href="/wiki/Magneto-acoustic_wave" class="mw-redirect" title="Magneto-acoustic wave">magneto-acoustic waves</a> and <a href="/wiki/Alfv%C3%A9n_wave" title="Alfvén wave">Alfvén waves</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-26" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-26">[26]</a></sup> Magneto-acoustic waves are sound waves that have been modified by the presence of a magnetic field, and Alfvén waves are similar to <a href="/wiki/Ultra_low_frequency" title="Ultra low frequency">ultra low frequency</a> <a href="/wiki/Radio_waves" class="mw-redirect" title="Radio waves">radio waves</a> that have been modified by interaction with <a href="/wiki/Matter" title="Matter">matter</a> in the plasma. Both types of waves can be launched by the turbulence of <a href="/wiki/Granule_(solar_physics)" title="Granule (solar physics)">granulation</a> and <a href="/wiki/Super_granulation" class="mw-redirect" title="Super granulation">super granulation</a> at the solar photosphere, and both types of waves can carry energy for some distance through the solar atmosphere before turning into <a href="/wiki/Shock_waves" class="mw-redirect" title="Shock waves">shock waves</a> that dissipate their energy as heat.</p> 
      <p>One problem with wave heating is delivery of the heat to the appropriate place. Magneto-acoustic waves cannot carry sufficient energy upward through the chromosphere to the corona, both because of the low pressure present in the chromosphere and because they tend to be <a href="/wiki/Reflection_(physics)" title="Reflection (physics)">reflected</a> back to the photosphere. Alfvén waves can carry enough energy, but do not dissipate that energy rapidly enough once they enter the corona. Waves in plasmas are notoriously difficult to understand and describe analytically, but computer simulations, carried out by Thomas Bogdan and colleagues in 2003, seem to show that Alfvén waves can transmute into other wave modes at the base of the corona, providing a pathway that can carry large amounts of energy from the photosphere through the chromosphere and transition region and finally into the corona where it dissipates it as heat.</p> 
      <p>Another problem with wave heating has been the complete absence, until the late 1990s, of any direct evidence of waves propagating through the solar corona. The first direct observation of waves propagating into and through the solar corona was made in 1997 with the <a href="/wiki/Solar_and_Heliospheric_Observatory" title="Solar and Heliospheric Observatory">Solar and Heliospheric Observatory</a> space-borne solar observatory, the first platform capable of observing the Sun in the <a href="/wiki/Extreme_ultraviolet" title="Extreme ultraviolet">extreme ultraviolet</a> (EUV) for long periods of time with stable <a href="/wiki/Photometry_(astronomy)" title="Photometry (astronomy)">photometry</a>. Those were magneto-acoustic waves with a frequency of about 1 <a href="/wiki/Hertz" title="Hertz">millihertz</a> (mHz, corresponding to a 1,000 second wave period), that carry only about 10% of the energy required to heat the corona. Many observations exist of localized wave phenomena, such as Alfvén waves launched by solar flares, but those events are transient and cannot explain the uniform coronal heat.</p> 
      <p>It is not yet known exactly how much wave energy is available to heat the corona. Results published in 2004 using data from the <a href="/wiki/TRACE" title="TRACE">TRACE</a> spacecraft seem to indicate that there are waves in the solar atmosphere at frequencies as high as 100 mHz (10 second period). Measurements of the temperature of different <a href="/wiki/Ions" class="mw-redirect" title="Ions">ions</a> in the solar wind with the UVCS instrument aboard <a href="/wiki/Solar_and_Heliospheric_Observatory" title="Solar and Heliospheric Observatory">SOHO</a> give strong indirect evidence that there are waves at frequencies as high as 200&nbsp;Hz, well into the range of human hearing. These waves are very difficult to detect under normal circumstances, but evidence collected during solar eclipses by teams from <a href="/wiki/Williams_College" title="Williams College">Williams College</a> suggest the presences of such waves in the 1–10&nbsp;Hz range.</p> 
      <p>Recently, Alfvénic motions have been found in the lower solar atmosphere <sup id="cite_ref-27" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-27">[27]</a></sup> <sup id="cite_ref-28" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-28">[28]</a></sup> and also in the quiet Sun, in coronal holes and in active regions using observations with AIA on board the <a href="/wiki/Solar_Dynamics_Observatory" title="Solar Dynamics Observatory">Solar Dynamics Observatory</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-29" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-29">[29]</a></sup> These Alfvénic oscillations have significant power, and seem to be connected to the chromospheric Alfvénic oscillations previously reported with the <a href="/wiki/Hinode" title="Hinode">Hinode</a> spacecraft .<sup id="cite_ref-30" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-30">[30]</a></sup></p> 
      <p>Solar wind observations with the <a href="/wiki/WIND_(spacecraft)" title="WIND (spacecraft)">WIND (spacecraft)</a> have recently shown evidence to support theories of Alfvén-cyclotron dissipation, leading to local ion heating.<sup id="cite_ref-31" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-31">[31]</a></sup></p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Magnetic_reconnection_theory">Magnetic reconnection theory</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Corona&amp;action=edit&amp;section=20" title="Edit section: Magnetic reconnection theory">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: 
       <a href="/wiki/Magnetic_reconnection" title="Magnetic reconnection">Magnetic reconnection</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright"> 
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Arcing_Active_Region.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9c/Arcing_Active_Region.jpg/220px-Arcing_Active_Region.jpg" width="220" height="220" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9c/Arcing_Active_Region.jpg/330px-Arcing_Active_Region.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9c/Arcing_Active_Region.jpg/440px-Arcing_Active_Region.jpg 2x" data-file-width="800" data-file-height="800"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption"> 
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Arcing_Active_Region.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div> Arcing active region by 
         <a href="/wiki/Solar_Dynamics_Observatory" title="Solar Dynamics Observatory">Solar Dynamics Observatory</a>
        </div> 
       </div> 
      </div> 
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/Magnetic_reconnection" title="Magnetic reconnection">magnetic reconnection</a> theory relies on the solar magnetic field to induce electric currents in the solar corona.<sup id="cite_ref-32" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-32">[32]</a></sup> The currents then collapse suddenly, releasing energy as heat and wave energy in the corona. This process is called "reconnection" because of the peculiar way that magnetic fields behave in plasma (or any electrically conductive fluid such as <a href="/wiki/Mercury_(element)" title="Mercury (element)">mercury</a> or <a href="/wiki/Seawater" title="Seawater">seawater</a>). In a plasma, <a href="/wiki/Magnetic_field_lines" class="mw-redirect" title="Magnetic field lines">magnetic field lines</a> are normally tied to individual pieces of matter, so that the <a href="/wiki/Topology" title="Topology">topology</a> of the magnetic field remains the same: if a particular north and south <a href="/wiki/Poles_of_astronomical_bodies#Magnetic_poles" title="Poles of astronomical bodies">magnetic pole</a> are connected by a single field line, then even if the plasma is stirred or if the magnets are moved around, that field line will continue to connect those particular poles. The connection is maintained by electric currents that are induced in the plasma. Under certain conditions, the electric currents can collapse, allowing the magnetic field to "reconnect" to other magnetic poles and release heat and wave energy in the process.</p> 
      <p><a href="/wiki/Magnetic_reconnection" title="Magnetic reconnection">Magnetic reconnection</a> is hypothesized to be the mechanism behind solar flares, the largest explosions in our solar system. Furthermore, the surface of the Sun is covered with millions of small magnetized regions 50–1,000&nbsp;km across. These small magnetic poles are buffeted and churned by the constant granulation. The magnetic field in the solar corona must undergo nearly constant reconnection to match the motion of this "magnetic carpet", so the energy released by the reconnection is a natural candidate for the coronal heat, perhaps as a series of "microflares" that individually provide very little energy but together account for the required energy.</p> 
      <p>The idea that <a href="/wiki/Nanoflares" title="Nanoflares">nanoflares</a> might heat the corona was proposed by <a href="/wiki/Eugene_Parker" title="Eugene Parker">Eugene Parker</a> in the 1980s but is still controversial. In particular, <a href="/wiki/Ultraviolet" title="Ultraviolet">ultraviolet</a> telescopes such as <a href="/wiki/TRACE" title="TRACE">TRACE</a> and <a href="/wiki/Solar_and_Heliospheric_Observatory" title="Solar and Heliospheric Observatory">SOHO</a>/EIT can observe individual micro-flares as small brightenings in extreme ultraviolet light,<sup id="cite_ref-33" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-33">[33]</a></sup> but there seem to be too few of these small events to account for the energy released into the corona. The additional energy not accounted for could be made up by wave energy, or by gradual magnetic reconnection that releases energy more smoothly than micro-flares and therefore doesn't appear well in the <a href="/wiki/TRACE" title="TRACE">TRACE</a> data. Variations on the micro-flare hypothesis use other mechanisms to stress the magnetic field or to release the energy, and are a subject of active research in 2005.</p> 
      <h3><span id="Spicules_.28type_II.29"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Spicules_(type_II)">Spicules (type II)</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Corona&amp;action=edit&amp;section=21" title="Edit section: Spicules (type II)">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3> 
      <p>For decades, researchers believed <a href="/wiki/Spicule_(solar_physics)" title="Spicule (solar physics)">spicules</a> could send heat into the corona. However, following observational research in the 1980s, it was found that spicule plasma did not reach coronal temperatures, and so the theory was discounted.</p> 
      <p>As per studies performed in 2010 at the <i>National Center for Atmospheric Research</i> in <a href="/wiki/Colorado" title="Colorado">Colorado</a>, in collaboration with the <i>Lockheed Martin's Solar and Astrophysics Laboratory</i> (LMSAL) and the <i>Institute of Theoretical Astrophysics</i> of the <a href="/wiki/University_of_Oslo" title="University of Oslo">University of Oslo</a>, a new class of spicules (TYPE II) discovered in 2007, which travel faster (up to 100&nbsp;km/s) and have shorter lifespans, can account for the problem.<sup id="cite_ref-34" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-34">[34]</a></sup> These jets insert heated plasma into the Sun's outer atmosphere.</p> 
      <p>Thus, a much greater understanding of the Corona and improvement in the knowledge of the Sun's subtle influence on the Earth's upper atmosphere can be expected henceforth. The Atmospheric Imaging Assembly on NASA's recently launched Solar Dynamics Observatory and NASA's Focal Plane Package for the Solar Optical Telescope on the Japanese Hinode satellite which was used to test this hypothesis. The high spatial and temporal resolutions of the newer instruments reveal this coronal mass supply.</p> 
      <p>These observations reveal a one-to-one connection between plasma that is heated to millions of degrees and the spicules that insert this plasma into the corona.<sup id="cite_ref-35" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-35">[35]</a></sup></p> 
      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="See_also">See also</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Corona&amp;action=edit&amp;section=22" title="Edit section: See also">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2> 
      <div role="navigation" aria-label="Portals" class="noprint portal plainlist tright" style="margin:0.5em 0 0.5em 1em;border:solid #aaa 1px">

        <li style="display:table-row"><span style="display:table-cell;padding:0.2em;vertical-align:middle;text-align:center"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/00/Crab_Nebula.jpg/28px-Crab_Nebula.jpg" width="28" height="28" class="noviewer" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/00/Crab_Nebula.jpg/42px-Crab_Nebula.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/00/Crab_Nebula.jpg/56px-Crab_Nebula.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3864" data-file-height="3864"></span><span style="display:table-cell;padding:0.2em 0.2em 0.2em 0.3em;vertical-align:middle"><a href="/wiki/Portal:Astronomy" title="Portal:Astronomy">Astronomy portal</a></span></li>

      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="References">References</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Corona&amp;action=edit&amp;section=23" title="Edit section: References">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>

        <li id="cite_note-Giacconi-10"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-Giacconi_10-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-Giacconi_10-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-Giacconi_10-2"><sup><i><b>c</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation book">Giacconi, Riccardo (1992). Kluwer Academic Publishers-Printed in the Netherlands. pp.&nbsp;3–19. <a href="/wiki/International_Standard_Book_Number" title="International Standard Book Number">ISBN</a>&nbsp;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/0-7923-2346-7" title="Special:BookSources/0-7923-2346-7">0-7923-2346-7</a>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=G.S.+Vaiana+memorial+lecture+in+Proceedinds+of+Physics+of+Solar+and+Stellar+Coronae%3A+G.S.+Vaiana+Memorial+Symposium&amp;rft.pages=3-19&amp;rft.pub=Kluwer+Academic+Publishers-Printed+in+the+Netherlands&amp;rft.date=1992&amp;rft.isbn=0-7923-2346-7&amp;rft.aulast=Giacconi&amp;rft.aufirst=Riccardo&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ACorona" class="Z3988"><span style="display:none;">&nbsp;</span></span></span></li> 
        <li id="cite_note-11"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-11">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation journal">Ofman, Leon (2000).         <li id="cite_note-Cirtain2013-24"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Cirtain2013_24-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation journal">Cirtain, J. "Energy release in the solar corona from spatially resolved magnetic braids". <i>Nature</i>. <b>493</b> (7433): 501–503. <a href="/wiki/Bibcode" title="Bibcode">Bibcode</a>:<a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://adsabs.harvard.edu/abs/2013Natur.493..501C">2013Natur.493..501C</a>. <a href="/wiki/Digital_object_identifier" title="Digital object identifier">doi</a>:<a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="//doi.org/10.1038%2Fnature11772">10.1038/nature11772</a>. <a href="/wiki/PubMed_Identifier" class="mw-redirect" title="PubMed Identifier">PMID</a>&nbsp;<a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="//www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/23344359">23344359</a>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Nature&amp;rft.atitle=Energy+release+in+the+solar+corona+from+spatially+resolved+magnetic+braids&amp;rft.volume=493&amp;rft.issue=7433&amp;rft.pages=501-503&amp;rft.date=2013&amp;rft_id=info%3Apmid%2F23344359&amp;rft_id=info%3Adoi%2F10.1038%2Fnature11772&amp;rft_id=info%3Abibcode%2F2013Natur.493..501C&amp;rft.aulast=Cirtain&amp;rft.aufirst=J.+W.&amp;rft.au=Golub%2C+L.&amp;rft.au=Winebarger%2C+A.+R.&amp;rft.au=De+Pontieu%2C+B.&amp;rft.au=Kobayashi%2C+K.&amp;rft.au=Moore%2C+R.+L.&amp;rft.au=Walsh%2C+R.+W.&amp;rft.au=Korreck%2C+K.+E.&amp;rft.au=Weber%2C+M.&amp;rft.au=McCauley%2C+P.&amp;rft.au=Title%2C+A.&amp;rft.au=Kuzin%2C+S.&amp;rft.au=Deforest%2C+C.+E.&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ACorona" class="Z3988"><span style="display:none;">&nbsp;</span></span></span></li> 
        <li id="cite_note-25"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-25">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a rel="nofollow" class="external free" href="http://parkersolarprobe.jhuapl.edu/The-Mission/index.php#Journey-to-the-Sun">http://parkersolarprobe.jhuapl.edu/The-Mission/index.php#Journey-to-the-Sun</a> <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20170822222954/http://parkersolarprobe.jhuapl.edu/The-Mission/index.php">Archived</a> 2017-08-22 at the <a href="/wiki/Wayback_Machine" title="Wayback Machine">Wayback Machine</a>.</span></li>

      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Further_reading">Further reading</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Corona&amp;action=edit&amp;section=24" title="Edit section: Further reading">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2> 
      <ul> 
       <li>Thorsten Dambeck: <i><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.mpg.de/english/illustrationsDocumentation/multimedia/mpResearch/2008/heft02/011/pdf13.pdf">Seething Cauldron in the Suns's Furnace</a></i>, MaxPlanckResearch, 2/2008, p.&nbsp;28–33</li> 
       <li>B. N. Dwivedi and A. K. Srivastava <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.ias.ac.in/currsci/10feb2010/295.pdf">Coronal heating by Alfvén waves</a> CURRENT 296 SCIENCE, VOL. 98, NO. 3, 10 FEBRUARY 2010, pp.&nbsp;295–296</li> 
      </ul> 
      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="External_links">External links</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Corona&amp;action=edit&amp;section=25" title="Edit section: External links">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2> 
      <table role="presentation" class="mbox-small plainlinks sistersitebox" style="background-color:#f9f9f9;border:1px solid #aaa;color:#000"> 
       <tbody>
        <tr> 
         <td class="mbox-image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/4/4a/Commons-logo.svg/30px-Commons-logo.svg.png" width="30" height="40" class="noviewer" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/4/4a/Commons-logo.svg/45px-Commons-logo.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/4/4a/Commons-logo.svg/59px-Commons-logo.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="1024" data-file-height="1376"></td> 
         <td class="mbox-text plainlist">Wikimedia Commons has media related to <i><b><a href="https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/Category:Solar_corona" class="extiw" title="commons:Category:Solar corona">Solar corona</a></b></i>.</td> 
        </tr> 
       </tbody>
      </table> 
      <ul> 
       <li><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://solarscience.msfc.nasa.gov/corona.shtml">NASA description of the solar corona</a></li> 
       <li><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.innovations-report.com/html/reports/physics_astronomy/report-33153.html">Coronal heating problem at Innovation Reports</a></li> 
       <li><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://imagine.gsfc.nasa.gov/docs/science/mysteries_l1/corona.html">NASA/GSFC description of the coronal heating problem</a></li> 
       <li><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://solar-center.stanford.edu/FAQ/Qcorona.html">FAQ about coronal heating</a></li> 
       <li><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://sohowww.nascom.nasa.gov">Solar and Heliospheric Observatory, including near-real-time images of the solar corona</a></li> 
       <li><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://xrt.cfa.harvard.edu/">Coronal x-ray images from the Hinode XRT</a></li> 
       <li><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://antwrp.gsfc.nasa.gov/apod/ap090726.html">nasa.gov Astronomy Picture of the Day July 26, 2009</a>&nbsp;– a combination of thirty-three photographs of the sun's corona that were digitally processed to highlight faint features of a total eclipse that occurred in March 2006</li> 
       <li><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://alienworlds.southwales.ac.uk/sunStructure.html#/corona">Animated explanation of the core of the Sun</a> (University of South Wales)</li> 
       <li><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://alienworlds.southwales.ac.uk/sunStructure.html#/coronatemp">Animated explanation of the temperature of the Corona</a> (University of South Wales)</li> 
       <li><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://sites.google.com/site/ecanrio/Home/referencias/ETMV-Libro_new.pdf?attredirects=0yd=1">Space,time,matter and vacuum: The Solar Corona. A sign of Quantum Gravity?(Spanish)</a></li> 
       <li><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20110710155828/http://blogs.physicstoday.org/update/2009/03/alfven-waves-may-heat-the-suns.html">Alfvén waves may heat the Sun's corona</a></li> 
       <li><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://news.discovery.com/space/sun-heat-mystery-110106.html">New Clue May Solve Solar Mystery</a></li> 
       <li><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.sciencemag.org/content/331/6013/55.abstract?sid=18d15db8-169c-4ebf-a391-dc1ad55f0fa9">The Origins of Hot Plasma in the Solar Corona</a></li> 
       <li><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=o-v9kLLiK4s">Solar Interface Region&nbsp;– Bart de Pontieu (SETI Talks) Video</a></li> 
      </ul>

               <li><a href="/wiki/Magnetar" title="Magnetar">Magnetar</a></li> 
              </ul> </li> 
             <li><a href="/wiki/Stellar_black_hole" title="Stellar black hole">Stellar black hole</a></li>

              <ul>

            </ul> 
           </div> </td> 
         </tr>

   <h1 id="firstHeading" class="firstHeading" lang="en">Solar eclipse of May 20, 2012</h1> 
   <div id="bodyContent" class="mw-body-content"> 
    <div id="siteSub" class="noprint">
     From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia
    </div> 
    <div id="contentSub"></div> 
    <div id="jump-to-nav" class="mw-jump">

    </div> 
    <div id="mw-content-text" lang="en" dir="ltr" class="mw-content-ltr">
     <div class="mw-parser-output">
      <table class="infobox vevent" style="width:22em;width:25em; text-align:left; font-size:90%;">

         <th colspan="2" class="summary" style="text-align:center;font-size:125%;font-weight:bold;padding-bottom:0.25em; background:; line-height:1.2em; text-align:center; font-size:115%;">Solar eclipse of <i>May 20, 2012</i></th> 
        </tr> 
        <tr> 
         <td colspan="2" style="text-align:center;padding-bottom:0.5em;"><a href="/wiki/File:Annular_Eclipse._Taken_from_Middlegate,_Nevada_on_May_20,_2012.jpg" class="image"><img alt="Annular Eclipse. Taken from Middlegate, Nevada on May 20, 2012.jpg" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/37/Annular_Eclipse._Taken_from_Middlegate%2C_Nevada_on_May_20%2C_2012.jpg/320px-Annular_Eclipse._Taken_from_Middlegate%2C_Nevada_on_May_20%2C_2012.jpg" width="320" height="320" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/37/Annular_Eclipse._Taken_from_Middlegate%2C_Nevada_on_May_20%2C_2012.jpg/480px-Annular_Eclipse._Taken_from_Middlegate%2C_Nevada_on_May_20%2C_2012.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/37/Annular_Eclipse._Taken_from_Middlegate%2C_Nevada_on_May_20%2C_2012.jpg/640px-Annular_Eclipse._Taken_from_Middlegate%2C_Nevada_on_May_20%2C_2012.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1801" data-file-height="1801"></a> 
          <div style="padding-top:0.1em; line-height:1.2em;">
           From 
           <a href="/wiki/Middlegate,_Nevada" title="Middlegate, Nevada">Middlegate, Nevada</a>
          </div> </td> 
        </tr> 
        <tr> 
         <td colspan="2" style="text-align:center;padding:0; line-height:1.2em; vertical-align:middle;"> 
          <div style="padding-bottom:0.5em;">

           <div style="line-height:1.2em; padding-top:0.1em;">
            Map
           </div> 
          </div> </td> 
        </tr> 
        <tr> 
         <th colspan="2" style="text-align:center;background:#eee; font-size:105%;">Type of eclipse</th> 
        </tr> 
        <tr> 
         <th scope="row" style="padding:0 0.5em 0 0; line-height:1.1em;">Nature</th> 
         <td style="padding:0; line-height:1.2em; vertical-align:middle;">Annular</td> 
        </tr> 
        <tr> 
         <th scope="row" style="padding:0 0.5em 0 0; line-height:1.1em;"><a href="/wiki/Gamma_(eclipse)" title="Gamma (eclipse)">Gamma</a></th> 
         <td style="padding:0; line-height:1.2em; vertical-align:middle;">0.4828</td> 
        </tr> 
        <tr> 
         <th scope="row" style="padding:0 0.5em 0 0; line-height:1.1em;"><a href="/wiki/Magnitude_of_eclipse" title="Magnitude of eclipse">Magnitude</a></th> 
         <td style="padding:0; line-height:1.2em; vertical-align:middle;">0.9439</td> 
        </tr> 
        <tr> 
         <th colspan="2" style="text-align:center;background:#eee; font-size:105%;">Maximum eclipse</th> 
        </tr> 
        <tr> 
         <th scope="row" style="padding:0 0.5em 0 0; line-height:1.1em;">Duration</th> 
         <td style="padding:0; line-height:1.2em; vertical-align:middle;">346&nbsp;sec (5&nbsp;m 46&nbsp;s)</td> 
        </tr> 
        <tr> 
         <th scope="row" style="padding:0 0.5em 0 0; line-height:1.1em;">Coordinates</th> 
         <td style="padding:0; line-height:1.2em; vertical-align:middle;"><span class="plainlinks nourlexpansion"><a class="external text" href="//tools.wmflabs.org/geohack/geohack.php?pagename=Solar_eclipse_of_May_20,_2012&amp;params=49.1_N_176.3_E_type:landmark"><span class="geo-nondefault"><span class="geo-dms" title="Maps, aerial photos, and other data for this location"><span class="latitude">49°06?N</span> <span class="longitude">176°18?E</span></span></span><span class="geo-multi-punct">? / ?</span><span class="geo-default"><span class="geo-dec" title="Maps, aerial photos, and other data for this location">49.1°N 176.3°E</span><span style="display:none">? / <span class="geo">49.1; 176.3</span></span></span></a></span></td> 
        </tr> 
        <tr> 
         <th scope="row" style="padding:0 0.5em 0 0; line-height:1.1em;">Max.&nbsp;width of&nbsp;band</th> 
         <td style="padding:0; line-height:1.2em; vertical-align:middle;">237&nbsp;km (147&nbsp;mi)</td> 
        </tr> 
        <tr> 
         <th colspan="2" style="text-align:center;background:#eee; font-size:105%;">Times (<a href="/wiki/UTC" class="mw-redirect" title="UTC">UTC</a>)</th> 
        </tr> 
        <tr> 
         <th scope="row" style="padding:0 0.5em 0 0; line-height:1.1em;">(P1) Partial begin</th> 
         <td style="padding:0; line-height:1.2em; vertical-align:middle;">20:56:07</td> 
        </tr> 
        <tr> 
         <th scope="row" style="padding:0 0.5em 0 0; line-height:1.1em;">(U1) Total begin</th> 
         <td style="padding:0; line-height:1.2em; vertical-align:middle;">22:06:17</td> 
        </tr> 
        <tr> 
         <th scope="row" style="padding:0 0.5em 0 0; line-height:1.1em;">Greatest eclipse</th> 
         <td style="padding:0; line-height:1.2em; vertical-align:middle;">23:53:54</td> 
        </tr> 
        <tr> 
         <th scope="row" style="padding:0 0.5em 0 0; line-height:1.1em;">(U4) Total end</th> 
         <td style="padding:0; line-height:1.2em; vertical-align:middle;">1:39:11</td> 
        </tr> 
        <tr> 
         <th scope="row" style="padding:0 0.5em 0 0; line-height:1.1em;">(P4) Partial end</th> 
         <td style="padding:0; line-height:1.2em; vertical-align:middle;">2:49:21</td> 
        </tr> 
        <tr> 
         <th colspan="2" style="text-align:center;background:#eee; font-size:105%;">References</th> 
        </tr> 
        <tr> 
         <th scope="row" style="padding:0 0.5em 0 0; line-height:1.1em;"><a href="/wiki/Saros_(astronomy)" title="Saros (astronomy)">Saros</a></th> 
         <td style="padding:0; line-height:1.2em; vertical-align:middle;"><a href="/wiki/Solar_Saros_128" title="Solar Saros 128">128</a> (58 of 73)</td> 
        </tr> 
        <tr> 
         <th scope="row" style="padding:0 0.5em 0 0; line-height:1.1em;">Catalog # (SE5000)</th> 
         <td style="padding:0; line-height:1.2em; vertical-align:middle;"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://eclipse.gsfc.nasa.gov/SEcat5/SE2011-2110.html">9535</a></td> 
        </tr> 
       </tbody>
      </table> 
      <p>An <b><a href="/wiki/Solar_eclipse#Types" title="Solar eclipse">annular solar eclipse</a></b> took place on <b>May 20, 2012</b> (May 21, 2012 in local time in the <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Hemisphere" title="Eastern Hemisphere">Eastern Hemisphere</a>). One of the three main types of <a href="/wiki/Solar_eclipse" title="Solar eclipse">solar eclipses</a>, an annular solar eclipse occurs when the Moon's <a href="/wiki/Apparent_diameter" class="mw-redirect" title="Apparent diameter">apparent diameter</a> is smaller than the Sun's, as compared to a <a href="/wiki/Solar_eclipse#Types" title="Solar eclipse">total solar eclipse</a>, when the <a href="/wiki/Moon" title="Moon">Moon</a> completely blocks the <a href="/wiki/Sun" title="Sun">Sun</a>.</p> 
      <p>The eclipse was visible in large areas of the Eastern Hemisphere and the <a href="/wiki/Western_Hemisphere" title="Western Hemisphere">Western Hemisphere</a>, including the land masses of <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Asia" class="mw-redirect" title="Eastern Asia">Eastern Asia</a> and <a href="/wiki/North_America" title="North America">North America</a>. It was the first annular eclipse to pass over the <a href="/wiki/United_States" title="United States">United States</a> since the <a href="/wiki/Solar_eclipse_of_May_10,_1994" title="Solar eclipse of May 10, 1994">solar eclipse of May 10, 1994</a> and Asia since the <a href="/wiki/Solar_eclipse_of_January_15,_2010" title="Solar eclipse of January 15, 2010">solar eclipse of January 15, 2010</a>.</p> 
      <p></p> 
      <div id="toc" class="toc"> 
       <div class="toctitle" lang="en" dir="ltr" xml:lang="en">

      <p></p> 
      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Path_and_viewing">Path and viewing</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Solar_eclipse_of_May_20,_2012&amp;action=edit&amp;section=1" title="Edit section: Path and viewing">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2> 
      <div class="thumb tleft"> 
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:SE2012May20A.gif" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/28/SE2012May20A.gif/220px-SE2012May20A.gif" width="220" height="238" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/2/28/SE2012May20A.gif 1.5x" data-file-width="250" data-file-height="270"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption"> 
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:SE2012May20A.gif" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div> Animated path of the eclipse
        </div> 
       </div> 
      </div> 
      <p>The antumbra travelled eastbound at an average rate of .62&nbsp;miles per minute (or 1.1&nbsp;kilometers per minute), remaining above the <a href="/wiki/Equator" title="Equator">equator</a> throughout the event.<sup id="cite_ref-Annular_Solar_Eclipse_of_2012_May_20_1-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Annular_Solar_Eclipse_of_2012_May_20-1">[1]</a></sup></p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Asia">Asia</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Solar_eclipse_of_May_20,_2012&amp;action=edit&amp;section=2" title="Edit section: Asia">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3> 
      <p>The eclipse began in <a href="/wiki/Southern_China" class="mw-redirect" title="Southern China">Southern China</a> at sunrise, shortly after 6:00 a.m. local time. Within an hour, the <a href="/wiki/Umbra,_penumbra_and_antumbra" title="Umbra, penumbra and antumbra">antumbra</a> of the eclipse had approached and passed over the cities of <a href="/wiki/Guangzhou" title="Guangzhou">Guangzhou</a>, <a href="/wiki/Xiamen" title="Xiamen">Xiamen</a>, <a href="/wiki/Quanzhou" title="Quanzhou">Quanzhou</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Fuzhou" title="Fuzhou">Fuzhou</a>, as well as <a href="/wiki/Hong_Kong" title="Hong Kong">Hong Kong</a> and <a href="/wiki/Taipei,_Taiwan" class="mw-redirect" title="Taipei, Taiwan">Taipei, Taiwan</a>. After crossing the <a href="/wiki/East_China_Sea" title="East China Sea">East China Sea</a>, the eclipse passed over much of eastern <a href="/wiki/Japan" title="Japan">Japan</a>, including the cities of <a href="/wiki/Nagoya" title="Nagoya">Nagoya</a> and <a href="/wiki/Tokyo" title="Tokyo">Tokyo</a>, before entering the Pacific Ocean. The <a href="/wiki/Umbra,_penumbra_and_antumbra" title="Umbra, penumbra and antumbra">penumbra</a> of the eclipse was visible throughout <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Asia" class="mw-redirect" title="Eastern Asia">Eastern Asia</a> and <a href="/wiki/List_of_islands_in_the_Pacific_Ocean" title="List of islands in the Pacific Ocean">islands in the Pacific Ocean</a>, lasting until late morning.<sup id="cite_ref-Annular_Solar_Eclipse_of_2012_May_20_1-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Annular_Solar_Eclipse_of_2012_May_20-1">[1]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Map_of_Eclipse_2-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Map_of_Eclipse-2">[2]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-3">[3]</a></sup></p> 
      <p>The path of the antumbra over highly populated areas allowed at least an estimated 100 million people to view annularity.<sup id="cite_ref-May_20th's_Annular_Eclipse_of_the_Sun_4-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-May_20th's_Annular_Eclipse_of_the_Sun-4">[4]</a></sup> Because it took place during Southeast Asia's summer <a href="/wiki/Wet_season" title="Wet season">monsoon season</a>, viewing conditions were not ideal in some areas, including Hong Kong.<sup id="cite_ref-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-5">[5]</a></sup></p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="North_America">North America</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Solar_eclipse_of_May_20,_2012&amp;action=edit&amp;section=3" title="Edit section: North America">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3> 
      <p>The antumbra entered North America between the coastlines of <a href="/wiki/Oregon" title="Oregon">Oregon</a> and <a href="/wiki/California" title="California">California</a>, shortly before 5:30 p.m. local time. Within 45 minutes, it had passed over <a href="/wiki/Medford,_Oregon" title="Medford, Oregon">Medford, Oregon</a>, <a href="/wiki/Redding,_California" title="Redding, California">Redding, California</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Reno,_Nevada" title="Reno, Nevada">Reno, Nevada</a>. It continued traveling southeast, passing 30&nbsp;miles north of <a href="/wiki/Las_Vegas,_Nevada" class="mw-redirect" title="Las Vegas, Nevada">Las Vegas, Nevada</a>, and directly over <a href="/wiki/Cedar_City,_Utah" title="Cedar City, Utah">Cedar City, Utah</a>, <a href="/wiki/Albuquerque,_New_Mexico" title="Albuquerque, New Mexico">Albuquerque, New Mexico</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Lubbock,_Texas" title="Lubbock, Texas">Lubbock, Texas</a> before terminating above central Texas at sunset. The prenumbra was visible throughout most of <a href="/wiki/North_America" title="North America">North America</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Western_Hemisphere" title="Western Hemisphere">Western Hemisphere</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Annular_Solar_Eclipse_of_2012_May_20_1-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Annular_Solar_Eclipse_of_2012_May_20-1">[1]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Map_of_Eclipse_2-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Map_of_Eclipse-2">[2]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Solar_Eclipse_Visible_From_California_to_Texas_Sunday_Afternoon_6-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Solar_Eclipse_Visible_From_California_to_Texas_Sunday_Afternoon-6">[6]</a></sup></p> 
      <p>An estimated 6 million people lived under the path of the antumbra. Numerous gatherings were held to view the eclipse, with some involving thousands of people.<sup id="cite_ref-Solar_Eclipse_Visible_From_California_to_Texas_Sunday_Afternoon_6-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Solar_Eclipse_Visible_From_California_to_Texas_Sunday_Afternoon-6">[6]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Spectacular_&quot;Ring_of_Fire&quot;_Solar_Eclipse_Wows_Millions_7-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Spectacular_&quot;Ring_of_Fire&quot;_Solar_Eclipse_Wows_Millions-7">[7]</a></sup> The eclipse was recorded and broadcast to those unable to see the eclipse.<sup id="cite_ref-Solar_Eclipse_2012:_How_To_See_The_May_20_Annular_Eclipse_8-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Solar_Eclipse_2012:_How_To_See_The_May_20_Annular_Eclipse-8">[8]</a></sup> Thirty-three national parks were under the direct path of the eclipse.<sup id="cite_ref-Solar_Eclipse_2012:_How_to_See_&quot;Ring_of_Fire&quot;_May_20_9-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Solar_Eclipse_2012:_How_to_See_&quot;Ring_of_Fire&quot;_May_20-9">[9]</a></sup></p> 
      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Related_eclipses">Related eclipses</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Solar_eclipse_of_May_20,_2012&amp;action=edit&amp;section=4" title="Edit section: Related eclipses">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2> 
      <h3><span id="Solar_eclipses_2011.E2.80.932014"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Solar_eclipses_2011–2014">Solar eclipses 2011–2014</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Solar_eclipse_of_May_20,_2012&amp;action=edit&amp;section=5" title="Edit section: Solar eclipses 2011–2014">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3> 
      <p>Each member in a <a href="/wiki/Eclipse_cycle#Eclipse_cycles" title="Eclipse cycle">semester series</a> of solar eclipses repeats approximately every 177 days and 4 hours (a semester) at alternating <a href="/wiki/Lunar_node" title="Lunar node">nodes</a> of the Moon's orbit. Note: Partial solar eclipses on <a href="/wiki/Solar_eclipse_of_January_4,_2011" title="Solar eclipse of January 4, 2011">January 4, 2011</a> and <a href="/wiki/Solar_eclipse_of_July_1,_2011" title="Solar eclipse of July 1, 2011">July 1, 2011</a> occur in the previous semester series.</p> 
      <table class="wikitable collapsible collapsed" style="text-align: center;">

      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Saros_128">Saros 128</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Solar_eclipse_of_May_20,_2012&amp;action=edit&amp;section=6" title="Edit section: Saros 128">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3> 
      <p>This eclipse is a part of the <a href="/wiki/Solar_Saros_128" title="Solar Saros 128">Solar Saros cycle 128</a>, which contains 73 events occurring every 18 years and 11 days. The series commenced with a partial solar eclipse on August 29, 984 AD. From May 16, 1417 through June 18, 1471 the series produced total solar eclipses, followed by hybrid eclipses from June 28, 1489 through July 31, 1543. It progressed to annular eclipses, producing them from August 11, 1561 through July 25, 2120. The series ends at member 73 as a partial eclipse on November 1, 2282. The longest duration of totality was 1 minutes and 45 seconds during the total solar eclipse of June 7, 1453.<sup id="cite_ref-10" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-10">[10]</a></sup></p> 
      <table class="wikitable collapsible collapsed"> 
       <tbody>
        <tr> 
         <th colspan="3">Series members 52–62 occur between 1901 and 2100</th> 
        </tr> 
        <tr> 
         <th>52</th> 
         <th>53</th> 
         <th>54</th> 
        </tr>

         <td><a href="/wiki/File:SE1904Mar17A.png" class="image"><img alt="SE1904Mar17A.png" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2e/SE1904Mar17A.png/150px-SE1904Mar17A.png" width="150" height="150" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2e/SE1904Mar17A.png/225px-SE1904Mar17A.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2e/SE1904Mar17A.png/300px-SE1904Mar17A.png 2x" data-file-width="728" data-file-height="729"></a><br> <a href="/wiki/Solar_eclipse_of_March_17,_1904" title="Solar eclipse of March 17, 1904">March 17, 1904</a></td>

      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Asia_2">Asia</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Solar_eclipse_of_May_20,_2012&amp;action=edit&amp;section=9" title="Edit section: Asia">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3> 
      <ul class="gallery mw-gallery-packed"> 
       <li class="gallerybox" style="width: 215.33333333333px"> 
        <div style="width: 215.33333333333px"> 
         <div class="thumb" style="width: 213.33333333333px;"> 
          <div style="margin:0px auto;">
           <a href="/wiki/File:Solar_eclipse_2012_May_21,_Taiwan.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5d/Solar_eclipse_2012_May_21%2C_Taiwan.jpg/320px-Solar_eclipse_2012_May_21%2C_Taiwan.jpg" width="214" height="120" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5d/Solar_eclipse_2012_May_21%2C_Taiwan.jpg/480px-Solar_eclipse_2012_May_21%2C_Taiwan.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5d/Solar_eclipse_2012_May_21%2C_Taiwan.jpg/640px-Solar_eclipse_2012_May_21%2C_Taiwan.jpg 2x" data-file-width="5120" data-file-height="2880"></a>

          <p>Composite image from <a href="/wiki/Keelung,_Taiwan" class="mw-redirect" title="Keelung, Taiwan">Keelung, Taiwan</a></p>

        </div> </li> 
       <li class="gallerybox" style="width: 162px"> 
        <div style="width: 162px">

      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="USA">USA</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Solar_eclipse_of_May_20,_2012&amp;action=edit&amp;section=10" title="Edit section: USA">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3> 
      <ul class="gallery mw-gallery-packed"> 
       <li class="gallerybox" style="width: 162px"> 
        <div style="width: 162px">

          </div>

Retrieved <span class="nowrap">17 October</span> 2017</span>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.atitle=Tokyo+to+be+treated+to+rare+annular+eclipse%2C+Venus+transit&amp;rft.date=2012-05-04&amp;rft.aulast=Matsutani&amp;rft.aufirst=Minoru&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.japantimes.co.jp%2Fnews%2F2012%2F05%2F04%2Fnational%2Ftokyo-to-be-treated-to-rare-annular-eclipse-venus-transit%2F%23.WeY0wEuGPrc&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ASolar+eclipse+of+May+20%2C+2012" class="Z3988"><span style="display:none;">&nbsp;</span></span></span></li> 
        <li id="cite_note-May_20th's_Annular_Eclipse_of_the_Sun-4"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-May_20th's_Annular_Eclipse_of_the_Sun_4-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation news">Beatty, Kelly (March 1, 2012). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.skyandtelescope.com/astronomy-news/observing-news/may-20ths-annular-eclipse-of-the-sun/">"May 20th's Annular Eclipse of the Sun"</a>. <i>Sky and Telescope</i><span class="reference-accessdate">.         <li id="cite_note-5"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-5">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation news"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.scmp.com/article/1001483/may-sun-shine-rare-eclipse">"May the Sun Shine on Rare Eclipse"</a>.         <li id="cite_note-Solar_Eclipse_Visible_From_California_to_Texas_Sunday_Afternoon-6"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-Solar_Eclipse_Visible_From_California_to_Texas_Sunday_Afternoon_6-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-Solar_Eclipse_Visible_From_California_to_Texas_Sunday_Afternoon_6-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation news">Potter, Ned (May 18, 2012). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://abcnews.go.com/Technology/solar-eclipse-2012-annular-eclipse-visible-california-texas/story?id=16377743">"Solar Eclipse Visible From California to Texas Sunday Afternoon"</a>. <i>ABC News</i><span class="reference-accessdate">.               <th scope="row" class="navbox-group" style="width:1%">Visibility</th> 
              <td class="navbox-list navbox-odd" style="text-align:left;border-left-width:2px;border-left-style:solid;width:100%;padding:0px">

              <th scope="row" class="navbox-group" style="width:1%">Historical</th> 
              <td class="navbox-list navbox-even" style="text-align:left;border-left-width:2px;border-left-style:solid;width:100%;padding:0px"> 
               <div style="padding:0em 0.25em"> 
                <ul> 
                 <li><a href="/wiki/Mursili%27s_eclipse" title="Mursili's eclipse">Mursili's eclipse</a> (1312 BC)</li> 
                 <li><a href="/wiki/Assyrian_eclipse" title="Assyrian eclipse">Assyrian eclipse</a> (763 BC)</li> 
                 <li><a href="/wiki/Eclipse_of_Thales" title="Eclipse of Thales">Eclipse of Thales</a> (585 BC)</li> 
                </ul>

          <th scope="row" class="navbox-group" style="width:1%;text-align:center;"><a href="/wiki/File:Total_Solar_Eclipse,_9_March_2016,_from_Balikpapan,_East_Kalimantan,_Indonesia.JPG" class="image" title="9 March 2016 total solar eclipse"><img alt="9 March 2016 total solar eclipse" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ec/Total_Solar_Eclipse%2C_9_March_2016%2C_from_Balikpapan%2C_East_Kalimantan%2C_Indonesia.JPG/80px-Total_Solar_Eclipse%2C_9_March_2016%2C_from_Balikpapan%2C_East_Kalimantan%2C_Indonesia.JPG" width="80" height="80" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ec/Total_Solar_Eclipse%2C_9_March_2016%2C_from_Balikpapan%2C_East_Kalimantan%2C_Indonesia.JPG/120px-Total_Solar_Eclipse%2C_9_March_2016%2C_from_Balikpapan%2C_East_Kalimantan%2C_Indonesia.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ec/Total_Solar_Eclipse%2C_9_March_2016%2C_from_Balikpapan%2C_East_Kalimantan%2C_Indonesia.JPG/160px-Total_Solar_Eclipse%2C_9_March_2016%2C_from_Balikpapan%2C_East_Kalimantan%2C_Indonesia.JPG 2x" data-file-width="750" data-file-height="751"></a><br> Total/hybrid eclipses<br> <span style="background-color: #F3D6D6">?</span> <small>next total/hybrid</small></th>

   <h1 id="firstHeading" class="firstHeading" lang="en">Solar eclipse of October 23, 2014</h1> 
   <div id="bodyContent" class="mw-body-content"> 
    <div id="siteSub" class="noprint">

    </div>

        <tr> 
         <th scope="row" style="padding:0 0.5em 0 0; line-height:1.1em;"><a href="/wiki/Saros_(astronomy)" title="Saros (astronomy)">Saros</a></th> 
         <td style="padding:0; line-height:1.2em; vertical-align:middle;"><a href="/wiki/Solar_Saros_153" title="Solar Saros 153">153</a> (9 of 70)</td> 
        </tr> 
        <tr> 
         <th scope="row" style="padding:0 0.5em 0 0; line-height:1.1em;">Catalog # (SE5000)</th> 
         <td style="padding:0; line-height:1.2em; vertical-align:middle;"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://eclipse.gsfc.nasa.gov/SEcat5/SE2011-2110.html">9540</a></td> 
        </tr> 
       </tbody>
      </table> 
      <p>A partial <a href="/wiki/Solar_eclipse" title="Solar eclipse">solar eclipse</a> occurred on October 23, 2014. A <a href="/wiki/Solar_eclipse" title="Solar eclipse">solar eclipse</a> occurs when the <a href="/wiki/Moon" title="Moon">Moon</a> passes between <a href="/wiki/Earth" title="Earth">Earth</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Sun" title="Sun">Sun</a>, thereby totally or partly obscuring the image of the Sun for a viewer on Earth. A partial solar eclipse occurs in the polar regions of the Earth when the center of the Moon's shadow misses the Earth.</p> 
      <p></p> 
      <div id="toc" class="toc"> 
       <div class="toctitle" lang="en" dir="ltr" xml:lang="en">

      <p></p> 
      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Viewing">Viewing</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Solar_eclipse_of_October_23,_2014&amp;action=edit&amp;section=1" title="Edit section: Viewing">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2> 
      <p>The center of the Moon's shadow missed the Earth, passing above the <a href="/wiki/North_Pole" title="North Pole">North Pole</a>, but a partial eclipse was visible at sunrise (October 24 local time) in far eastern <a href="/wiki/Russia" title="Russia">Russia</a>, and before sunset (October 23) across most of <a href="/wiki/North_America" title="North America">North America</a>.</p> 
      <table class="wikitable"> 
       <tbody>
        <tr> 
         <td><a href="/wiki/File:SE2014Oct23P.gif" class="image"><img alt="SE2014Oct23P.gif" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/e/e1/SE2014Oct23P.gif" width="250" height="270" data-file-width="250" data-file-height="270"></a><br> Animated path</td> 
        </tr> 
       </tbody>
      </table> 
      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Visibility">Visibility</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Solar_eclipse_of_October_23,_2014&amp;action=edit&amp;section=2" title="Edit section: Visibility">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2> 
      <p>The partial eclipse was visible in most of <a href="/wiki/North_America" title="North America">North America</a>, as well as eastern <a href="/wiki/Siberia" title="Siberia">Siberia</a>.</p> 
      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Gallery">Gallery</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Solar_eclipse_of_October_23,_2014&amp;action=edit&amp;section=3" title="Edit section: Gallery">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>

      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Related_eclipses">Related eclipses</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Solar_eclipse_of_October_23,_2014&amp;action=edit&amp;section=4" title="Edit section: Related eclipses">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2> 
      <h3><span id="Solar_eclipses_2011.E2.80.932014"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Solar_eclipses_2011–2014">Solar eclipses 2011–2014</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Solar_eclipse_of_October_23,_2014&amp;action=edit&amp;section=5" title="Edit section: Solar eclipses 2011–2014">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3> 
      <p>Each member in a <a href="/wiki/Eclipse_cycle#Eclipse_cycles" title="Eclipse cycle">semester series</a> of solar eclipses repeats approximately every 177 days and 4 hours (a semester) at alternating <a href="/wiki/Lunar_node" title="Lunar node">nodes</a> of the Moon's orbit. Note: Partial solar eclipses on <a href="/wiki/Solar_eclipse_of_January_4,_2011" title="Solar eclipse of January 4, 2011">January 4, 2011</a> and <a href="/wiki/Solar_eclipse_of_July_1,_2011" title="Solar eclipse of July 1, 2011">July 1, 2011</a> occur in the previous semester series.</p> 
      <table class="wikitable collapsible collapsed" style="text-align: center;">

      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Metonic_series">Metonic series</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Solar_eclipse_of_October_23,_2014&amp;action=edit&amp;section=6" title="Edit section: Metonic series">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3> 
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/Metonic_cycle" title="Metonic cycle">metonic series</a> repeats eclipses every 19 years (6939.69 days), lasting about 5 cycles. Eclipses occur in nearly the same calendar date. In addition, the octon subseries repeats 1/5 of that or every 3.8 years (1387.94 days).</p> 
      <table class="wikitable collapsible collapsed"> 
       <tbody>
        <tr> 
         <th colspan="5">21 eclipse events between August 12, 1942 and August 11, 2018</th> 
        </tr> 
        <tr>

         <th>May 30</th> 
         <th>March 18</th> 
         <th>January 4-5</th> 
         <th>October 23-24</th> 
        </tr>

         <td><a href="/wiki/File:SE1992Jan04A.png" class="image"><img alt="SE1992Jan04A.png" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e0/SE1992Jan04A.png/150px-SE1992Jan04A.png" width="150" height="150" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e0/SE1992Jan04A.png/225px-SE1992Jan04A.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e0/SE1992Jan04A.png/300px-SE1992Jan04A.png 2x" data-file-width="728" data-file-height="729"></a><br> <a href="/wiki/Solar_eclipse_of_January_4,_1992" title="Solar eclipse of January 4, 1992">January 4, 1992</a></td> 
         <td><a href="/wiki/File:SE1995Oct24T.png" class="image"><img alt="SE1995Oct24T.png" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/af/SE1995Oct24T.png/150px-SE1995Oct24T.png" width="150" height="150" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/af/SE1995Oct24T.png/225px-SE1995Oct24T.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/af/SE1995Oct24T.png/300px-SE1995Oct24T.png 2x" data-file-width="728" data-file-height="729"></a><br> <a href="/wiki/Solar_eclipse_of_October_24,_1995" title="Solar eclipse of October 24, 1995">October 24, 1995</a></td>

      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="References">References</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Solar_eclipse_of_October_23,_2014&amp;action=edit&amp;section=7" title="Edit section: References">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2> 
      <div class="reflist" style="list-style-type: decimal;"> 
       <div class="mw-references-wrap">

              <th scope="row" class="navbox-group" style="width:1%">Visibility</th>

              <th scope="row" class="navbox-group" style="width:1%">Historical</th> 
              <td class="navbox-list navbox-even" style="text-align:left;border-left-width:2px;border-left-style:solid;width:100%;padding:0px"> 
               <div style="padding:0em 0.25em"> 
                <ul> 
                 <li><a href="/wiki/Mursili%27s_eclipse" title="Mursili's eclipse">Mursili's eclipse</a> (1312 BC)</li> 
                 <li><a href="/wiki/Assyrian_eclipse" title="Assyrian eclipse">Assyrian eclipse</a> (763 BC)</li> 
                 <li><a href="/wiki/Eclipse_of_Thales" title="Eclipse of Thales">Eclipse of Thales</a> (585 BC)</li> 
                </ul>

          <th scope="row" class="navbox-group" style="width:1%;text-align:center;"><a href="/wiki/File:Total_Solar_Eclipse,_9_March_2016,_from_Balikpapan,_East_Kalimantan,_Indonesia.JPG" class="image" title="9 March 2016 total solar eclipse"><img alt="9 March 2016 total solar eclipse" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ec/Total_Solar_Eclipse%2C_9_March_2016%2C_from_Balikpapan%2C_East_Kalimantan%2C_Indonesia.JPG/80px-Total_Solar_Eclipse%2C_9_March_2016%2C_from_Balikpapan%2C_East_Kalimantan%2C_Indonesia.JPG" width="80" height="80" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ec/Total_Solar_Eclipse%2C_9_March_2016%2C_from_Balikpapan%2C_East_Kalimantan%2C_Indonesia.JPG/120px-Total_Solar_Eclipse%2C_9_March_2016%2C_from_Balikpapan%2C_East_Kalimantan%2C_Indonesia.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ec/Total_Solar_Eclipse%2C_9_March_2016%2C_from_Balikpapan%2C_East_Kalimantan%2C_Indonesia.JPG/160px-Total_Solar_Eclipse%2C_9_March_2016%2C_from_Balikpapan%2C_East_Kalimantan%2C_Indonesia.JPG 2x" data-file-width="750" data-file-height="751"></a><br> Total/hybrid eclipses<br> <span style="background-color: #F3D6D6">?</span> <small>next total/hybrid</small></th>

   <h1 id="firstHeading" class="firstHeading" lang="en">Earth</h1> 
   <div id="bodyContent" class="mw-body-content"> 
    <div id="siteSub" class="noprint">
     From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia
    </div> 
    <div id="contentSub"></div> 
    <div id="jump-to-nav" class="mw-jump">
      Jump to: 
     <a href="#mw-head">navigation</a>, 
     <a href="#p-search">search</a> 
    </div> 
    <div id="mw-content-text" lang="en" dir="ltr" class="mw-content-ltr">
     <div class="mw-parser-output">
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       This article is about the planet itself. For its human aspects, see 
       <a href="/wiki/World" title="World">World</a>. For other uses, see 
       <a href="/wiki/Earth_(disambiguation)" class="mw-disambig" title="Earth (disambiguation)">Earth (disambiguation)</a> or 
       <a href="/wiki/Planet_Earth_(disambiguation)" class="mw-disambig" title="Planet Earth (disambiguation)">Planet Earth (disambiguation)</a>.
      </div>

          </div> </th> 
         <td>

        <tr> 
         <th colspan="2" style="text-align:center;background-color:#c0c0ff">Atmosphere</th> 
        </tr> 
        <tr> 
         <th scope="row" style="max-width:11em;"> 
          <div style="padding:0.1em 0;line-height:1.2em;">
           Surface

          </div> </th> 
         <td><span class="nowrap"><span style="display:none" class="sortkey">7005101325000000000?</span>101.325&nbsp;<a href="/wiki/Pascal_(unit)" title="Pascal (unit)">kPa</a></span> (at <a href="/wiki/Sea_level" title="Sea level">MSL</a>)</td> 
        </tr> 
        <tr> 
         <th scope="row" style="max-width:11em;"><a href="/wiki/Atmospheric_chemistry#Atmospheric_composition" title="Atmospheric chemistry">Composition by volume</a></th> 
         <td> 
          <div class="plainlist nowrap"> 
           <ul> 
            <li>78.08% <a href="/wiki/Nitrogen" title="Nitrogen">nitrogen</a> (N<sub><small>2</small></sub>; dry air)<sup id="cite_ref-earth_fact_sheet_5-8" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-earth_fact_sheet-5">[3]</a></sup></li> 
            <li>20.95% <a href="/wiki/Oxygen" title="Oxygen">oxygen</a> (O<sub><small>2</small></sub>)</li> 
            <li>0.930% <a href="/wiki/Argon" title="Argon">argon</a></li> 
            <li>0.0402% <a href="/wiki/Carbon_dioxide" title="Carbon dioxide">carbon dioxide</a><sup id="cite_ref-NOAA_27-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-NOAA-27">[23]</a></sup></li> 
            <li>~&nbsp;1% <a href="/wiki/Water_vapor" title="Water vapor">water vapor</a> <small>(<a href="/wiki/Climate" title="Climate">climate</a>-variable)</small></li> 
           </ul> 
          </div> </td> 
        </tr> 
       </tbody>
      </table> 
      <p><b>Earth</b> is the third <a href="/wiki/Planet" title="Planet">planet</a> from the <a href="/wiki/Sun" title="Sun">Sun</a> and the only object in the <a href="/wiki/Universe" title="Universe">Universe</a> known to harbor <a href="/wiki/Life" title="Life">life</a>. According to <a href="/wiki/Radiometric_dating" title="Radiometric dating">radiometric dating</a> and other sources of evidence, Earth <a href="/wiki/Age_of_the_Earth" title="Age of the Earth">formed</a> over 4 <a href="/wiki/Bya" title="Bya">billion years ago</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-USGS1997_28-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-USGS1997-28">[24]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-29" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-29">[25]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-30" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-30">[26]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Gravity_of_Earth" title="Gravity of Earth">Earth's gravity</a> interacts with other objects in space, especially the Sun and the <a href="/wiki/Moon" title="Moon">Moon</a>, Earth's only <a href="/wiki/Natural_satellite" title="Natural satellite">natural satellite</a>. Earth <a href="/wiki/Earth%27s_orbit" title="Earth's orbit">revolves around the Sun</a> in 365.26 days, a period known as an Earth <a href="/wiki/Year" title="Year">year</a>. During this time, Earth <a href="/wiki/Earth%27s_rotation" title="Earth's rotation">rotates about its axis</a> about 366.26 times.<sup id="cite_ref-sidereal_solar_31-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-sidereal_solar-31">[n 5]</a></sup></p> 
      <p>Earth's <a href="#Axial_tilt_and_seasons">axis of rotation</a> is tilted, producing <a href="/wiki/Season" title="Season">seasonal variations</a> on the planet's surface.<sup id="cite_ref-yoder1995_32-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-yoder1995-32">[27]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Gravity" title="Gravity">gravitational interaction</a> between the Earth and Moon causes <a href="/wiki/Tide" title="Tide">ocean tides</a>, stabilizes the Earth's orientation on its axis, and gradually slows its rotation.<sup id="cite_ref-aaa428_261_33-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-aaa428_261-33">[28]</a></sup> Earth is the densest planet in the <a href="/wiki/Solar_System" title="Solar System">Solar System</a> and the largest of the four <a href="/wiki/Terrestrial_planet" title="Terrestrial planet">terrestrial planets</a>.</p> 
      <p><a href="/wiki/Lithosphere#Earth's_lithosphere" title="Lithosphere">Earth's lithosphere</a> is divided into several rigid <a href="/wiki/Plate_tectonics" title="Plate tectonics">tectonic plates</a> that migrate across the surface over periods of many millions of years. About 71% of Earth's surface is <a href="/wiki/Water_distribution_on_Earth" title="Water distribution on Earth">covered with water</a>, mostly by <a href="/wiki/Ocean" title="Ocean">oceans</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-34" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-34">[29]</a></sup> The remaining 29% is <a href="/wiki/Land#History_of_land_on_Earth" title="Land">land</a> consisting of <a href="/wiki/Continent" title="Continent">continents</a> and <a href="/wiki/Island" title="Island">islands</a> that together have many lakes, rivers and other sources of water that contribute to the <a href="/wiki/Hydrosphere" title="Hydrosphere">hydrosphere</a>. The majority of <a href="/wiki/Polar_regions_of_Earth" title="Polar regions of Earth">Earth's polar regions</a> are covered in ice, including the <a href="/wiki/Antarctic_ice_sheet" title="Antarctic ice sheet">Antarctic ice sheet</a> and the sea ice of the Arctic ice pack. Earth's interior remains active with a solid iron inner core, a liquid outer core that generates the <a href="/wiki/Earth%27s_magnetic_field" title="Earth's magnetic field">Earth's magnetic field</a>, and a convecting <a href="/wiki/Mantle_(geology)" title="Mantle (geology)">mantle</a> that drives plate tectonics.</p> 
      <p>Within the first billion years of <a href="/wiki/History_of_Earth" title="History of Earth">Earth's history</a>, life appeared in the oceans and began to affect the <a href="/wiki/Atmosphere_of_Earth" title="Atmosphere of Earth">Earth's atmosphere</a> and surface, leading to the proliferation of <a href="/wiki/Aerobic_organism" title="Aerobic organism">aerobic</a> and <a href="/wiki/Anaerobic_organism" title="Anaerobic organism">anaerobic organisms</a>. Some geological evidence indicates that life may have arisen as much as 4.1&nbsp;billion years ago. Since then, the combination of Earth's distance from the Sun, physical properties, and <a href="/wiki/Geological_history_of_Earth" title="Geological history of Earth">geological history</a> have allowed life to evolve and thrive.<sup id="cite_ref-AP-20151019_35-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-AP-20151019-35">[30]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-PNAS-20151014-pdf_36-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-PNAS-20151014-pdf-36">[31]</a></sup> In the history of the Earth, <a href="/wiki/Biodiversity" title="Biodiversity">biodiversity</a> has gone through long periods of expansion, occasionally punctuated by <a href="/wiki/Extinction_event" title="Extinction event">mass extinction events</a>. Over 99% of all <a href="/wiki/Species" title="Species">species</a><sup id="cite_ref-Book-Biology_37-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Book-Biology-37">[32]</a></sup> that ever lived on Earth are <a href="/wiki/Extinct" class="mw-redirect" title="Extinct">extinct</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-StearnsStearns2000_38-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-StearnsStearns2000-38">[33]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-NYT-20141108-MJN_39-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-NYT-20141108-MJN-39">[34]</a></sup> Estimates of the number of species on Earth today vary widely;<sup id="cite_ref-science_241_4872_1441_40-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-science_241_4872_1441-40">[35]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-MillerSpoolman2012_41-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-MillerSpoolman2012-41">[36]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-NSF-2016002_42-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-NSF-2016002-42">[37]</a></sup> most species have not been described.<sup id="cite_ref-PLoS-20110823_43-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-PLoS-20110823-43">[38]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/World_population" title="World population">Over 7.6&nbsp;billion humans</a> live on Earth and depend on its <a href="/wiki/Biosphere" title="Biosphere">biosphere</a> and <a href="/wiki/Natural_resources" class="mw-redirect" title="Natural resources">natural resources</a> for their survival. Humans have developed diverse <a href="/wiki/Society" title="Society">societies</a> and <a href="/wiki/Culture" title="Culture">cultures</a>; politically, the world has <a href="/wiki/List_of_sovereign_states" title="List of sovereign states">about 200 sovereign states</a>.</p>
